paragraph1: In a realm suspended between the tangible and the ethereal, two souls, a blind man and Jim Singer, found themselves recounting their surreal journeys through what seemed to be an afterlife. The blind man, his sightless eyes conveying a deep-seated wonder, narrated the moment he traversed a desert composed of living sand. The grains, animated and pulsating, surged around him, enveloping him in a realization of his own demise as they throbbed like the rhythmic beating of a heart. This desert was not just a landscape but a revelation, the sand whispering secrets of the transition from life to death. Meanwhile, Jim Singer, a humble sandwich shop manager, shared his own extraordinary voyage. He spoke of dying peacefully in his bed, only to awaken on a train journeying through a forest populated by towering giraffes. The giraffe spots swirled around him in a dance of colors and patterns, a kaleidoscope of life he had left behind. Each turn of the train's wheels seemed to echo a deeper understanding of his existence and its cessation. Both men, through their narratives, conveyed a profound sense of wonder and enlightenment at their own deaths, as if they had stumbled upon a threshold of existence that defied earthly comprehension. Their stories, though distinct, were intertwined by a shared recognition of the afterlife's enigmatic beauty. As they spoke, the world around them seemed to fade, leaving only the vivid recollections of their journeys. The paragraph captures their experiences from an external viewpoint, yet it delves into the heart of their revelations, offering a glimpse into the mysterious realms beyond life, where the boundaries of reality blur and the soul embarks on a journey of discovery and acceptance.
paragraph2: When the blind man arrived in the city, he claimed that he had travelled across a desert of living sand. First he had died, he said, and then—snap!—the desert. He told the story to everyone who would listen, bobbing his head to follow the sound of their footsteps. Showers of red grit fell from his beard. He said that the desert was bare and lonesome and that it had hissed at him like a snake. He had walked for days and days, until the dunes broke apart beneath his feet, surging up around him to lash at his face, then everything went still and began to beat like a heart. The sound was as clear as any he had ever heard. It was only at that moment, he said, with a million arrow-points of sand striking his skin, that he had truly realized he was dead. Jim Singer, who managed the sandwich shop in the monument district, said that he had felt a prickling sensation in his fingers and then stopped breathing. “It was my heart,” he insisted, thumping on his chest. “Took me in my own bed.” He had closed his eyes, and when he opened them again he was on a train, the kind that trolleys small children around in circles at amusement parks. The rails were leading him through a thick forest of gold-brown trees, but the trees were actually giraffes, and their long necks were reaching like branches into the sky. A wind rose up and peeled the spots from their backs. The spots floated down around him, swirling and dipping in the wake of the train. It took him a long time to understand that the throbbing noise he heard was not the rattling of the wheels along the tracks.

paragraph1: After Christmas, I looked for a job. The ads in the newspaper were for low-paying jobs, like file clerk or telephone solicitor or receptionist. My mother drove me to interviews for maybe a week before I found a secretarial position that didn’t require experience, working for a lawyer in Westland named Ned Johnson. The office was in a small house, brick, with stiff fir trees on either side of the door and a flower box under the window. My mother waited in the car while I went to the door. Ned Johnson was there by himself. Given that he would wander my dream-mind for decades, I don’t know why my memory of our first meeting is so vague, obscured by disconnected feelings that move like clouds or greasy smoke across the receding moment. He was a short, thick-bodied man with deep, shining, active eyes. I was startled by him without knowing why. During the interview, I said weird things I wouldn’t normally say. He told me that the job was dull, and I said, “I like dull work.” He stared as if he were insulted, and I thought the interview was over—but instead he said something weird. He said, “There’s something off about you. You’re closed and tight, like a wall.” And I just said, “I know.” When my mother asked how the interview went, I said, “I don’t think he liked me.” But the next day a girl called and told me he wanted to hire me. She said I could start tomorrow if it was convenient. My parents were really happy. I remember my father smiling, holding a can of beer and some peanuts; there was something special for dessert. The people who came into the office were odds and ends in human form: a man with a scar on his face who was suing his neighbors because their dog barked “all goddam day,” a middle-aged Black woman in mod teen clothes, an old Russian lady in a purple coat. The furniture, too, was comically mismatched, and there was too much of it for the low-ceilinged rectangular room: two cheap swollen couches faced each other before my grossly big oak desk, which itself pointlessly faced two haughty high-backed armchairs, positioned as if for an important meeting that never took place. But I liked the strange furniture. It made the lawyer seem more human because it offset his extreme consistency, his choppy economical movements, his always shining eyes. His style of training was loud and cheerful, full of stressful encouragement. When I did something right, he would clap his hands and say, “She’s coming along!” If I made a mistake, he would say, “Slowly, slowly!” or “Just do the best you can!” It was the same voice he used to greet a client he liked, the old lady from Russia who wore the purple coat with a thick sash knotted around her crumpled waist. She was the only foreigner I had ever met and she was the only person the lawyer came out of his office to meet, instead of just buzzing me to send her in. When she was next on the list, he would open his door and say, “There’s my girlfriend!,” and she would rise and wobble toward him with fierce, caneless dignity. His attention to her made me trust him. Because there were clients that he did not like at all and he didn’t bother to hide it from me, saying things like “He is completely crazy” or “I feel sorry for her husband.” He was sincere in his likes and dislikes. When Donna asked me how the job was, I said, “It’s O.K.” But I liked it more than that because it was so much better than school. At school, I’d had no friends, except for a girl named Sandy, and the only thing we had in common was that we both liked animals. I almost never talked, because I didn’t know how; I couldn’t understand the way other kids talked to one another. I felt afraid all the time. I was afraid of saying something wrong, and I was afraid of being mocked or bullied the way I had been in elementary school. What was strange about this: I was good with words. I was in honors English and history because I could write papers. But I couldn’t make my ability with written words transfer to the bewildering clash of people talking, their faces and voices coloring their words with too many expressions to respond to. My skill in English was so useless that I despised it; even my parents didn’t care that much about it. It wasn’t like that in the lawyer’s office. His voice and his face were like traffic signals; they always said some version of the same thing. I could not have explained what the thing was but it didn’t matter: I knew what I was supposed to do. He cared about my skills. I had said weird things and he had said them back, but it didn’t interfere with the rhythm of our time together. The things he said were no different from him telling me to type a letter or find a document.
paragraph2: After Christmas, my search for employment became a daily ritual, with my mother dutifully driving me to various interviews across town, her unwavering support both comforting and slightly pressuring as we navigated the winter streets together. It wasn't until we reached the law office of Ned Johnson in Westland that something finally clicked, though at the time, the experience felt surreal and disconnected, like watching scenes from someone else's life play out before me. Ned Johnson himself was an intriguing figure – a short, thick-bodied man whose active eyes seemed to catch every detail while simultaneously conveying a warmth that put me at ease despite my nervousness. The interview itself was anything but conventional; we exchanged what could only be described as odd remarks, our conversation meandering through topics that seemed barely related to the secretarial position I was applying for, yet somehow this unusual dynamic worked in my favor. When he offered me the job, I felt a mixture of relief and curiosity about what working in this peculiar environment would entail. My parents' evident pleasure at my securing the position added another layer of complexity to my emotions, their approval both reassuring and slightly overwhelming. The office itself was a reflection of Ned's personality – charmingly mismatched furniture created an atmosphere that was more living room than law office, and the parade of eccentric clients who passed through the door each day added color and interest to my daily routine. What struck me most was Ned's teaching style; unlike my school experiences where I had often felt isolated and afraid, his approach was consistently encouraging and sincere, making even the most challenging tasks seem manageable. There was something deeply comforting about the predictability of our office interactions, the clear communication and expectations that allowed me to gradually build confidence in my abilities. The filing systems, phone protocols, and legal documentation processes that initially seemed daunting became familiar territory under his patient guidance, and I found myself developing a sense of competence that had eluded me in previous settings. The contrast between the structured yet nurturing environment of Ned's office and my prior experiences of feeling lost and undervalued was stark, and I began to understand that sometimes the most unexpected opportunities can lead to the most significant personal growth. Each day brought new challenges, from dealing with difficult clients to mastering complex legal terminology, but Ned's unwavering support and genuine interest in my development made these challenges feel like stepping stones rather than obstacles. The office became more than just a workplace; it transformed into a space where I could be myself while learning and growing professionally, where mistakes were viewed as learning opportunities rather than failures, and where the quirky atmosphere and diverse clientele created a uniquely accepting environment. Looking back, I realize that what might have seemed like an odd fit at first glance – the nervous job seeker and the unconventional lawyer – turned out to be exactly what I needed at that point in my life. The position offered not just employment but a chance to develop skills and confidence in an environment that celebrated individuality while maintaining professional standards. Ned's approach to mentoring, combined with the office's welcoming atmosphere, helped me overcome my previous insecurities and discover capabilities I hadn't known I possessed. The daily routine of managing appointments, handling correspondence, and interacting with clients became more than just job duties; they became opportunities to prove to myself that I could handle responsibility and contribute meaningfully to something larger than myself. The mismatched furniture and eclectic collection of clients that initially seemed strange became symbolic of the office's accepting nature, where differences were celebrated rather than criticize

Ned Johnson was there by himself. Given that he would wander my dream-mind for decades, I don’t know why my memory of our first meeting is so vague, obscured by disconnected feelings that move like clouds or greasy smoke across the receding moment. He was a short, thick-bodied man with deep, shining, active eyes. I was startled by him without knowing why. During the interview, I said weird things I wouldn’t normally say. He told me that the job was dull, and I said, “I like dull work.” He stared as if he were insulted, and I thought the interview was over—but instead he said something weird. He said, “There’s something off about you. You’re closed and tight, like a wall.” And I just said, “I know.” When my mother asked how the interview went, I said, “I don’t think he liked me.” But the next day a girl called and told me he wanted to hire me. paragraph1: Todd Browne exited the elevator, whistling, as Charlotte moved in for a second, firmer embrace of Gerald. “Merry, merry,” Todd said, nodding as he passed. Charlotte held Gerald tightly around the waist and was crying against his lapel. “You and your wonderful clothes, your perfect clothes, your perfect friends, your uptight, ruinous friends,” she said, head thrown back, her mascara-streaked eyes looking directly into his. Ruinous friends? She was wearing stockings with a run down one calf, and short red boots. Her eyes were as red as her footwear. That was hyperbole; still, her eyes were alarmingly red from such a brief burst of crying. “Let’s get a drink,” he said, finally finding his voice and leading Charlotte to the door. “Merry Christmas,” he said, nodding to the soldier-straight doorman as they walked past him. “And to all a good night,” he heard himself adding. He turned toward Charlotte, giving her a false smile. “And laying his finger aside of his nose . . .” “Oh, why don’t you just admit you’re discombobulated, instead of talking nonsense, like some proud little schoolboy who’s memorized his lesson,” she said when they got outside. “If you can’t tell, the last thing I need is another drink. I wasn’t even able to come upstairs. Let’s go to Rockefeller Center. The tree’s being lit tonight. It’s what people do in New York at Christmas. They have cocktail parties and they go off to see the tree. I had my cocktail party alone, while you had yours with your wonderful friends.” He put his arm around her shoulders. There were many puddles, though it was not, at the moment, raining. It was difficult to walk with his arm around her shoulders, her gait was so irregular, so he let go and clasped her hand.
paragraph2: As Todd Browne stepped out of the elevator, a cheerful whistle escaped his lips, accompanied by a festive "Merry, merry" as he passed by Charlotte and Gerald. However, his holiday cheer was starkly contrasted by the distressing scene unfolding before him. Charlotte, her eyes streaked with mascara and her stockings marred by a noticeable run, clung to Gerald, her body shaking with sobs as she cried against his lapel. Her emotional state was further exacerbated by her disheveled appearance, a testament to the turmoil brewing within. Gerald, attempting to offer comfort, suggested they grab a drink, gently guiding her out of the building as they exchanged holiday greetings with the doorman. Once outside, Charlotte's emotional outburst continued, with her accusing Gerald of being disoriented and insisting they head to Rockefeller Center to witness the Christmas tree lighting. Her frustration stemmed from having spent the evening alone, a fact that only added to her already fragile state. As Gerald attempted to support her by placing a reassuring arm around her shoulders, her unsteady gait forced him to hold her hand instead, a gesture that seemed to offer a semblance of stability in the midst of her emotional turmoil.

paragraph1: Fenway Park stands as more than just a baseball stadium; it's a living museum where the ghosts of Ted Williams and Carl Yastrzemski still roam. But beyond the Green Monster and the crack of bats, the park serves as a gateway to Boston's cultural tapestry. A short walk leads to the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, where stolen masterpieces leave empty frames and whisper of an unsolved mystery. The contrast between the boisterous ballpark and the hushed galleries is stark, yet both spaces hold stories of passion and dedication. Nearby, the Time Out Market buzzes with local flavors, offering a modern counterpoint to Fenway's timeless appeal. Here, lobster rolls and craft beers mingle with the scent of new ideas and old traditions. As visitors move between these spaces, they traverse not just city blocks, but layers of Boston's identity. The peanuts and cracker jacks give way to fine art and culinary innovation, yet the thread of local pride runs through it all. In this compact area, one can experience the full spectrum of Boston's character: it's love for sports, it's reverence for art, and it's evolving palate.

paragraph1: We embarked on an educational journey with a group of about thirty children, aiming to teach them about root systems and instill a sense of responsibility by planting orange trees. The excitement was palpable as we dug into the earth, each child carefully placing a sapling into the ground, envisioning a future where their trees would bear fruit. However, our hopes were dashed when, despite our dedication, all the trees succumbed, possibly due to poor soil or subpar supplies from the nursery. Watching the children gaze upon the lifeless trees was heart-wrenching, as the once vibrant scene turned into a visual of desolation. The situation reminded me of another recent incident when all the snakes in our care died after the boiler was shut off for four days during a strike. Unlike the trees, this was easier to explain to the children; they understood the strike's implications and the lack of heat. Yet, it was a stark lesson on the fragility of life and the impact of external circumstances beyond our control. Both experiences served as somber reminders of the challenges we face in nurturing life and the importance of resilience in the face of disappointment. As I stood among the children, I pondered how we could turn these unfortunate events into valuable lessons, hoping to inspire a deeper understanding and appreciation for the delicate balance of nature.
paragraph2: Well, we had all these children out planting trees, see, because we figured that . . . that was part of their education, to see how, you know, the root systems . . . and also the sense of responsibility, taking care of things, being individually responsible. You know what I mean. And the trees all died. They were orange trees. I don’t know why they died, they just died. Something wrong with the soil possibly or maybe the stuff we got from the nursery . . . wasn’t the best. We complained about it. So we’ve got thirty kids there, each kid has his or her own little tree to plant, and we’ve got these thirty dead trees. All these kids looking at these little brown sticks, it was depressing. It wouldn’t have been so bad except that . . . Before that, just a couple of weeks before the thing with the trees, the snakes all died. But I think that the snakes—well, the reason that the snakes kicked off was that . . . you remember, the boiler was shut off for four days because of the strike, and that was explicable. It was something you could explain to the kids because of the strike. I mean, none of their parents would let them cross the picket line and they knew there was a strike going on and what it meant. So when things got started up again and we found the snakes they weren’t too disturbed.

paragraph1: As I stood there, I couldn't help but feel a wave of regret wash over me, and I turned to her, my voice laced with apology, "I'm so sorry for yelling, I feel terrible about it." She smiled, her eyes sparkling with amusement, and I was reminded of the countless times we'd spent together, our bond strengthened by her being my cousin Ernest's partner, making her more than just a friend, but family. She playfully reached out and tickled me, sending me into a fit of laughter, my breath catching in my throat as I tried to squirm away. The moment was a much-needed respite from the chaos that had been my day so far. I had missed my morning classes, and to make matters worse, I was running late for my shift at the cafeteria. As I rushed to get ready, I couldn't shake off the feeling of inadequacy that had been plaguing me lately. I thought back to the advice Beverly and Kay had given me, about how I needed to be more confident, more outgoing, if I wanted to catch the eye of a guy. But every time I tried, I seemed to get it wrong, and I couldn't help but feel like I was stuck in some kind of rut. After a hectic shift at the cafeteria, I decided to head to the library to work on an essay that was due soon. As I walked through the tunnel that connected the buildings, I was bombarded by advertisements plastered on the walls - "Get fit with our gym membership", "Eat healthy with our meal plans" - the usual college fare. But one notice caught my eye, a recital announcement that brought back memories of a poem by Housman we had studied in class. The lines "That is the land of lost content, I see it shining plain, the happy highways where I went and cannot come again" echoed in my mind, and I felt a pang of shame wash over me. It was a memory I had tried to bury, but it still lingered, a reminder of a past experience that I would rather forget. I pushed the thoughts aside and focused on my essay, but the words of the poem lingered, a haunting reminder of the fragility of life and the choices we make.
paragraph2: “O.K.,” I said. “Sorry I yelled at you. Did I yell? I’m sorry. You’re our friend and you brought me my things and I appreciate it. You’re Ernest’s cousin and you’re our family.” She slipped behind me and her fingers darted into my armpits and she began to tickle me, at first lazily and then furiously. “Aren’t you? Aren’t you?” I tried to get free but I couldn’t. I went into spasms of suffering laughter and wriggled and cried out and begged her to stop. Which she did, when she had me quite helpless, and both of us were out of breath. “You’re the ticklishest person I ever met,” she said. I had to wait a long time for the bus, stamping my feet on the pavement. When I got to the college, I had missed my second class, as well as the first, and I was late for my work in the cafeteria. I changed into my green cotton uniform in the broom closet and pushed my mop of black hair (the worst hair in the world for showing up in food, the manager had warned me) under a cotton snood. I was supposed to get the sandwiches and salads out on the shelves before the doors opened for lunch, but now I had to do it with an impatient line of people watching me. I thought of what Beverly and Kay had said, about spoiling my chances with men, marking myself off in the wrong way. How scornful I’d been when they said it, but maybe they’d been right, after all. It appeared that, except in examinations, I got many things wrong. After I’d finished cleaning up the cafeteria tables, I changed back into my ordinary clothes and went to the college library to work on my essay. An underground tunnel fed from the Arts Building to the library, and on bulletin boards around the entrance to this tunnel were posted advertisements for movies and restaurants and used bicycles and typewriters, as well as notices for plays and concerts. The Music Department announced that a free recital of songs composed to fit the poems of the English country poets would be presented on a date that had now passed. I had seen this notice before, and did not have to look at it to be reminded of the names: Herrick, Housman, Tennyson. A few steps into the tunnel the lines began to assault me: On Wenlock Edge the wood’s in trouble. Had he known? Had he known that I would never think of those lines again without feeling the prickle of the upholstery on my bare haunches? The sticky prickly shame. A far greater shame it seemed now than at the time. He had got me, in spite of myself.

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
As I stood there, I couldn't help but feel a wave of regret wash over me, and I turned to her, my voice laced with apology, "I'm so sorry for yelling, I feel terrible about it." She smiled, her eyes sparkling with amusement, and I was reminded of the countless times we'd spent together, our bond strengthened by her being my cousin Ernest's partner, making her more than just a friend, but family. She playfully reached out and tickled me, sending me into a fit of laughter, my breath catching in my throat as I tried to squirm away. The moment was a much-needed respite from the chaos that had been my day so far. I had missed my morning classes, and to make matters worse, I was running late for my shift at the cafeteria. As I rushed to get ready, I couldn't shake off the feeling of inadequacy that had been plaguing me lately. I thought back to the advice Beverly and Kay had given me, about how I needed to be more confident, more outgoing, if I wanted to catch the eye of a guy. But every time I tried, I seemed to get it wrong, and I couldn't help but feel like I was stuck in some kind of rut. After a hectic shift at the cafeteria, I decided to head to the library to work on an essay that was due soon. As I walked through the tunnel that connected the buildings, I was bombarded by advertisements plastered on the walls - "Get fit with our gym membership", "Eat healthy with our meal plans" - the usual college fare. But one notice caught my eye, a recital announcement that brought back memories of a poem by Housman we had studied in class. The lines "That is the land of lost content, I see it shining plain, the happy highways where I went and cannot come again" echoed in my mind, and I felt a pang of shame wash over me. It was a memory I had tried to bury, but it still lingered, a reminder of a past experience that I would rather forget. I pushed the thoughts aside and focused on my essay, but the words of the poem lingered, a haunting reminder of the fragility of life and the choices we make.

paragraph1: She sat in BWI, straddling a small suitcase with a photograph in it's information tag. Her father had always said that his birthday was the one day of the year when the Universe aligned in his favor. She didn't believe that, now that he'd divorced her mother and revealed that he'd had a second family for years. Then again, today was his birthday, and here she was going to meet him, and them. Had he been trying to convince himself, or her, that life was kinder than it truly was? A Delta attendant came on the PA and announced another delay to her flight. She took a deep breath, took out the photograph, and tried to focus on the faces that were about to become her new reality.
paragraph2: As she sat in the airport, clutching a small suitcase and a faded photograph, the girl's mind began to wander to her father's words. He had always said that his birthday was the one day of the year when the universe aligned in his favor, when even mosquito bites felt like a gentle reminder of life's beauty. But now, as she waited to meet the family he had kept hidden from her, she couldn't shake the feeling that his sayings were just that - words, empty and insubstantial. She thought about the countless times he had promised to take her to meet his family, only to cancel at the last minute, citing work or illness. The girl's emotions swirled, a mix of excitement and trepidation, as she wondered what this new family would be like, whether they would welcome her with open arms or regard her as a stranger. Her father's sayings, once comforting, now seemed like a flimsy shield against the uncertainty that lay ahead. She recalled the way he would scratch at mosquito bites, his eyes closed in a look of exaggerated bliss, and felt a pang of sadness. Had he been trying to convince himself, or her, that life was kinder than it truly was? As she glanced around the airport, the girl felt a sense of disconnection, as if she were hovering between two worlds, neither here nor there. The sound of announcements and muted conversations created a sense of background hum, a reminder that life was moving forward, regardless of her doubts. She took a deep breath, smoothing out the photograph, and tried to focus on the faces that were about to become her new reality. But her mind kept drifting back to her father, wondering what he had been searching for all these years, and whether she was about to find it for him.

paragraph1: None of that matters when I experience the undeniable presence, the unique truth a particular song can deliver—your song, “URML,” my best example—because then I know time, my time, my life is always more than it appears to me. Didn’t that voice, that snatch of music just remind me that there’s more in any moment, more to the life I think I’m caught up in, than I can ever know, ever understand, ever come to terms with, make peace with, survive, so much more and more and different and other than it had seemed an instant before the music. If I listen, if I let it be, let it alone, just listen to the music while it delivers inklings and intimations of things very different than I thought they were, are, and sometimes I do go there, into a different space, thank you, thank you, the music reveals, that other, more than possible place, and I go there, can’t help myself, because I need it, need help so much, I do, I do, I yearn, I hear the music and nothing is what it was an instant before or ever after, maybe, if I listen, keep believing, learning my life is less than nothing and also perhaps a tiny, tiny bit more than everything I believed I already knew, every damned body already knows, if I really listen, let myself hear when a song speaks. Link copied How do you work the magic of your art, Mr. Jackson. What makes your music special when it’s special. How do you offer a space with your voice that feels real enough for a listener to enter. What secrets have you learned to please an audience. How do you put all of yourself into a song, but then disappear so there’s only music and it belongs to the listener. When your voice breaks silence, how does it make silence speak. You did it at least once, certainly, for my son and probably countless times for others, including me. How does a song reach out and touch. Do you sing to please yourself. When a song feels good to you while you are singing it, is that the best test. Is that the answer to all this letter’s dumb questions. Or maybe simply an answer I want, need. “URML” ’s secret.
paragraph2: Listening to "URML," a song by Mr. Jackson, has fundamentally altered my perception of life and time, offering an experience so profound that it seems to transcend the ordinary boundaries of understanding. As I immerse myself in its rhythm and melody, I find myself transported to a mental realm where life's significance shifts, becoming both more and less than I previously imagined. There's a transformative power in the music that unveils hidden truths and possibilities, whispering secrets that feel both personal and universal. I feel an immense gratitude for this gift, for the way it gently nudges me to view the world through a different lens, where the mundane becomes magical and the complex becomes simple. It is as if Mr. Jackson has unlocked a door to another dimension, inviting me and my son to step through and explore the boundless potential of our existence. I often find myself pondering the magic behind Mr. Jackson's artistry, questioning how he manages to create music that resonates so deeply with the listener. How does he craft something that feels so intimately personal, yet speaks to the collective human experience? This mystery is part of what makes the song so powerful; it touches the soul, stirring emotions that lie dormant and awakening a sense of wonder that is both exhilarating and humbling. As the music plays, I watch my son, mesmerized, as he too is swept away by its beauty, and I am reminded of the universal language of music that connects us all. Together, we are caught in the spell of "URML," carried along a journey that defies time, where past, present, and future merge into a single, harmonious moment. It is an exploration of the power of music and the mysteries of artistic expression that leave me in awe, grateful for the ability to experience such profound beauty. In these moments, I am reminded that music, in its purest form, is a testament to the human spirit's capacity to create, connect, and transform. It is a reminder of the potential for art to reach into the depths of our being, reshaping perceptions and touching lives in ways that words alone cannot convey.

paragraph1: Perched on the edge of her new bed, Louisa traced her fingers along the unfamiliar quilt pattern while stealing glances at the art supplies scattered across the wooden desk by the window, their presence both inviting and somehow intrusive in this strange space she was expected to call home. The death of her father three weeks ago had thrust her into a world populated by relatives she'd never known existed – her Aunt Marie and Uncle Jerry Brickner – whose sudden appearance in her life felt like characters stepping out of a book she'd never meant to read. Uncle Jerry, with his forced smiles and awkward attempts at conversation over breakfast, seemed to be trying too hard to bridge a gap that felt more like a chasm to Louisa, his questions about her school preferences and favorite foods landing like pebbles tossed into a deep well, echoing but never quite reaching the bottom. The room they'd prepared for her was thoughtfully arranged, she had to admit, with watercolors, colored pencils, and pristine sketchbooks laid out as if in anticipation of an artist's touch, but it was the collection of dolls on the shelf that truly caught her attention. Their tiny, perfect features and miniature clothes transported her back to the dollhouse her father had crafted for her sixth birthday – a labor of love that had taken him months to complete, with its hand-painted walls and tiny furniture he'd carved himself. She remembered how she'd spent countless hours arranging and rearranging the diminutive rooms, creating elaborate stories for the tiny family that lived there, each piece of furniture holding its own significance in her carefully constructed world. That dollhouse had been her sanctuary, a place where she could control every aspect of life in a way that real life never allowed, and now, sitting in this room filled with well-meaning strangers' attempts to make her feel at home, she longed for that sense of control again. The art supplies and dolls, while generous gestures from her aunt and uncle, served as bittersweet reminders of a life she'd lost, a life where her father's presence had made even the smallest spaces feel like home. Now, surrounded by these new possessions in this unfamiliar room, Louisa felt more than ever like a doll herself, placed carefully in a new house but somehow not quite belonging to the scene around her.
paragraph2: Louisa doubted her aunt felt this way. Until she and her mother had moved here, Louisa had never heard of this aunt or uncle—her mother’s brother, whom Louisa was now meant to pretend she’d known about her whole life. Her whole ten years of life, during which she had never heard their names, or seen their photos, or received a card or a gift from them on her birthday, had never answered the telephone to hear either one of them ask for her mother or her father. Now she lived in their house and drank orange juice with them staring at her. They behaved toward her the way all adults had since her father had died: with a combination of hearty attention and squeamish discomfort. “Brick-ner, like this ugly brick building we’re in,” the man had added heartily. “That’s how you can remember! But my first name is Jerry, and I’d like you to just call me that. Can I call you Louisa?” “So I don’t need to remember,” she said. “What’s that?” He pointed his grin at her. “What did you say?” “I said I don’t need to remember ‘Brickner, like this ugly brick building,’ because you said I should just call you Jerry.” The man reared back and raised his eyebrows. “Let me guess—you’re a very smart girl.” “At least smart enough to be in fifth grade.” “Oh, I’ll bet. Oh, I’m sure there’s no doubt about that,” “Jerry” blathered, not listening, which was how she had understood that the appointment was not about her grade level. The room was full of admittedly interesting things: art supplies and those faceless wooden figures meant for posing, as well as actual dolls of different sorts, ranging from the sloppy-floppy Raggedy Ann style to the “realistic infant” style, with a hard plastic head, hands, and feet and a queasily soft trunk, arms, and legs, to wild-haired Barbies and those soldier Barbies for boys, the G.I. Joes. There was an intriguing if off-kilter doll house, the kind that was meant to be played with and not just admired, with cluttered furnishings in slightly different sizes, as if there had been disagreement about which scale to use. Louisa knew about scale, about one foot = one inch. Her father had made her a doll house the year she turned six. First grade had been the year of her passion for a store at the mall called It’s a Small World, which sold elaborate miniature homes that she would gaze into, mesmerized, with the peculiar sensation of leaving her body and slipping in amid those wee wonderful things, things she lacked the words for and so had to learn one by one—fireplace irons and grandfather clocks and hat stands and claw-footed armoires.

paragraph1: I sat across from Neal, barely registering his elaborate tales of weekend adventures, my mind fixated on the one question that had been haunting me for months. When I finally interrupted him to ask about Caro, his expression shifted from animated to somber. "Look," he said, leaning forward, "sometimes people do things without fully understanding the consequences." I watched him carefully choose his words as he continued to explain how Caro might have been crying out for attention, or perhaps she simply hadn't realized how dangerous her actions would be that day. The counselor had suggested something similar during our sessions, theorizing that Caro's impulsiveness stemmed from deeper emotional turmoil, but Neal's perspective felt more genuine, less clinical. Ruthann had her own theory, insisting that we were all somehow complicit in what happened, but Neal dismissed such collective guilt as unproductive. "You can't keep torturing yourself with 'what ifs,'" he advised, his voice gentler than I'd ever heard it. "Life has to go on, and you have to find your way to happiness, regardless of the circumstances that brought you here." His words made sense intellectually, but they couldn't erase the image seared into my memory: Caro running towards the water, her figure silhouetted against the setting sun, her decision already made before any of us could react. I nodded at Neal's wisdom while my mind rebelliously clung to that final scene, wondering if there would ever be a time when the weight of that moment wouldn't press so heavily on my conscience.
paragraph2: “Anyway, I don’t think my life style is so interesting. I think you might want to know how it happened.” I could not figure out how to speak. “I was stoned,” he said. “And, furthermore, I’m not a swimmer. Not many swimming pools around where I grew up. I’d have drowned, too. Is that what you wanted to know?” I said that he was not really the one that I was wondering about. Then he became the third person I’d asked, “What do you think Caro had in mind?” The counsellor had said that we couldn’t know. “Likely she herself didn’t know what she wanted. Attention? I don’t think she meant to drown herself. Attention to how bad she was feeling?” Ruthann had said, “To make your mother do what she wanted? Make her smarten up and see that she had to go back to your father?” Neal said, “It doesn’t matter. Maybe she thought she could paddle better than she could. Maybe she didn’t know how heavy winter clothes can get. Or that there wasn’t anybody in a position to help her.” He said to me, “Don’t waste your time. You’re not thinking what if you had hurried up and told, are you? Not trying to get in on the guilt?” I said that I had considered what he was saying, but no. “The thing is to be happy,” he said. “No matter what. Just try that. You can. It gets to be easier and easier. It’s nothing to do with circumstances. You wouldn’t believe how good it is. Accept everything and then tragedy disappears. Or tragedy lightens, anyway, and you’re just there, going along easy in the world.” Now, goodbye. I see what he meant. It really is the right thing to do. But, in my mind, Caro keeps running at the water and throwing herself, as if in triumph, and I’m still caught, waiting for her to explain to me, waiting for the splash.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
I sat across from Neal, barely registering his elaborate tales of weekend adventures, my mind fixated on the one question that had been haunting me for months. When I finally interrupted him to ask about Caro, his expression shifted from animated to somber. "Look," he said, leaning forward, "sometimes people do things without fully understanding the consequences." I watched him carefully choose his words as he continued to explain how Caro might have been crying out for attention, or perhaps she simply hadn't realized how dangerous her actions would be that day. The counselor had suggested something similar during our sessions, theorizing that Caro's impulsiveness stemmed from deeper emotional turmoil, but Neal's perspective felt more genuine, less clinical. Ruthann had her own theory, insisting that we were all somehow complicit in what happened, but Neal dismissed such collective guilt as unproductive. "You can't keep torturing yourself with 'what ifs,'" he advised, his voice gentler than I'd ever heard it. "Life has to go on, and you have to find your way to happiness, regardless of the circumstances that brought you here." His words made sense intellectually, but they couldn't erase the image seared into my memory: Caro running towards the water, her figure silhouetted against the setting sun, her decision already made before any of us could react. I nodded at Neal's wisdom while my mind rebelliously clung to that final scene, wondering if there would ever be a time when the weight of that moment wouldn't press so heavily on my conscience.

Paragraph 2:
“Anyway, I don’t think my life style is so interesting. I think you might want to know how it happened.” I could not figure out how to speak. “I was stoned,” he said. “And, furthermore, I’m not a swimmer. Not many swimming pools around where I grew up. I’d have drowned, too. Is that what you wanted to know?” I said that he was not really the one that I was wondering about. Then he became the third person I’d asked, “What do you think Caro had in mind?” The counsellor had said that we couldn’t know. “Likely she herself didn’t know what she wanted. Attention? I don’t think she meant to drown herself. Attention to how bad she was feeling?” Ruthann had said, “To make your mother do what she wanted? Make her smarten up and see that she had to go back to your father?” Neal said, “It doesn’t matter. Maybe she thought she could paddle better than she could. Maybe she didn’t know how heavy winter clothes can get. Or that there wasn’t anybody in a position to help her.” He said to me, “Don’t waste your time. You’re not thinking what if you had hurried up and told, are you? Not trying to get in on the guilt?” I said that I had considered what he was saying, but no. “The thing is to be happy,” he said. “No matter what. Just try that. You can. It gets to be easier and easier. It’s nothing to do with circumstances. You wouldn’t believe how good it is. Accept everything and then tragedy disappears. Or tragedy lightens, anyway, and you’re just there, going along easy in the world.” Now, goodbye. I see what he meant. It really is the right thing to do. But, in my mind, Caro keeps running at the water and throwing herself, as if in triumph, and I’m still caught, waiting for her to explain to me, waiting for the splash.

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: As I reflect on my interactions with this enigmatic woman, I am struck by the push-and-pull of our relationship, a delicate dance of fascination and frustration that has left me reeling. I recall one particularly sleepless night, when her soft humming of a song about a "greasy old duck" sent my imagination into overdrive, conjuring up visions of a monstrous creature that haunted my every waking moment. Her boasts about the old duck's prowess as a hunter only served to heighten my anxiety, as she drew unflattering comparisons between its skills and my own perceived inadequacies. In a bid to elicit some sympathy, I suggested that I might starve, but she simply laughed and returned with a collection of bird bones, which she intended to use to adorn her dress. I offered to help her dye the bones, hoping to find some common ground, but she rebuffed me, implying that my involvement might somehow interfere with the dress's healing properties. Her rejection cut deep, and I found myself professing my love, only to be met with a cruel retort that left me feeling raw and vulnerable. Undeterred, she continued to work on her dress, a stunning creation made from moose hide and adorned with the dyed bird bones, which seemed to radiate a soft, natural beauty. Despite my admiration, she warned me not to touch, suggesting that her beauty was somehow dangerous, a warning that only served to heighten my desire. I couldn't help but hope that the dress might somehow bring us closer together, but she revealed that she was dizzy from wine given to her by an old man, a revelation that only served to further distance herself from me. As I watched her, I couldn't help but feel a sense of longing, a sense of being forever out of reach.
paragraph2: One night, she hummed in an irritating manner, under her breath. “Niinimoshenh,” she finally let me hear her singing, “sweetheart, little duck, speak softly, for my old man will hear you creeping underneath my blanket.” Of course, after that I tossed all night, at each little noise, imagining the greasy old duck sneaking into our cabin. Now that she slept across the room from me, such a thing was remotely possible. I began to sleep by the door, but then I feared the window. The upshot was that I got no sleep at all. She boasted of the old duck’s hunting skills, and how he always had fresh game—waawaashkeshi or mooz. “Never gopher! Never things I’ve seen you eat!” “What would you know? You never cook for me anymore.” I tried to make myself meek and pitiful. “You’ll come home from Mass one day and find me dried up in the corner, starved to death.” “Go snare something then,” she said, heartless. She walked out laughing at me, came back with bird bones for her dress. I didn’t ask her where she’d got them, only if I could help her dye them red with the bark of speckled alder I’d gathered in atonement. “You?” She looked at me and sniffed, as though I were covered with moh. “You might interfere with the dress’s healing properties.” This cut me deeper than anything she’d said so far, and I let myself be naked in my speech. “I’ve got nothing in my heart but love for you.” “Nothing in your pants, either.” With a cruel laugh, she sat against the shady side of the cabin to work on her dress, which was almost finished. I must admit, she’d done a good job on it. The dress was made of a moose hide that she’d pounded and stretched and rubbed to a velvet softness. She’d used raspberry leaf and root dyes to color the bird bones, and, unlike the harsh, bright glare of the trader’s beads, these soft pinks and purples put roses in the woman’s cheeks. I said so. “Don’t touch” was all she said. “My roses have pickers so long they could pierce your heart and kill you.” I crept close to her, thinking that maybe the medicine dress would do its healing work and bring us together, but the opposite happened. “My, my.” She clucked her tongue, her eyes sparkling with malicious fire. “I’m dizzy. That old man down the road gave me a sip of wine!”

paragraph1: She trudged through the dense forest, her muscles aching from the weight of Max secured to her back in a makeshift swaddle fashioned from old blankets and rope, while Quinn, the worn fabric doll, rested safely in the backpack strapped to her chest. The forest canopy filtered the sunlight, creating a dappled pattern on the leaf-strewn ground as Max's small hands occasionally reached out to grasp at low-hanging branches and colorful leaves, his delighted giggles breaking the otherwise eerie silence. As they ventured deeper into the wilderness, she remained vigilant, her eyes scanning the undergrowth for any signs of movement, knowing that various creatures called these woods home. Max would sometimes engage in animated conversations with Quinn, pulling the doll from the backpack to show it interesting findings like peculiar stones or vibrant mushrooms, while she carefully rationed their dwindling supplies, making mental notes of edible plants and water sources they encountered. The forest gradually began to thin, the lush vegetation giving way to scraggly bushes and eventually bare earth, until they found themselves at the edge of a vast, sandy expanse that stretched endlessly before them. The transition was jarring, like stepping from one world into another, and she hesitated before pressing forward into this barren landscape where the wind whispered strange songs and the sand shifted beneath their feet in unpredictable patterns. As darkness descended, the environment took on an increasingly surreal quality, with shadows bending in impossible ways and the horizon seeming to pulse and breathe like a living entity. Her exhaustion mounted as she struggled to maintain her bearings in this disorienting terrain, the weight of Max and their supplies becoming nearly unbearable. In a moment of confusion, amid swirling sand and deceiving darkness, she realized with horror that she could no longer feel Max's presence against her back. Panic seized her heart as she spun around, calling out his name into the void, until her eyes finally found him sitting perfectly still in the sand, his small figure illuminated by a strange, ambient light. Relief flooded through her as she rushed to gather him in her arms, but as they emerged from the darkness into a patch of clearer visibility, her hand instinctively reached for the front pocket of her backpack, finding it empty. Quinn, Max's constant companion and sole source of comfort in this harsh world, was gone, lost somewhere in the vast expanse of sand and shadow they had traversed. The realization hit her like a physical blow, and she collapsed to her knees, hot tears streaming down her face as Max looked on in confusion. The doll had been more than just a plaything; it had been a symbol of normalcy, a small piece of childhood preserved in a world that seemed determined to strip away all innocence and joy. She held Max close as she wept, knowing that they would have to press on without Quinn, another small loss in a journey marked by countless sacrifices, yet this one felt particularly cruel. The wind continued to blow across the desolate landscape, carrying with it the ghost of children's laughter and the memory of simpler times, as she gathered her strength to stand once more, adjusting Max's weight on her back and facing the uncertain path ahead with renewed determination, though her heart ached for the small comfort they had lost in the unforgiving darkness.
paragraph2: V. She fixed him to her back in a swaddle of cut bedsheets and wore the backpack on her front. Quinn she stuffed down beside him. The straps chafed, and Max squirmed and kicked, sometimes he cried, but mostly, as they travelled, he spoke softly to the doll. In the afternoon, they passed the lake. A victory. Of course, there was only more forest, all the same. She built a fire beneath an overhanging rock; she ate jerky and apologized to Max for not feeding him. He pouted but then wandered off, picking up sticks and digging with them in the earth. The sun set. They sang to Quinn: I’ll see you in the mo-or-ning. In the night, she woke and felt Max breathing against her. They followed the sun, so she called it west. Sometimes the hills they climbed would level and drop limply back down; other times, they’d break through the tree line to bare rocky stretches, where eagles skimmed overhead. They travelled along a mountain ridge, two beautiful days, but had to double back when they came to a high chasm: no way down. That afternoon, they saw black bears, three of them, nosing along the mountainside. She shifted Max so he could see and said, “Bears.” She stewed and ate nettles; she kicked mushrooms from tree trunks and roasted them. When Max put both hands into the fire, she panicked and started to shout, then stopped and let him. The trees thinned. No more big pines, only firs, growing shorter and sparser, until—it happened so gradually she barely noticed—they were out of the forest. The soil turned sandy and pale. Before them was nothing. Nothing whatsoever. Now and then, she’d look back: the forest’s edge, like a wall, and the mountains looming over it, clouds and sky above the peaks, all together like something in a fishbowl. She walked until it was only a green-blue smear, and then nothing. And then they were nowhere. On her back, Max was quiet and still. The sand was soft and felt nice on her feet. It faded to a dirty white, like smudged paper, and so did the horizon. When the lack of perspective made her dizzy, she walked with her eyes shut. They had no fires. She ran out of water. Sometimes Max whispered things in her ear. Then the last trace of gray was gone from the sand. It was fine and synthetic-feeling; when displaced, it whirled in the air with unnatural lightness. The sky darkened, and the air grew thinner; it tasted like plastic. Then the only light was behind her, as if she were walking into a cave. And soon they were in total darkness. O.K., she thought. What now. She sat down, slipped the backpack’s straps over her arms, and found the lighter. Briefly, it lit the space around them. She pulled Max from her back, curled up with him, and fell asleep. When she woke, he was gone. She felt for the lighter and couldn’t find it; the darkness jumped before her eyes. But then she calmed herself: he couldn’t have gone far. She angled her head to listen, in one direction, then another, and on hands and knees she found the place where the sand went smooth again. In rigid, deliberate movements she crawled out, feeling with her fingers, counting each motion away from the backpack, and then returning. Wider each time, a spiral. Finally she felt a divot in the sand ahead of her, and then another. She followed the indentations out, slow and careful, the blood loud in her ears. Her fingertips found Max’s cloth diaper, and then his back, his shoulders, the nape of his neck; she went into a crouch and drew her arms around him. Only later did it terrify her: he’d been sitting perfectly still, staring into the dark. Back out in the light, it was the first thing she noticed: “Max. Where is Quinn?” She dug through the pack. “Quinn,” he said. She looked toward the dark, then at him, and fell into wild sobs.

paragraph1: Tommy was brimming with curiosity as he turned to his grandmother, Mawmaw, and asked about Shirley. Though Mawmaw brushed off his inquiry with a dismissive wave, Tommy couldn't resist the allure of the mysterious creature outside. He dashed out the door, eager to spend time with Shirley, who, from a distance, resembled a large dog but upon closer inspection, bore the unmistakable features of a mammoth, complete with a trunk and tusks. Mawmaw watched from the porch, her face a picture of concern as she fretted about potential diseases. Tommy, however, was quick to reassure her, promising to wash his hands scrupulously, which he did before joining her for breakfast. As they settled down to eat, Mawmaw's curiosity got the better of her, and she pressed Tommy about the origins of the mammoth. Tommy launched into an explanation about the Back from Extinction Zoo, a place shrouded in mystery and advanced science. He described how sometimes, due to cloning mishaps intended for their shows, twin animals would be created. This led to legal tangles, as the zoo could only keep one of the twins. The grim reality was that the other twin was typically euthanized after filming, a task assigned to Samantha, a zookeeper. Tommy spoke with a mixture of admiration and sadness about Samantha, acknowledging the weight of her responsibility. Her job was necessary yet heartbreaking, and he could not fathom the burden she carried. Mawmaw listened intently, her initial apprehension about Shirley giving way to a mix of awe and empathy for both the zookeeper and the majestic creature in their yard. As Tommy continued to speak, it was clear that Shirley had become more than just an anomaly; she was a testament to the wonders and ethical quandaries of modern science.
paragraph2: “And how’s Shirley this morning?” Tommy asks. All morning she hasn’t let herself look out the window above the sink. “Don’t see nothing out there,” Mawmaw says. “Don’t see it?” Tommy is up in a flash and out the back door. She watches him scurry across the grass in his boxers. He goes inside the pen. The mammoth emerges from behind the oak tree in the far right corner. From a distance it’s almost doglike. But that long probing trunk. Those tusks! Tommy squats in front of the mammoth and runs his fingers through the dirty-blond coat. “Wash your hands,” Mawmaw says once he’s back inside. “Could have diseases.” “Maw, it doesn’t have any diseases,” he says. Yet she can’t help but notice how thoroughly he scrubs his hands in the sink. She puts his breakfast plate on the table and sits down to watch him eat. “How come they let you take this elephant?” she asks. “Isn’t that against the rules?” “It’s not an elephant. Listen, Maw, I’m going to let you in on a dirty little secret. You know about the Back from Extinction Zoo, right?” “It’s where that cute little zookeeper takes all the animals to live at the end of every show.” “That’s right. Her name is Samantha. Only, she doesn’t take every animal to the zoo. We never say this on the air, but sometimes we clone twins by mistake, and that, legally speaking, is a bureaucratic nightmare. There are so many fucking laws that we—” “No ‘F,’ please.” “Sorry, but it’s true. You’d think we were trying to make nuclear weapons. We’re allowed to keep both twins alive until we’ve filmed the episode, so we can use each one on camera. But then we have to get rid of one. Samantha is the person who has to euthanize them. It’s awful.” Tommy scrapes the grits into a small pile and takes another bite.

She puts his breakfast plate on the table and sits down to watch him eat. “How come they let you take this elephant?” she asks. “Isn’t that against the rules?” “It’s not an elephant. Listen, Maw, I’m going to let you in on a dirty little secret. You know about the Back from Extinction Zoo, right?” “It’s where that cute little zookeeper takes all the animals to live at the end of every show.” “That’s right. Her name is Samantha. Only, she doesn’t take every animal to the zoo. We never say this on the air, but sometimes we clone twins by mistake, and that, legally speaking, is a bureaucratic nightmare. There are so many fucking laws that we—” “No ‘F,’ please.” “Sorry, but it’s true. You’d think we were trying to make nuclear weapons. We’re allowed to keep both twins alive until we’ve filmed the episode, so we can use each one on camera. But then we have to get rid of one. Samantha is the person who has to euthanize them. It’s awful.” Tommy scrapes the grits into a small pile and takes another bite.

You must produce your answer in the following JSON format:
{"preference": "1|2"}

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: It was useless for her now to try to see the paintings. She went, full of intentions, to the Van Eyck diptych and looked for a long time at the souls in Hell, kept there by the implacable, impartial, and genderless angel who stood upon its closing mouth. She looked, in renewed astonishment, at Jo Davidson’s pink, wrinkled, embalmed head of Jules Bache, which sat, a trinket on a fluted pedestal, before a Flemish tapestry. But she was really conscious of nothing but her desire to leave the museum in the company of Alfred Eisenburg, her cousin-german in the territory of despair. So she had to give up, two hours before the closing time, although she had meant to stay until the end, and she made her way to the central stairs, which she descended slowly, in disappointment, enviously observing the people who were going up, carrying collapsible canvas stools on which they would sit, losing themselves in their contemplation of the pictures. Salvador Dali passed her, going quickly down. At the telephone booths, she hesitated, so sharply lonely that she almost looked for her address book, and she did take out a nickel, but she put it back and pressed forlornly forward against the incoming tide. Suddenly, at the storm doors, she heard a whistle and she turned sharply, knowing that it would be Eisenburg, as, of course, it was, and he wore an incongruous smile upon his long, El Greco face. He took her hand and gravely asked her where she had been all this year and how she happened to be here, of all places, of all days.
paragraph2: As she wandered through the museum's hallowed halls, her gaze drifted from the intricate details of the Van Eyck diptych to the smooth contours of the sculpture by Jo Davidson, but her mind refused to follow. Despite her initial intention to immerse herself in the art, she found her thoughts consumed by the desire to leave, to escape the stifling atmosphere and reunite with her cousin, Alfred Eisenburg. She had planned to stay until the museum closed, to drink in every last drop of culture, but now she felt restless, her feet carrying her towards the exit with a sense of disappointment and disillusionment. As she descended the stairs, she couldn't help but feel envious of the other visitors, who seemed to be absorbing every brushstroke and nuance with an ease she couldn't muster. Her thoughts were interrupted by the sudden appearance of Salvador Dali, his unmistakable mustache a jarring presence in the midst of her reverie. For a moment, she considered making a phone call, driven by a pang of loneliness, but before she could act, a whistle pierced the air, and Eisenburg's smiling face appeared before her. "What are you doing here?" he asked, his eyes sparkling with curiosity, and she felt a sense of relief wash over her, grateful to be distracted from her own discontent.

paragraph1: Jacob was the only one who referred to the Israeli cousins as our Israeli cousins. To his wife, Julia, to Max, and to their older son, Sam, they were the Israeli cousins. Jacob felt no desire for ownership of them, and too much association made him itchy, but he felt that they were owed warmth commensurate with the thickness of blood. Or he felt that he should feel that. It would have been easier if they’d been easier. He’d known Tamir since they were children. Jacob’s grandfather Isaac and Tamir’s grandfather Benny were brothers in a Galician shtetl of such minuscule size and importance that the Germans didn’t get to it until their second pass through the Pale to wipe up Jewish crumbs. Isaac and Benny had avoided the fate of their five brothers by doing things that were often spoken around but never spoken of. After the war, Benny moved to Israel, where he had a son, Shlomo, who had Tamir. Isaac moved to America, where he had a son, Irv, who had Jacob. The brothers would visit each other every few years, as if the performance of familial intimacy would retroactively defeat the German people and save everyone. Isaac would lavish Benny and his family with expensive-looking tchotchkes, take them to the “best” second-tier restaurants, close his Jewish bodega for a week to show them the sights of Washington. And when they left he’d spend twice as long as their visit bemoaning how bigheaded and tiny-minded they were, how American Jews were Jews and these Israeli lunatics were Hebrews—people who, given their way, would sacrifice animals and serve kings. Then he’d reiterate how important it was to maintain closeness. Jacob found the Israeli cousins—his Israeli cousins—curious, at once alien and familiar. He saw his family’s faces in their faces, but also something different, something that could equally well be described as ignorant or unself-conscious, phony or free. Perhaps it was existential constipation, but the Israelis didn’t seem to give a shit about anything. All Jacob’s family ever did was give shits. They were shit-givers. When Isaac shattered his hip and died, as all Jews who outlive cancer and Gentiles eventually do, Tamir surprised everyone by flying in for the funeral. He and Jacob stayed up late that night, drinking beers at Jacob’s kitchen table. “He lived a good, long life,” Tamir said, and then took a good, long drink. “I suppose so, except for the good part,” Jacob said. “He spent his days clipping coupons for things he would never buy, while telling anyone who’d listen that no one listened to him.” A drink. “We once took the kids to a zoo in Berlin—” “You’ve been to Berlin?” “For work. It coincided with a school break.” “You’ve taken your children to Germany and not to Israel?” “As I was saying, we went to a zoo in the East, and it was pretty much the most depressing place I’ve ever been. There was a panther in a habitat the size of a parking space, with flora as convincing as a plastic Chinese-food display. He was walking figure eights, over and over, the exact same path. Every time he turned, he’d jerk his head back and squint. Every time. We were mesmerized. Max, who was maybe five, pressed his palms to the glass and asked, ‘When is Great-Grandpa’s birthday?’ What kind of five-year-old asks such a question at such a moment?” “The kind who worries that his great-grandfather is a depressed panther,” Tamir said. “Exactly. And he was right. The same routine, day after day after day: instant black coffee and black bread with canteloupe; read the Jewish Week with that enormous magnifying glass; check the house to make sure all the lights are still off; push a walker on tennis balls to shul to have the same Sad Libs conversations with the same macular degenerates, substituting different names into the news about cancers and graduations; thaw a brick of chicken soup while flipping through the same photo albums; eat the soup while advancing through another paragraph of the Jewish Week; nap in front of one of the same five movies; walk across the street to confirm Mr. Kowalski’s continued existence; skip dinner; check the house to make sure all the lights are still off; go to bed at seven and have eleven hours of the same nightmares. Is that happiness?” “It’s a version.” “Not one that anyone would choose.” Jacob was ashamed both of the inadequate life he’d tolerated for his grandfather and of judging it inadequate. “I regret that we didn’t keep in better touch,” he said. “You and your grandfather?” “No. Us.”
paragraph2: Jacob's insistence on saying "our Israeli cousins" stood as a lonely semantic flag in his household, where Julia, Max, and Sam opted for the more detached "the Israeli cousins," a subtle yet telling distinction that reflected the complicated nature of this trans-continental family connection. The weight of this relationship bore heavily on Jacob's conscience, rooted in the shared history of his grandfather Isaac and great-uncle Benny, Holocaust survivors whose means of survival remained shrouded in unspoken darkness, their separate paths leading to America and Israel respectively, where they built parallel lives that would forever be connected yet distinctly apart. The family tree branched through their sons, Shlomo and Irv, eventually reaching Jacob and Tamir, cousins who inherited not just blood ties but also the unspoken obligation to maintain a connection neither fully embraced nor completely rejected. Their family visits played out like carefully choreographed performances, each side acutely aware of their differences while maintaining a veneer of familial warmth, their interactions peppered with subtle judgments and cultural misunderstandings that neither party could fully bridge. The death of Isaac marked a turning point, bringing Tamir to American soil for the funeral, where the cousins found themselves sharing beers and unprecedented honesty about their grandfather's life - a life that Jacob now viewed through the dual lens of shame: shame for accepting the monotony that had characterized Isaac's existence, and shame for presuming to judge it. The conversation with Tamir that night exposed the superficiality of their relationship, leading Jacob to a painful recognition of his own role in maintaining this distance, despite his performative use of "our" when referring to his Israeli relatives. The realization that he had allowed this meaningful connection to wither into mere obligation weighed heavily on Jacob, who found himself caught between his instinct to maintain familial bonds and his discomfort with too close an association, a contradiction that seemed to mirror the complex dynamics between their respective nations and cultures. This internal struggle manifested in his daily life through small gestures and word choices, like his insistence on using "our" when referring to Tamir's family, a linguistic choice that seemed to compensate for the actual distance he helped maintain. The relationship between the cousins, much like the branching paths their grandfathers took after the war, represented both the endurance and fragility of family bonds across geographical, cultural, and ideological divides, with Jacob's regret serving as a poignant reminder of the opportunities lost in allowing these connections to fade into mere formality. Their shared heritage, marked by their grandfathers' survival and subsequent divergent paths, created an unspoken bond that neither cousin fully embraced nor could entirely ignore, leaving them in a perpetual state of connection and disconnection, much like their respective nations. The complexity of their relationship was further complicated by the unspoken expectations and obligations that came with their shared history, creating a dynamic where both felt compelled to maintain contact while simultaneously keeping each other at arm's length, their interactions marked by a peculiar mix of familiarity and distance that neither seemed able to bridge completely. This tension between obligation and genuine connection, between shared history and divergent presents, between the desire to maintain family ties and the comfort of distance, all came to a head during that post-funeral conversation, leaving Jacob with a profound sense of loss - not just for his grandfather, but for the deeper connection with Tamir that he had never fully pursued, a realization that came too late to easily remedy but not too late to acknowledge

paragraph1: Corman's office stood in stark contrast to the polished facades of his colleagues' practices. The worn leather chairs and sun-faded diplomas suggested a career that had seen better days. Still, there was an unmistakable dignity in how he carried himself, his suits creased by late nights poring over case files. When he offered coffee, it came in a chipped mug, but the gesture felt genuine. His current case seemed to weigh heavily on him - the thin skin beneath his eyes had darkened, and there was a slight tremor in his fingers whenever he rifled through filing cabinets. Corman's demeanor was reserved, almost apologetic, as if he felt personally responsible for and complicit in the injustices he fought against. His apartment always appeared sparse and utilitarian, as if it could serve little purpose for him. Despite the challenges, there was a stubborn resilience about Corman, a sense that he would see this case through, not for glory or financial gain, but because it was the right thing to do. In his presence, one got the impression of a man who had seen the darker side of the legal system but hadn't lost faith in it's potential for good.

paragraph1: My father's bond with Yezha, his aging German Shepherd, was something out of an Eastern European fairytale. As a child of war-torn Bosnia, he'd learned to ration every morsel, to see food as mere sustenance. So we were all shocked when he began to research canine nutrition with the fervor of a new parent, crafting homemade meals that would make a gourmet chef proud. I watched, bemused, as he meticulously measured supplements and grated fresh vegetables. This man, who once scoffed at the idea of "fancy" dog food, now spent hours in the kitchen for Yezha. As Yezha's muzzle grayed and her steps slowed, I looked on, wondering who would care for my father in this way. I felt ashamed to feel that I didn't have it in me to do the same. When Yezha finally passed, my father hardly spoke. I went back to my job across the sea. I signed him up for organic food deliveries to try and cheer him up and pass on the favor. But when I visited next, I saw them sitting in the trash, unopened.
paragraph2: My father's bond with Yezha, his aging German Shepherd, was a mirror to his own past. As a child of war-torn Bosnia, he'd learned to ration every morsel, to see food as mere sustenance. But Yezha's declining health softened something in him. He began to research canine nutrition with the fervor of a new parent, crafting homemade meals that would make a gourmet chef proud. I watched, bemused, as he meticulously measured supplements and grated fresh vegetables. This man, who once scoffed at the idea of "fancy" dog food, now spent hours in the kitchen for Yezha. It wasn't just about extending her life; it was about dignity, comfort, and love. As Yezha's muzzle grayed and her steps slowed, my father's own habits shifted. He started buying organic produce for himself, experimenting with new recipes. He spoke more openly about his childhood, as if Yezha's vulnerability had unlocked his own. In caring for her, he seemed to be nurturing the part of himself that had been neglected for so long. When Yezha finally passed, the changes in my father remained – a lasting testament to the healing power of caring for another.

paragraph1: Dr. Cole reversed out of his driveway with practiced precision, watching the garage door descend in his rearview mirror – a simple action that had once brought him comfort but now served as a solitary goodbye in his increasingly isolated world. The mechanical whir of the door, accompanied by the soft crunch of gravel beneath his tires, created a symphony of solitude that had become all too familiar. The morning air was crisp and still, broken only by the persistent chorus of birds whose songs seemed amplified in the absence of the usual suburban cacophony. As he navigated the empty streets, the eerie silence of what used to be a bustling neighborhood pressed heavily upon him, transforming the familiar landscape into something almost unrecognizable. The world had become a ghost town, with vacant driveways and darkened windows replacing the once-vibrant signs of life that had defined his community. His car's engine hummed steadily, its sound emphasizing rather than dispelling the overwhelming quietness that enveloped everything. A flash of russet fur caught his attention as a fox darted across the road, its confident stride a testament to how wildlife had begun to reclaim these abandoned spaces. The sight served as a poignant reminder of how much had changed, nature asserting itself in the vacuum left by human absence, making Dr. Cole feel like an intruder in what was once unquestionably his domain.
paragraph2: Dr. Cole eased his car from his garage, then stopped, out of habit, to watch in his rearview mirror the garage door slide gently down and the light above it extinguish itself. This had once given him an absurd, vain satisfaction; now it was his only goodbye. The car was expensive and comfortable, as was the house that went with it: large, sedate, islanded in lawns and leafage, like the others in the discreet crescent. As he drove off, the purr of the engine and the crackle of gravel were the only sounds, except for—though inside his car he couldn’t hear it—the great anthem of birds. It was a little after six on an April morning, but at eight it would still be astonishingly quiet. Except for the birds. They had become extraordinarily loud, as if by some conscious effort. But that was an illusion. It was the contrast with the silence. Less than an hour ago, he’d been lying in bed, listening to them and marvelling. A solitary man in a big house, surrounded, hymned by birds. And the roads, even the main ones, would be empty. They would be just as empty at eight. The phrase “ghost town” sometimes came to Dr. Cole as he made this journey. Ghost world. He would reach the hospital within fifteen minutes. Normally—when had “normally” ceased to apply?—it might take forty-five. Graham Swift on ghost worlds. As he turned out of the driveway, a fox slipped nonchalantly through the beam of his headlights. One morning, he had counted six foxes. The birds and the foxes. They had reclaimed the world.

paragraph1: Oaxaca is a city of old and new, deftly weaving it's indigenous roots together with contemporary influence. The streets hum with a sense of eternal tradition; markets overflow with handwoven textiles and aromas of mole, while sacred sites such as Monte Albán stand as silent keepers of ancient stories. Yet, the city pulses with a new artistic energy, driven by a wave of bohemian expats and artists seeking inspiration in it's colorful atmosphere. Modern art galleries and workshops sprout amid colonial architecture, creating a unique interplay between modern avant-garde and traditional style. Cafés and co-working spaces have become the new centers of social life, where elderly patrons sit next to digital nomads eagerly networking. This collision of worlds is not without tension, but it is in this tension that Oaxaca finds it's unique equilibrium, a careful dance of preservation and innovation. Local artisans remain the city's soul, teaching new arrivals the importance of craft while also adopting fresh techniques and perspectives. In the end, Oaxaca's evolution is not a story of cultural erosion but one of symbiotic growth, where history lives comfortably in the present.
