paragraph1: They leaped over the fence back into the woods. When the younger twin caught his foot on the barbed wire and fell, hollering, they stopped to see if he was O.K. But Eykelboom’s father was still coming toward them through the vacant lot, the stick in his hand, and they took off running again down the dark trail. They listened for Eykelboom ahead of them as they ran. Instead they heard his father, following. They ran in the dark on the trail that followed the creek to the crossing upstream. They tripped over vines and roots and stumbled in ruts but kept going. They scrambled down the upper creek bank, jumped the creek, and ran up the other side. They heard Eykelboom’s father far back on the trail—he had no flashlight and didn’t know these woods—calling out to his boy. The boys called out then, too—Eykelboom! Emile! Ikey! they called in turn. They searched for an hour or so, then made their way back to the street. They left the woods at a different spot, crossed the fence behind the Porters’ yard, and peered out from the side of their house. A police cruiser was parked half on the street, half in the Eykelbooms’ yard. Eykelboom’s father was talking to a cop near the open door of the cruiser. His mother was there, just outside the carport, in a house robe. A couple of people stepped out of their homes, curious. Cautiously, the boys went over. Eykelboom’s father stiffened when he saw them. He still had the stick in his hand. He looked at the cop, then at the boys. He said, What have you little bastards done with my boy? What have you done? I’ll fucking kill you if you’ve hurt him. It was hard not to run. Then Wayne said, We didn’t do anything to him. What’re you doing with that stick in your hand? What were you going to do to him before he ran away? What do you mean ran away? Eykelboom’s father said. The cop peered at the boys from beneath his visor. That’s right, Wayne said. He beats Ikey all the time. He made him run off. The cop’s narrowed eyes moved from Wayne to the other boys to Eykelboom’s father. He looked at the stick. I’ll handle this, Mr. Eykelboom, the cop said. Please put the stick down and go inside your house for now.
paragraph2: As they fled through the woods, the group of boys, including the pair of twins and Wayne, could hear the snapping of twigs and the labored breathing of Eykelboom's father as he pursued them, his stick at the ready. The younger twin, his legs pumping furiously as he struggled to keep up, failed to notice the barbed wire stretching across their path and tripped, his palms scraping against the rough earth. His brother quickly pulled him to his feet, and they continued running, their eyes scanning the trees for any sign of their friend Eykelboom, who had also fled to escape his father's wrath. For what felt like an hour, they searched the woods, their calls of "Eykelboom!" going unanswered. Eventually, they made their way back to the street, where they were met with an ominous sight: a police cruiser parked in front of the Eykelbooms' house, its lights flashing lazily. Eykelboom's father stood on the porch, his face twisted in anger as he spoke with a police officer. The boys approached cautiously, their eyes fixed on the stick still clutched in Eykelboom's father's hand. "You're the ones who've been hurting my boy," he spat, his eyes flashing with accusation. Wayne stepped forward, his face set in a defiant expression. "That's not true," he said, his voice steady. "You're the one who's been beating him. That's why he ran away." The police officer intervened, his voice firm but calm. "Put the stick down, sir. Let's go inside and talk about this." Eykelboom's father hesitated, his grip on the stick tightening before he finally relinquished it, his eyes never leaving the group of boys. The officer turned to the boys. "You kids okay?" he asked, his eyes scanning their faces. "Do any of you know where Eykelboom is?" The boys shook their heads, their faces somber with worry. As they stood there, the only sound the quiet hum of the police cruiser, they couldn't help but wonder what would happen next.

They leaped over the fence back into the woods. When the younger twin caught his foot on the barbed wire and fell, hollering, they stopped to see if he was O.K. But Eykelboom’s father was still coming toward them through the vacant lot, the stick in his hand, and they took off running again down the dark trail. They listened for Eykelboom ahead of them as they ran. Instead they heard his father, following. They ran in the dark on the trail that followed the creek to the crossing upstream. They tripped over vines and roots and stumbled in ruts but kept going. They scrambled down the upper creek bank, jumped the creek, and ran up the other side. They heard Eykelboom’s father far back on the trail—he had no flashlight and didn’t know these woods—calling out to his boy. The boys called out then, too—Eykelboom! Emile! Ikey! they called in turn. They searched for an hour or so, then made their way back to the street. They left the woods at a different spot, crossed the fence behind the Porters’ yard, and peered out from the side of their house. A police cruiser was parked half on the street, half in the Eykelbooms’ yard. Eykelboom’s father was talking to a cop near the open door of the cruiser. His mother was there, just outside the carport, in a house robe. A couple of people stepped out of their homes, curious. Cautiously, the boys went over. Eykelboom’s father stiffened when he saw them. He still had the stick in his hand. He looked at the cop, then at the boys. He said, What have you little bastards done with my boy? What have you done? I’ll fucking kill you if you’ve hurt him. It was hard not to run. Then Wayne said, We didn’t do anything to him. What’re you doing with that stick in your hand? What were you going to do to him before he ran away? What do you mean ran away? Eykelboom’s father said. The cop peered at the boys from beneath his visor. That’s right, Wayne said. He beats Ikey all the time. He made him run off. The cop’s narrowed eyes moved from Wayne to the other boys to Eykelboom’s father. He looked at the stick. I’ll handle this, Mr. Eykelboom, the cop said. Please put the stick down and go inside your house for now.

Paragraph 2:
As they fled through the woods, the group of boys, including the pair of twins and Wayne, could hear the snapping of twigs and the labored breathing of Eykelboom's father as he pursued them, his stick at the ready. His brother quickly pulled him to his feet, and they continued running, their eyes scanning the trees for any sign of their friend Eykelboom, who had also fled to escape his father's wrath. For what felt like an hour, they searched the woods, their calls of "Eykelboom!" going unanswered. paragraph1: As I sat by the crackling fire, the warmth enveloping me in a comforting embrace, I couldn't help but feel a peculiar mix of queasiness and satisfaction as I picked at the crow meat on my plate. The rich, gamey flavor lingered on my palate, a stark reminder of the evening's unconventional feast. Beside me, Big Uncle sat with a thoughtful expression, his eyes reflecting the dancing flames. I had always been curious about the story behind his limp, a mystery he had never fully revealed. Tonight, perhaps spurred by the intimacy of our shared meal, I finally mustered the courage to ask about his foot. He looked at me, a glint of reminiscence in his eyes, and began to weave his tale. It was a story of youthful bravado and a night that had changed him forever. Big Uncle recounted the time he decided to journey home over the mountain after a celebration, a decision made in the exuberance of the moment, despite the elders' warnings about the wild animals that roamed the area and the superstitions that cloaked the path in fear. As he spoke, the firelight cast shadows that danced across his face, adding depth to the story unfolding in the night. His voice was steady, each word carefully chosen, painting vivid images of the treacherous path and the haunting calls of unseen creatures in the darkness. I listened intently, captivated by the blend of danger and adventure in his narrative. The tale was more than just a story; it was a piece of the past that had shaped the man beside me. As he spoke, I felt a newfound respect for Big Uncle, for the courage he had shown in facing the unknown and for the wisdom he had gained from that fateful journey. The fire crackled softly, casting its warm glow, as the night deepened around us, and Big Uncle's story lingered in the air like an echo of the past.
paragraph2: “What’s the matter? I gave you the small one?” “No, sir. I was just wondering—” “If both of you had come back? Well, then, I suppose you’d be fighting over the one, ungh?” He laughed and tore a piece of meat from the breast of his to dab in the salt. I ate, too, and despite my queasiness at the clump of black crow feathers I saw in the underbrush, the meat tasted wonderful, its gamy tang cut by the salt. My face warmed by the fire, and my stomach rumbling even as I ate, I tore my bird to shreds and sucked at the bones until they were dry. It was dark when we were done, and we passed the jug of water back and forth to wash down the last scraps of crow meat. “The nights are long if you’re the thoughtful sort,” Big Uncle said. “So tell me what you’re thinking about.” “I was wondering about your foot,” I said. “The smell bother you?” “No, sir. I can’t smell it now. I found your wrappings this morning.” “Well, it’s a story. Like some folktale. But everyone’s life is like a story, isn’t it? From a long, long time ago.” I expected Big Uncle to smoke while he talked, but he just closed his eyes, as if to let the firelight warm his eyelids. He sat with his legs crossed, his bad foot on top, and he told the story into the fire. “I was coming home after some celebration—the hundred-day party for Old Pak’s grandson. It was past sunset, and they told me to stay the night there in that village, but I stubbornly decided to come home over the mountain. There were still wild animals in the woods back then and even rumors of tigers, though no one had seen one since the Japanese came. That’s why people said not to go—because of the tigers—but they were actually afraid of ghosts and goblins and the usual lies.

paragraph1: In a kind of anxious triumph, sensing his hostess’s exasperation yet determined not to acknowledge it, Anton swung the lurid pumpkin head down from his shoulders, holding it in his chafed-looking, big-knuckled hands. Now Hadley could see that the pumpkin was only two-thirds of a shell. It had been gutted and carved and its back part cut away—the back of what would be, in a human, the cranium. So the uncanny pumpkin head was a kind of pumpkin mask set on Anton’s shoulders and held in place by hand. Yet it was so lifelike; as the scarecrow figure had lurched up the walk in her direction, the face had appeared alive. “Is good? Is—surprise? ‘Happy Halloween’ is right?” Was it Halloween? Hadley was sure it was not. October 31st wasn’t for several more days. “Is for you, Hedley. To set here.” He was red-faced now and smiling in a shyly aggressive manner. On his angular face and in the stiff, wiry hair that receded sharply from his forehead were bits of pumpkin flesh and seeds, at which Anton wiped, surreptitiously, the way a boy might wipe at his runny nose. Hadley thought, If he kisses me, he will smell of pumpkin. Her husband had died and abandoned her. Now other men would drop by the house. Anton presented Hadley with the misshapen pumpkin. The damned thing must have weighed fifteen pounds. It almost slipped from her hands. Hadley thought it would have served Anton Kruppev right if she’d dropped the pumpkin and it had smashed on the brick. No doubt, he’d have offered to clean it up. “Anton, thank you! This is very. . . ” Their hands brushed together. Anton was standing close beside her. He was several inches taller than Hadley, though his posture was slouched, his back prematurely rounded. Perhaps there was something wrong with his spine. And he breathed quickly, audibly, as if he’d been running. Or as if he’d been about to declare something and then thought better of it.
paragraph2: Anton stood before Hadley with a peculiar mix of triumph and anxiety, his large, chafed hands cradling a meticulously carved pumpkin head that, moments before, had served as his makeshift mask. The two-thirds shell, thoroughly gutted and expertly carved, seemed to glow with an almost ethereal quality in the ambient light, though Hadley's barely concealed exasperation threatened to dim its charm. Despite detecting her less-than-enthusiastic response, Anton maintained his cheerful disposition, his big-knuckled fingers nervously adjusting the position of his offering. Hadley's surprise was evident, not merely at the unexpected gesture but at its timing – Halloween was still some distance away – and her thoughts drifted momentarily to her late husband, creating an unspoken comparison with the various men who had since crossed her threshold. Anton's demeanor, characterized by a curious blend of shy aggression and obvious anticipation, manifested in his reddened face and slightly slouched posture as he extended the pumpkin toward her. When their hands briefly touched during the exchange, the contact seemed to amplify Anton's already quickened breathing, his chest rising and falling with an urgency that betrayed his nervous state. His physical awkwardness, combined with his determined effort to appear composed, spoke volumes about his unvoiced intentions, creating a moment charged with both possibility and uncertainty. Through it all, the carved pumpkin served as both a bridge and a barrier between them, its hollow grin a silent witness to this delicate dance of tentative courtship.

paragraph1: The beeping of machines faded into white noise as I sat by Francesco's bedside, watching his chest rise and fall with labored breaths. Outside the window, a group of interns laughed as they passed, their voices muffled through the glass. I found myself envying their carefree demeanor, their lives still brimming with possibility. Francesco's wife, Maria, busied herself adjusting his pillows, her movements gentle yet purposeful. Her eyes never left his face, as if memorizing every line and shadow. A nurse entered, checking vitals with practiced efficiency, her presence a reminder of the clinical nature of this space. I noticed a vase of wilting flowers on the nightstand, forgotten in the weight of more pressing concerns. As I shifted in my chair, my gaze fell on a family photo taped to the wall – Francesco, younger and vibrant, surrounded by smiling faces at a beach. The contrast between that frozen moment and the present reality struck me, and I felt a sudden, sharp pang of grief. Yet, as Maria's hand found mine and squeezed it softly, I was reminded of the enduring power of human connection, even in the face of inevitable loss.
paragraph2: I sat by Francescon's bedside. Outside the window, a landscaper's trimmer was revving. Francescon's wife, Maria, busied herself adjusting his pillows, pulling him forward with one hand behind his neck then easing him back. Her eyes never left his face. A nurse entered, checked his vitals with practiced efficiency. Wilting Gerberas in a vase reminded me of the Japanese philosophy of wabi sabi. As I shifted in my chair, my gaze fell on a family photo taped to the wall – Francescon, younger and vibrant, surrounded by smiling faces at a beach. Maria squeezed my hand and told me to go find something to eat.

paragraph1: Dr. Cole eased his car from his garage, then stopped, out of habit, to watch in his rearview mirror the garage door slide gently down and the light above it extinguish itself. This had once given him an absurd, vain satisfaction; now it was his only goodbye. The car was expensive and comfortable, as was the house that went with it: large, sedate, islanded in lawns and leafage, like the others in the discreet crescent. As he drove off, the purr of the engine and the crackle of gravel were the only sounds, except for—though inside his car he couldn’t hear it—the great anthem of birds. It was a little after six on an April morning, but at eight it would still be astonishingly quiet. Except for the birds. They had become extraordinarily loud, as if by some conscious effort. But that was an illusion. It was the contrast with the silence. Less than an hour ago, he’d been lying in bed, listening to them and marvelling. A solitary man in a big house, surrounded, hymned by birds. And the roads, even the main ones, would be empty. They would be just as empty at eight. The phrase “ghost town” sometimes came to Dr. Cole as he made this journey. Ghost world. He would reach the hospital within fifteen minutes. Normally—when had “normally” ceased to apply?—it might take forty-five. Graham Swift on ghost worlds. As he turned out of the driveway, a fox slipped nonchalantly through the beam of his headlights. One morning, he had counted six foxes. The birds and the foxes. They had reclaimed the world.
paragraph2: Dr. Cole reversed out of his driveway with practiced precision, watching the garage door descend in his rearview mirror – a simple action that had once brought him comfort but now served as a solitary goodbye in his increasingly isolated world. The mechanical whir of the door, accompanied by the soft crunch of gravel beneath his tires, created a symphony of solitude that had become all too familiar. The morning air was crisp and still, broken only by the persistent chorus of birds whose songs seemed amplified in the absence of the usual suburban cacophony. As he navigated the empty streets, the eerie silence of what used to be a bustling neighborhood pressed heavily upon him, transforming the familiar landscape into something almost unrecognizable. The world had become a ghost town, with vacant driveways and darkened windows replacing the once-vibrant signs of life that had defined his community. His car's engine hummed steadily, its sound emphasizing rather than dispelling the overwhelming quietness that enveloped everything. A flash of russet fur caught his attention as a fox darted across the road, its confident stride a testament to how wildlife had begun to reclaim these abandoned spaces. The sight served as a poignant reminder of how much had changed, nature asserting itself in the vacuum left by human absence, making Dr. Cole feel like an intruder in what was once unquestionably his domain.

paragraph1: At the restaurant, he gave the woman a look of his own. This look said two things: one, you worry too much, and, two, this is fun—I’m having fun, now you have fun. The woman was having fun, but she also didn’t want to get food poisoning. As if having read her mind, the man said, If you do get sick, you can blame me. Eventually, the waitress noticed that the couple had arrived. She had been picking polish off her nails. She looked up but didn’t get up and instead waved them to the bar. Sit anywhere you like, she said sleepily. Then she disappeared behind a black curtain embroidered with the Chinese character for the sun. When they first started dating, they’d agreed that if there weren’t any glaring red flags, and there weren’t, they would try to live together, and they did. To make things fair, each tried to find a job in the other’s city. Not surprisingly, the demand for financial analysts in New York was much higher than the demand for pottery instructors in Boston. Huzzah, he texted the day the movers arrived at her old apartment. She texted back a smiley face, then, later, pictures of her empty living room, bedroom, bathroom, and the pile of furniture and things she was donating so that, once they were living together, they would not have, for example, two dining-room sets, twenty pots and pans, seven paring knives, and so on.
paragraph2: John gave Sarah a reassuring glance across the dimly lit restaurant table, his eyes conveying that she should relax and enjoy herself despite her visible apprehension about the establishment's food safety standards. "If you get sick, I'll take full responsibility," he quipped with a gentle smile, attempting to lighten her mood. The waitress, who had been intently studying her freshly manicured nails, finally acknowledged their presence with a cursory nod and gestured toward the bar area before vanishing behind a heavy velvet curtain. Their presence in this questionable establishment was just another step in their carefully planned journey together, having decided to cohabitate only after methodically ensuring they were compatible in all major aspects of life. The transition hadn't been simple; both had explored job opportunities in each other's cities, but ultimately, John's position as a financial analyst in New York proved more practical than Sarah's work as a pottery instructor in Boston. As she prepared for the move, Sarah had kept him updated with a steady stream of texts – snapshots of her increasingly empty apartment, lists of items she was donating to avoid duplicates in their shared space, and the bittersweet process of dismantling her independent life to build something new together.

Paragraph 1:
At the restaurant, he gave the woman a look of his own. This look said two things: one, you worry too much, and, two, this is fun—I’m having fun, now you have fun. The woman was having fun, but she also didn’t want to get food poisoning. As if having read her mind, the man said, If you do get sick, you can blame me. Eventually, the waitress noticed that the couple had arrived. She had been picking polish off her nails. She looked up but didn’t get up and instead waved them to the bar. Sit anywhere you like, she said sleepily. Then she disappeared behind a black curtain embroidered with the Chinese character for the sun. When they first started dating, they’d agreed that if there weren’t any glaring red flags, and there weren’t, they would try to live together, and they did. To make things fair, each tried to find a job in the other’s city. Not surprisingly, the demand for financial analysts in New York was much higher than the demand for pottery instructors in Boston. Huzzah, he texted the day the movers arrived at her old apartment. She texted back a smiley face, then, later, pictures of her empty living room, bedroom, bathroom, and the pile of furniture and things she was donating so that, once they were living together, they would not have, for example, two dining-room sets, twenty pots and pans, seven paring knives, and so on.

Paragraph 2:
John gave Sarah a reassuring glance across the dimly lit restaurant table, his eyes conveying that she should relax and enjoy herself despite her visible apprehension about the establishment's food safety standards. "If you get sick, I'll take full responsibility," he quipped with a gentle smile, attempting to lighten her mood. The waitress, who had been intently studying her freshly manicured nails, finally acknowledged their presence with a cursory nod and gestured toward the bar area before vanishing behind a heavy velvet curtain. Their presence in this questionable establishment was just another step in their carefully planned journey together, having decided to cohabitate only after methodically ensuring they were compatible in all major aspects of life. The transition hadn't been simple; both had explored job opportunities in each other's cities, but ultimately, John's position as a financial analyst in New York proved more practical than Sarah's work as a pottery instructor in Boston. As she prepared for the move, Sarah had kept him updated with a steady stream of texts – snapshots of her increasingly empty apartment, lists of items she was donating to avoid duplicates in their shared space, and the bittersweet process of dismantling her independent life to build something new together.

You must produce your answer in the following JSON format:
{"preference": "1|2"}

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: Sarah hesitated, her knees pressed against the cold tile floor of the gas station bathroom. The toilet before her emitted an unexpectedly fresh scent of lemon, a stark contrast to the grimy surroundings. She reached for her backpack, fingers brushing against the familiar canvas texture. Inside, a roll of bills, swollen with desperation and questionable choices, pressed against the lining. Sarah's mind drifted to Evan's words from earlier that day, his voice a mix of concern and determination: "If we get separated, head north. Don't stop until you reach the border." She blinked, pushing away the memory and focusing on the task at hand. Her trembling fingers fumbled with the zipper, the sound echoing in the small space. As she gathered her belongings, Sarah couldn't shake the feeling that this moment, crouched before a surprisingly clean toilet in a rundown gas station, might be the last glimpse of normalcy for a while. She stood, adjusting the weight of the backpack on her shoulders, and took a deep breath. The lemony scent lingered, an oddly comforting reminder that sometimes, things aren't as bad as they seem. With one last glance at her reflection in the spotted mirror, Sarah pushed open the bathroom door and stepped into the unknown.

She stood, adjusting the weight of the backpack on her shoulders, and took a deep breath. The lemony scent lingered, as though urging her forward. With one last glance at her reflection in the spotted mirror, Sarah pushed open the bathroom door and stepped into the dark night.

paragraph1: Audio: Patricia Lockwood reads. Everyone at gate B6 was bathed in gold. She sat there with one foot off the edge of the earth, close to falling, until she saw the couple with matching extravagant mullets that hung down past their shoulder blades. The man took out a brush and began to fight through his mullet until it was free, and then he handed the brush to his wife and she began to fight through hers with the same consecrated look; these mullets were their acre and when God came down he would not find a rock, a stump, a weed. They shook out their hair together, as if it were all on the same head, joined hands, and rested. She sat in the gold that made them the same and felt a little less like dying. • The cursor blinked where her mind was. She put one true word after another and put the words in the portal. All at once they were not true, not as true as she could have made them. Where was the fiction? Distance, arrangement, emphasis, proportion? Did they become untrue only when they entered someone else’s life and butted up, trivial, against its bigness? • A twenty‐three‐year‐old influencer sat next to her on the couch and spoke of the feeling of being a public body; his skin seemed to have no pores whatsoever. “Did you read . . . ?” they said to each other again and again. “Did you read?” They kept raising their hands excitedly to high‐five, for they had discovered something even better than being soul mates: that they were exactly, and happily, and hopelessly, the same amount of online. • Patricia Lockwood on the extremely online. “I have a theory,” she said to the crowd, and then paused, for somewhere she thought she heard someone groan. She tried to resume, but couldn’t recall what she’d been about to say—something about being a woman in our time. • In Vienna the little cakes looked like the big buildings, or else the big buildings looked like the little cakes. She ate both, layer upon layer. Then, as she swung at the top of the Ferris wheel in the Prater, coffee sloshing in her stomach above the linden leaves, her phone buzzed and there were the words, from her far mother: “Something has gone wrong” and “How soon can you get here?”
paragraph2: Patricia Lockwood sat reading quietly as life unfolded around her at gate B6, where her attention was drawn to a peculiar sight that would later become a moment of unexpected solace. A couple, sporting matching mullets, engaged in an intimate ritual of brushing each other's hair, their synchronicity creating a touching display of affection that somehow lifted the weight of despondency from the observing woman's shoulders. As she watched them, her mind wandered to her own struggles with writing, grappling with the authenticity of words once they left the safety of her thoughts and entered the public sphere. The atmosphere shifted when a twenty-three-year-old influencer took the seat beside her, their shared understanding of the digital world creating an instant connection, marked by enthusiastic high-fives and animated conversation about their online experiences. Later, as Patricia stood before a crowd, she attempted to articulate a theory, but the words seemed to slip away like sand through her fingers, leaving her thoughts scattered and incomplete. The narrative then transported her to Vienna, where she found herself immersed in the city's architectural harmony, savoring rich cakes while admiring buildings that appeared to mirror one another in an endless architectural dialogue. The peaceful moment was interrupted during a ride on a Ferris wheel, as her phone buzzed with an urgent message from her mother, the content of which immediately cast a shadow over the otherwise serene experience. This sequence of events, moving from the intimate scene at the airport to the public speaking engagement and finally to the distant city of Vienna, wove together themes of connection, communication, and the unexpected ways in which moments of joy and concern could intersect in one's life, all while maintaining a delicate balance between personal observation and public performance.

paragraph1: Seated at the bar of the Russian Riviera, Volodya Sorkin told Kostya, “There wasn’t enough room in the marriage for the three of us.” “You, her, and Baryshnikov?” Kostya asked. “Me, her, and the letter,” Volodya said. Volodya was a regular at the Russian Riviera. On nights when his limousine wasn’t booked, he stopped in to catch Ivetta’s performance in the Vegas-style floor show. Before the show, he nursed a drink and talked to whoever was around—mostly to Kostya, who had little to do but sit at the bar. Fights and confrontations were uncommon. The clientele at the Russian Riviera was predominantly middle-aged, educated, and relatively well off. Also, it was Jewish. In this respect, Kostya discerned a cultural difference between Russians and Jews: on the rare occasion when there was trouble, nobody pulled a knife. Through Volodya, Kostya became acquainted with Ivetta. Until then, Kostya hadn’t had much interaction with the dancers and musicians, who socialized mainly with one another, but he had taken notice of Ivetta. Not because of some striking physical attribute—with the costumes and the makeup, all the dancers looked like variations on the same woman—but because she possessed a quality that Kostya had observed in the best athletes: she gave the impression of effortlessness. It was the illusion that the forces of time and gravity did not apply equally to all people. Her face and neck still flushed with the charge of the performance, Ivetta slid in beside her father at the bar. She kissed Volodya affectionately, and seemed to take no notice of Kostya until Volodya turned inclusively in his direction. “This is my good friend Kostya,” Volodya said. “Very nice to meet you, Kostya,” Ivetta said. “Kostya is a boxer,” Volodya said. “Was a boxer,” Kostya said. “Not anymore?” Ivetta asked. “I wouldn’t say so.” “When were you a boxer?” Ivetta asked. “It depends who you ask,” Kostya said. “I asked you.” “Then I would say six years ago.” “And if I asked someone else?” “Then they might say two weeks ago.”
paragraph2: Volodya Sorkin, a familiar face at the Russian Riviera, situated himself comfortably at the bar, engaging in a lively conversation with Kostya, a man who often found himself with idle time. The bar, a culturally distinct venue predominantly frequented by the Jewish community, exuded an atmosphere of casual camaraderie and rare conflict. As Volodya spoke, he mentioned a metaphorical third presence in his marriage, which Kostya, with a quizzical expression, initially misunderstood as another person. Volodya chuckled, clarifying that the third presence was, in fact, a letter, a revelation that sparked Kostya's curiosity and deepened their conversation. Volodya's visits to the bar were often timed for nights when his limousine wasn't booked, allowing him the pleasure of witnessing Ivetta's performances. Ivetta, a dancer of remarkable talent, was known for her natural grace on stage—a quality that Kostya, despite his rough-and-tumble past as a boxer, found himself admiring. After her performance, Ivetta joined Volodya and Kostya at the bar. Her entrance was met with a warm greeting from her father, Volodya, who introduced her to Kostya. With a wry smile, Kostya divulged his past as a boxer, though the exact timeline of his career remained humorously ambiguous, adding a layer of mystery to his character. Ivetta, unfazed by the ambiguity, engaged in the conversation with a friendly ease that further enriched the convivial atmosphere of the evening. The Russian Riviera, with its unique cultural tapestry, served as a backdrop to this unfolding interaction, where the bonds of family, friendship, and shared stories intertwined seamlessly. In this setting, the trio shared laughs, exchanged stories, and found common ground, illustrating how the simple act of conversation could bridge diverse backgrounds and life experiences. As the night wore on, the bar continued to hum with the soft murmur of conversations and the occasional burst of laughter, encapsulating the essence of this warm and welcoming enclave.

paragraph1: Sarah sat on the wooden bench, her fingers tracing the grooves worn smooth by all those who had sat there before her. The gardens around her hummed. A gentle breeze carried the scent of lavender and rosemary. She closed her eyes and focused on the warmth of sunlight on her skin and the soft rustling of the leaves above. As she opened them again, her gaze fell on a small, iridescent pebble nestled in the grass. She picked it up and it's cool surface felt soothing against her palm. It reminded her of the smooth scar tissue forming over her recent surgery site. A ladybug landed on her knee, it's tiny legs tickling her as it explored the fabric of her jeans. Sarah watched it, noting how it's vibrant red contrasted with the faded denim. In the distance, wind chimes tinkled softly. Their melody mingled with the muffled sounds of life beyond the garden walls. She took a deep breath. The air filled her lungs and she noticed how it no longer caused her pain. As she exhaled, Sarah realized she was finally beginning to heal.

As she exhaled, Sarah felt a sense of peace wash over her, realizing that in this moment, surrounded by nature's subtle wonders, she was finally beginning to heal.

paragraph1: Allistair was twelve when he first stepped between his parents on Maple Street, their shouts echoing off the neighboring houses. His father's breath reeked of whiskey, his mother's mascara ran in dark rivulets down her cheeks. Allistair spoke softly, trying to redirect their attention, but his words were lost in the storm of their anger. He gently tugged at his mother's sleeve, only to have her wrench her arm away, nearly knocking him off balance. His father laughed, a harsh bark that made Allistair flinch. In that moment, standing there on the cracked sidewalk under the flickering streetlight, Allistair realized he was invisible to them. The next day at school, he sat silent in class, replaying the scene in his mind. He began to withdraw, spending more time alone in his room, building elaborate Lego structures – cities where he could control every aspect, where no one shouted or cried. Years later, as an adult, Allistair would find himself unconsciously holding his breath whenever he heard raised voices, his hands instinctively moving to build or fix something, anything, to regain a sense of order.
paragraph2: Allistair was twelve when he first tried to step between his parents shouting. They were on the street, on Maple Street, and everyone could hear. His father's breath reeked of whiskey, his mother's mascara ran in dark rivulets down her cheeks. Allistair spoke softly, but they weren't listening. It was like dropping a pebble into a tornado. He gently tugged at his mother's sleeve. She wrenched her arm away, nearly knocking him off balance. His father laughed, a harsh bark that made Allistair flinch. Standing there on the cracked sidewalk under the flickering streetlight, Allistair knew he was invisible to them. There was nothing he could say or do. The next day at school, he sat silent in class. The scene replayed again and again in his mind. He spent time alone in his room, building elaborate Lego structures – cities where he could control every aspect, where no one shouted or cried. Years later, as an adult, Allistair would find himself unconsciously holding his breath whenever he heard raised voices, his hands instinctively moving to build or fix something, anything.

paragraph1: As I sat quietly nursing my drink in the dimly lit pub, I couldn't help but overhear a spirited conversation from the table nearby. A group of friends was encouraging one of their own to come over and talk to me, but he seemed to brush off their suggestions with a mix of embarrassment and reluctance. My curiosity piqued, I glanced over and was immediately struck by the uncanny resemblance he bore to Patrick, a person from my past. It wasn't just the way he looked; there was something about his demeanor and the way he carried himself that reminded me of him. Both had a similar fashion sense, favoring a casual yet refined style that seemed effortlessly put together, though this man had a more rugged edge to him. As I continued to observe him, I couldn't help but compare the two: Patrick, who I remember as an academic deeply immersed in the world of Early Modern literature, and this man, whose hands and posture suggested a life of physical labor. My assumptions were confirmed later in the evening when he introduced himself as a gas engineer. Despite the differences in their lives and personalities, there was a shared authenticity in how they presented themselves. In a spontaneous moment of boldness, something quite uncharacteristic of me, I decided to break the ice and initiate a conversation. It was a risky move, one I had never dared to make before, but something about the familiarity of his presence compelled me to take that leap. Our conversation was a delightful revelation, filled with unexpected depth and warmth, bridging the gap between his technical world and the literary realm that Patrick inhabited. As we exchanged stories and laughter, I realized this encounter was not merely a coincidence but a serendipitous opportunity to reflect on the past and embrace the present.
paragraph2: “Go on, ask her,” they said, meaning me to hear. “Fuck off,” he said, red-faced, pretending to be busy with the first mouthful of his pint. Every time I saw him I’d feel the same shock at his likeness to Patrick. People come in physical types; I’ve seen girls I immediately recognized as belonging to the same type as me: small and round with these deep-lidded frog eyes. There are dark ones and blond ones, but the type is as unmistakable as if we belonged to the same subspecies. And, even though there were specific points on which they didn’t match, this man and Patrick had the same overall effect. The man in the pub was blurred where Patrick was definite. His skin was coarser. His hair wasn’t as black and straight—it was dark brown, with honey-brown curling bits in it. He was a little shorter than Patrick, but more muscular, as if he did physical work. He told me that he was a gas engineer, which wasn’t all that physical, but presumably more strenuous than lecturing on the literature of the Early Modern period. He had a little beer belly like Patrick’s. His jeans hung on his narrow hips in the same way. Actually—oddly, considering how unalike their lives and personalities were—they even dressed the same. They wore tight V-necked sweaters over jeans, without a shirt. They wore black T-shirts with those little cap sleeves. I suppose they had both found the styles that suited them. And soon something began that I’m shocked to think of now. Something that I initiated. It would never have occurred to him even to speak to me, beyond ordering his drinks, if I hadn’t started it. I didn’t just flirt with him. I went all out to make things go further. I knew that this was supposed to be a risky and demeaning strategy for a girl; it certainly wasn’t something I’d ever done before.

paragraph1: As Wanda lauded Alejandro's impressive German skills, despite his unmistakable accent, Kiril couldn't help but feel a pang of discomfort. It wasn't that he disagreed with Wanda's assessment, but rather the fact that they were discussing Alejandro's abilities behind his back that struck a chord within him. Kiril's sudden outburst, defending Alejandro's linguistic prowess, caught the other students off guard, and the room fell silent. Realizing his fervor had made everyone uneasy, Kiril quickly apologized, attempting to diffuse the tension. The teacher, sensing an opportunity to steer the conversation back on track, introduced the class to the German word "Krankentag," explaining its meaning as a sick day. The lesson continued, but the atmosphere had shifted. Notably, Claire, who had previously enjoyed playing piano with the teacher, ceased to do so after the incident. In the next class, Claire sat attentively, diligently jotting down unfamiliar words from Morgan's essay to study later, her focus solely on the task at hand. Meanwhile, the teacher played the piano alone, the melodies filling the room, but lacking the warmth of Claire's accompaniment. Alejandro's continued absence from class only added to Kiril's growing sense of monotony, leaving him longing for the unexpected events that used to punctuate his high school days. As the classes blended together, Kiril found himself yearning for something, anything, to disrupt the routine, to bring back the spark that had once made learning feel so exhilarating. The days ticked by, each one a carbon copy of the last, and Kiril couldn't help but wonder when, or if, the monotony would be broken.
paragraph2: “Alejandro is a good student,” Wanda said, clearly and with perfect pronunciation. “His German is very good, despite his accent.” Kiril wondered if she had practiced lines like these at home, about each of them: Arthur learns very slowly. Kiril speaks too quickly, he is nervous. It seemed unfair to talk like this, behind someone’s back. “But having an accent all of us!” he said, his voice a shade too loud. “It is natural, and he speaks well and he asks good questions. He is a very good student, the best!” Now the students looked afraid, as if he had threatened them. Kiril was filled with remorse. “I am sorry,” he said. “I am making many mistakes.” “It is my fault,” the teacher said. “Let us not speak of Alejandro. Probably he is sick. He is taking a sick day. There is a word for this.” He wrote it on the board: Krankentag. “Yes, that is good,” he said, stepping back. “If you use this word, you will sound like a native speaker.” The class wrote the word down. After that day, Claire and the teacher no longer played the piano together. During the next class, while Morgan read a halting essay about her political activism—“I am walking against the government; I am walking with many others to the large building of the government, holding hands”—Kiril watched Claire out of the corner of his eye. Whenever Morgan spoke an unfamiliar word, Claire wrote it down in her notebook. Later, during the break, newly bereft of music, she checked these words against an online dictionary, clarifying their gender and their endings and making small corrections. The teacher played in the other room, alone, the pieces softer, more restrained. Alejandro did not come to the next class, or the one after that. Kiril waited for him to appear, the way in high school he had waited for far-fetched things to break up the tedium: sudden snowstorms, a citywide blackout, subtle variations on the end of the world.

paragraph1: The church hall buzzed with anticipation as D.G.F. prepared to take the stage, with Monika positioned behind her drum kit, exchanging knowing glances with Katja and Elli as they readied their instruments. The peaceful atmosphere shattered when 88 Tommy and his gang of skinheads burst through the main entrance, their combat boots thundering against the wooden floor as they began overturning chairs and shoving audience members. Chaos erupted instantly, with screams filling the air and people scrambling toward the exits, while the skinheads methodically destroyed everything in their path. Monika's heart raced as she abandoned her drums and made a desperate dash for the side door, her fingers trembling as she pushed it open, only to find herself suddenly flanked by two men in dark raincoats who emerged from the shadows. Their grip was firm as they claimed to be there for her protection, but their rough handling suggested otherwise as they dragged her toward a waiting car despite her fierce struggles and protests. The men's faces remained impassive as they forced her into the backseat, their movements practiced and efficient, suggesting this wasn't their first such operation. The car wound through the darkening streets of Berlin until it reached a hairdresser's shop in Lichtenberg, its neon sign casting an eerie glow over the wet pavement. Inside, Monika found herself face to face with the roll-neck man, whose presence seemed to fill the small space with an unspoken threat. The fluorescent lights of the shop cast harsh shadows across his features as he regarded her with calculated interest, while the sound of rain against the windows created an ominous backdrop to this surreal scenario. The entire sequence of events, from the violent disruption at the church hall to her forced relocation to this seemingly innocent hairdresser's shop, left Monika feeling trapped in a nightmare from which she couldn't wake up, her musician's hands now clenched into fists as she confronted whatever fate awaited her in this strange and threatening situation.
paragraph2: The church hall had a proper stage, and they were standing in the wings, waiting to go on, when some skinheads arrived. Not a few. Twenty or thirty. It was 88 Tommy’s birthday, and they’d all been drinking. Everyone knew 88 Tommy and his idiot friends, but tonight there were more of them, a lot of faces she didn’t recognize. D.G.F. went into their first song, and right away the skins pushed their way to the front. They started spitting and making obscene gestures. From farther back, someone threw a bottle. Monika was protected behind the kit, but at the front it was bad. Katja was jabbing at shirtless men with her mike stand, warning them to keep back. During the second song a couple of guys started Sieg heil-ing and one of them got onstage and pushed Elli down into the crowd and after that it was chaos. As if at a signal, the stage was full of skinheads throwing punches, kicking over the P.A., beating people with mike stands. Monika cowered behind her kit, unable to see what had happened to her friends. When she spotted an opening between the scuffling bodies, she ran for a side door. Almost as soon as she got outside, she was grabbed by two men in bureaucratic raincoats who smelled of cigarettes. They hustled her in the direction of a waiting car, talking loudly about how they were “here to protect” her and “get her to safety.” The street was full of people who had come outside to get away from the fight. The men made such a noise, raising their voices. They drew everybody’s attention. Pastor Daniel was in the crowd, holding a handkerchief against a wound on his forehead. He frowned as he saw her go past. She tried to shake the men off, but one of them poked her in the small of her back with a fist or a stick, a quick discreet attack that caused a flash of intense pain. While she was incapacitated, they more or less picked her up and threw her into the back seat of a car. They drove her to a hairdresser, of all places, nearby in Lichtenberg. The lights were on in the shop even though it was almost midnight. She could do with a makeover, said one, laughing. Mousy little thing like her ought to do something with herself. She should take a little more pride in her appearance. They led her to the back of the shop where, of course, the roll-neck man was waiting, natty in driving gloves and a new brown leather jacket. Have a seat, he said. Don’t worry, you’re safe now.

paragraph1: As Sander sat through dinner and into the night, his thoughts were consumed by the weight of sin that seemed to bear down upon him. He couldn't shake the feeling that he was losing the battle to find the holy part of himself, that the sinful desires that churned within him were slowly gaining the upper hand. His mother's suspicious glances only added to his sense of unease, as if she could see the turmoil that roiled beneath his surface. The absence of Clara, the woman who had captivated him, only intensified his feelings of guilt and responsibility, leaving him to wonder if his own sinful nature had driven her away. He felt a pang of sadness for her soul, as if he had somehow failed her. But then, just as the evening seemed at its darkest, Clara arrived, and Sander's heart surged with happiness and hope. For a moment, he allowed himself to imagine a future where they might marry, where his lustful thoughts might be balanced by a desire for virtue. It was a fragile thread of redemption, but Sander clung to it, desperate to believe that he might yet find a way to reconcile his sinful nature with his longing for the divine. As he gazed at Clara, he felt the weight of his struggle slowly begin to lift, replaced by a sense of possibility and promise.
paragraph2: All through dinner, all through the night, he wonders. Where is the holy part of him? He can’t find it, only sin. He seems to be made of sin, to contain nothing but dirty desires, tits and asses. All week, his mother looks at him as if she knows something, as if she suspects him, and maybe she’s right to. Clara’s white thigh torments him, the ease as her body enters the stream, the dazzle of sunlight on water and pale skin. She isn’t there at Fellowship. He looks from face to face and doesn’t see her. Then back to his mother, who has seen him searching, who knows, who is disappointed in him. This much good remains in Sander: he’s sad for the sake of Clara’s immortal soul that he drove her away. His greed and sin have pushed her back into the darkness. He sees again what a trap and a contrivance the world is, a tangle of sin and pain. And Sander’s God is nowhere near. He searches and searches within himself. Then she arrives, and Sander fills with an unreasonable happiness. All is not lost, not yet. She takes her place in the women’s section and kneels and prays, modest in her long skirt, a gray scarf over her head. She’s naked under her clothes, though. Sander knows this. Maybe God will find a way for them. Maybe they will marry. Maybe there is a godly way. Sander is filled with lust and virtue at the same time, seeing her in bridal white, the tattoo snaking up her neck. Sander in a good suit, with a good haircut . . .

paragraph1: Two weeks ago, he’d been discharged for unreliability and insubordination. The man Jim was inside—not the blushing, humiliated boy who’d stood ham-handed before the bosses—had shaken off the blow and turned away. But Annie had wept when he told her, and then said angrily, through her tears, that there was a baby coming, knowing even as she said it that to break the news to him in this way was to condemn the child to a life of trouble. He took the tea towels she had left to dry by the sink, wound them into ropes, and placed them along the windowsill. He carried the length of rubber tubing through the living room and into the bedroom. He slipped off his shoes and put the tube to his mouth as if to pull smoke. He had seen this in a picture book somewhere: a fat sultan on a red pillow, doing much the same. He sat on the edge of the bed. He bowed his head and prayed: now and at the hour of our death. He lay back on the bed. He noticed that the room had grown dimmer still. Hour of our. Our hour. He remembered his mother, the picture book spread out on her wide lap. Within this very hour he would put his head on her shoulder once again. Or would he? Would this effort to prove himself his own man—to prove that the hours of his life belonged to himself alone—bar him from Heaven? Did he believe in Heaven? There were moments when his faith fell out from under him like a trapdoor. He stood up. Found his nightshirt beneath his pillow and twisted it, too. Then placed it along the edge of the bedroom window, again pushing the material into the narrow crevice where the frame met the sill, knowing all the while that the gesture was both ineffectual and unnecessary.
paragraph2: Jim stood in the dimly lit kitchen, his trembling fingers tracing the edge of the tea towels he'd gathered, while the memory of his dismissal played relentlessly in his mind like a broken record. The humiliation of facing his supervisors, their stern faces etched with disappointment as they listed his infractions—unreliability, insubordination—still burned fresh in his consciousness. Annie's reaction had been exactly as he'd feared: first the shocked silence, then the flood of tears, and finally the explosive anger that seemed to shake their small apartment's walls. Her pregnancy made the timing impossibly cruel, and Jim could see their carefully planned future crumbling before his eyes. As he methodically collected the rubber tubing from beneath the sink, a strange image from a childhood picture book floated into his mind—a sultan, resplendent in his robes, master of his own destiny. The irony wasn't lost on Jim as he contemplated how his own attempt to seize control might be his final act of defiance. His hands instinctively clasped together in prayer, a lifetime of religious teaching wrestling with his current intentions. The question that tormented him most was whether Heaven's gates would remain forever closed to someone who chose their own exit. Yet even as he made his preparations, arranging the items with a precision that seemed absurd given their purpose, he recognized the futility of it all. Each movement felt like a step in an elaborate dance between desperation and the faint whisper of hope that still lingered somewhere in the recesses of his mind, urging him to find another way out of this darkness that had enveloped his world so completely.
text_input:

But Annie had wept when he told her, and then said angrily, through her tears, that there was a baby coming, knowing even as she said it that to break the news to him in this way was to condemn the child to a life of trouble. He took the tea towels she had left to dry by the sink, wound them into ropes, and placed them along the windowsill. He carried the length of rubber tubing through the living room and into the bedroom. He slipped off his shoes and put the tube to his mouth as if to pull smoke. He had seen this in a picture book somewhere: a fat sultan on a red pillow, doing much the same. He sat on the edge of the bed. He bowed his head and prayed: now and at the hour of our death. He lay back on the bed. He noticed that the room had grown dimmer still. Hour of our. Our hour. He remembered his mother, the picture book spread out on her wide lap. Within this very hour he would put his head on her shoulder once again. Or would he? Would this effort to prove himself his own man—to prove that the hours of his life belonged to himself alone—bar him from Heaven? Did he believe in Heaven? There were moments when his faith fell out from under him like a trapdoor. He stood up. Found his nightshirt beneath his pillow and twisted it, too. Then placed it along the edge of the bedroom window, again pushing the material into the narrow crevice where the frame met the sill, knowing all the while that the gesture was both ineffectual and unnecessary.

Paragraph 2:
Jim stood in the dimly lit kitchen, his trembling fingers tracing the edge of the tea towels he'd gathered, while the memory of his dismissal played relentlessly in his mind like a broken record. The humiliation of facing his supervisors, their stern faces etched with disappointment as they listed his infractions—unreliability, insubordination—still burned fresh in his consciousness. Annie's reaction had been exactly as he'd feared: first the shocked silence, then the flood of tears, and finally the explosive anger that seemed to shake their small apartment's walls. Her pregnancy made the timing impossibly cruel, and Jim could see their carefully planned future crumbling before his eyes. As he methodically collected the rubber tubing from beneath the sink, a strange image from a childhood picture book floated into his mind—a sultan, resplendent in his robes, master of his own destiny. The irony wasn't lost on Jim as he contemplated how his own attempt to seize control might be his final act of defiance. His hands instinctively clasped together in prayer, a lifetime of religious teaching wrestling with his current intentions. The question that tormented him most was whether Heaven's gates would remain forever closed to someone who chose their own exit. Yet even as he made his preparations, arranging the items with a precision that seemed absurd given their purpose, he recognized the futility of it all. Each movement felt like a step in an elaborate dance between desperation and the faint whisper of hope that still lingered somewhere in the recesses of his mind, urging him to find another way out of this darkness that had enveloped his world so completely.

You must produce your answer in the following JSON format:
{"preference": "1|2"}

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: Divining their love, she quickly banished Mooshum to the men’s bunkhouse, where he soon learned the many ways in which he could make children in the future with Junesse. He practiced in his mind, and could hardly wait. But Maude forbade their marriage until both were sixteen. When that day came, she threw a wedding supper that was talked about for years, featuring several delectably roasted animals that seemed to be the same size and type as those which had gone missing from the farms of the dinner guests. This caused a stir, but Maude kept the liquor flowing, and most of the ranchers shrugged it off. What was not shrugged off, what was truly resented, was the fact that Maude had thrown an elaborate shindig for a couple of Indians. Or half-breeds. It didn’t matter which. These were uncertain times in North Dakota. People’s nerves were still shot over what had happened to Custer, and every few years there occurred a lynching. Just a few years before, the remains of five men had been found, still strung from trees, supposedly the victims of a vigilante party led by Flopping Bill Cantrell. Some time later, an entire family was murdered and three Indians were caught by a mob and hanged for maybe doing it, including a boy named Paul Holy Track, who was only thirteen. The foul murder of a woman on a farm just to the west of Maude’s place caused the neighbors to disregard, in their need for immediate revenge, the sudden absence of that woman’s husband and to turn their thoughts to the nearest available Indian.
paragraph2: As Mooshum's love for Junesse became increasingly apparent, Maude, with a knowing glint in her eye, sent him packing to the men's bunkhouse, where he would eagerly await a future with his beloved. Though the young lovers were bursting with anticipation, Maude insisted they wait until they were both sixteen to tie the knot, a stipulation they begrudgingly accepted. When the day of their wedding finally arrived, Maude pulled out all the stops, hosting a memorable supper that featured an assortment of roasted animals that bore a suspicious resemblance to those that had gone missing from the guests' farms. The initial stir caused by this revelation was quickly placated with liberal pours of liquor, but beneath the surface, resentment simmered, fueled by the fact that the celebration was for a couple of Indians, or, as some of the guests disparagingly referred to them, half-breeds. The tense racial climate in North Dakota, where the lynching of Native Americans was a tragic reality, still lingered in the air, a painful reminder of the violence and injustice that had been perpetrated against the community, including the wrongful hanging of a young boy named Paul Holy Track. And now, with the recent murder of a local resident, the community was quick to point fingers at a nearby Indian, further exacerbating the already volatile tensions, as the cycle of blame and hatred continued unabated.

paragraph1: I often find myself lost in thoughts about my family's history, a rich tapestry interwoven with stories and symbols that have shaped who I am today. One particular memory stands out vividly—receiving a small, unassuming paperweight as a child. At first glance, it seemed like a simple object, but for me, it represented much more. It was a metaphor for the complex and intricate history of my family, a history that I have spent countless hours contemplating. I often liken our family history to grapes, each grape representing a story, a life, a moment in time that has contributed to the vast vineyard of our shared past. This metaphorical vineyard is both beautiful and burdensome, as it carries the weight of generations of love, struggle, and resilience. Nowadays, my reflections on family history are often intertwined with my anxieties about my child, Astra. I find myself consumed by an obsessive fear that Astra might choke on food—a fear that has taken root deep within me and grown into a pervasive worry that I cannot seem to shake. This fear has become a point of tension between my partner, Inma, and me, as well as with Inma's mother, who frequently sides with Inma in our disagreements. Inma and I have different approaches to parenting, and my anxiety over Astra choking often leads to arguments that seem to encompass broader issues of power and love within our relationship. Inma believes that I am overly cautious and that my fears are unfounded, while I feel that my concerns are valid and that I am simply trying to protect our child. This conflict is further complicated by the involvement of Inma's mother, whose opinions often add fuel to the fire. She seems to view my concerns as an overreaction, aligning herself with Inma's more relaxed approach. In these moments, I feel isolated and misunderstood, my fears dismissed as irrational. However, my anxiety is very real to me, and it manifests in various ways, from meticulously cutting Astra's food into tiny, manageable pieces to constantly watching for any signs of distress while she eats. It's as though my fear of choking has become a focal point of my life, a lens through which I view my role as a parent and protector. This fear has caused me to question my abilities and has led to moments of self-doubt and insecurity. Despite the tension it creates, I cannot simply ignore what feels like an ever-present danger. Then, one day, I found myself in a situation that forced me to confront my own fears in a very personal way. I was enjoying a meal when, suddenly, I began to choke. In those terrifying moments, I realized how fragile life truly is and how easily the unexpected can occur. As I struggled to breathe, it dawned on me that my fear of Astra choking was not just about the act itself but about the vulnerability and lack of control that it represented. This incident served as a catalyst for introspection and self-awareness, prompting me to reconsider the dynamics at play in my relationship with Inma. I began to see that our differing beliefs about voicing fears were at the heart of many of our conflicts. Inma tends to approach life with a sense of optimism and trust, believing that voicing fears gives them power and life. In contrast, I have always felt that expressing my fears is a way to confront and manage them, to prepare for the worst so that I am not caught off guard. Our opposing viewpoints have led to misunderstandings and arguments, each of us convinced that our way is the right way. Through this experience, I realized that perhaps there is no right or wrong way, but rather a need for balance and understanding. I understood that my fear, while valid, should not overshadow the joy and spontaneity of life. Similarly, Inma's optimism should be tempered with caution and preparedness. This newfound understanding has not magically resolved our differences, but it has opened the door to more open and empathetic communication. It has allowed me to express my fears in a way that invites dialogue rather than defensiveness, and it has encouraged Inma to acknowledge my concerns without dismissing them outright. As we continue to navigate the challenges of parenthood and partnership, I am learning to let go of the need for control and to embrace the unpredictability of life. I am slowly coming to terms with the fact that I cannot protect Astra from every danger, just as I cannot rewrite the past or alter my family's history. Instead, I can strive to create a nurturing and supportive environment where Astra can grow and thrive, where fears can be voiced and addressed without judgment. This journey is ongoing, and there are still moments of tension and disagreement, but I am hopeful that, with time and patience, we can find a balance that allows us to move forward together, united in our love for Astra and our commitment to one another.
paragraph2: When I was a child, somebody gave me a paperweight that contained within it an impossibly detailed forest scene, and when I think of the grapes, of how all the complexity of our family became enfolded in the grapes, I imagine that if I had lifted one of those grapes up to the light and rotated it around I would have perceived within it all of our family histories depicted in miniature, not just me and Inma in our own high chairs at the dawn of the eighties, our parents feeding us, but our own parents being fed in the forties and fifties, all the way back to our respective Old Worlds, Kyiv and San Juan, kasha or plantains, however mouths were sated and policed according to family and cultural custom, and if I kept rotating the grape I’d also see Mrs. Sackett wielding her pencil of life and Mr. Kessler telling us not to practice our thrusts, all of it as intricately rendered as the shield of Achilles, or Zeuxis’ grapes, which were so perfectly represented in his paintings that birds tried to eat them, birds, which sing from their syrinx, not their larynx, and cannot to my knowledge choke to death, although some can mimic human speech. When I was in charge of preparing Astra’s food, I chopped everything so finely I admit I might as well have blended it or hit it with a hammer, which is not what I was supposed to be doing, I was supposed to be giving her an experience of texture, as Inma kept pointing out—“She has to learn what she likes; she has to learn to use her teeth”—and since Inma’s mother was over many times a week she often witnessed Inma remarking that I’d inadvertently liquefied Astra’s food, and of course Inma’s mom silently sided with Inma, forming a triangle; I was the neurotic cracker with no experience caring for children who was trying to micromanage the steamed carrots, the hot dogs (which, thankfully, Astra didn’t really like), and the grapes. Because Inma’s mom had taught kindergarten (she’d recently retired), I’d hoped she might share the intensity of my concern about Astra choking—surely there had been trainings about these things—but although both Inma and her mother were incredibly conscientious caretakers in general, so graceful and competent with Astra that I felt bumbling in comparison, and although they watched her closely when she ate, the fear of her choking quickly became my thing, the worry I carried that carried all of my other worries: I would pulverize the food and they would not quite slice it properly, which is the way of polarization. When Inma’s mom was sitting with Astra at the table, it was less that I watched over them than that my effort not to was palpable, and if Inma or her mom was cutting something for Astra I perceived a slight exaggeration in their gestures, a trace of performativity that said, See how tiny these pieces are? Do we have your permission to feed her? It was a cliché, this tension around the child’s eating, the triangulation, etc., but I was finding small, mortally uncut grapes in the purple plastic snack container Inma’s mom took with Astra to the park, and large grapes on the high chair that were cut in half but never lengthwise (anyway, they should be quartered), and then I’d confront Inma about it, as if it were her fault, demanding she talk to her mom, and before we knew it we would be having a spectacular fight, scaling up from the grapes to questions of power, labor, value, the possibility of love, Astra crying when we yelled (or, worse, taking it all in silently, blinking her large brown eyes). We’d had one such fight only a month or two before I choked. And it was only when I choked, while I was standing there choking at Café Loup, that I fully realized (although not in these words) that our polarization around the grapes issued from our conflicting but, in fact, equally magical beliefs about the effects of my voicing, again and again, my fear of Astra choking. Inma would of course agree that the food should be cut up, but the intensity of my focus on this particular risk, the repetitive articulation of my concerns—reading statistics off my phone (“Last year alone, every child in America choked to death”), showing with my thumb and index finger the tiny diameter of a child’s windpipe—was, in Inma’s mind, courting disaster. This was both because talking about it at all invited the evil in and because too much confidence in “risk management,” the financialized world view of the privileged, was a kind of hubris, the fantasy that you could halve or quarter the constant threats that attended living; it was asking God, or whatever cosmic force, to cut you lengthwise down to size. Inma, then, did not speak her fears, for fear that speaking them would make them happen (that speaking them would summon one of those little tornadoes of debris); she did not, while pregnant with Astra, ever acknowledge her terror of another late miscarriage, for instance, neither to me nor, I’m sure, to her mother, whereas I told my own mother constantly that the pregnan

paragraph1: As Morse stood there, his mind began to wander to the impending piano recital that his son Robert was scheduled to perform in, and his anxiety level skyrocketed. He couldn't shake the feeling that it was going to be a disaster, what with Robert's lack of practice and the fact that they didn't even have a real piano at home. The makeshift cardboard keyboard he had crafted for Robert to practice on had been a valiant effort, but it had ultimately fallen victim to his daughter Annie's voracious appetite. Morse's thoughts swirled with strategies to encourage Robert to practice, but every time he considered being more forceful, he was met with a pang of hesitation - he simply couldn't bear the thought of seeing Robert upset. As he stood there, his brow furrowed in worry, Morse's body began to betray his inner turmoil, his shoulders tensing and his jaw clenched in a futile attempt to ward off the stress that was building inside him. The pressures of parenting weighed heavily on him, and in this moment, Morse felt like he was shouldering the weight of the world, his love for his children tangled up in a knot of anxiety and uncertainty.
paragraph2: Why should he be worried when all he was doing was going home to enjoy his beautiful children without a care in the world, although on the other hand there was Robert’s piano recital, which was sure to be a disaster, since Robert never practiced and they had no piano and weren’t even sure where or when the recital was and Annie, God bless her, had eaten the cardboard keyboard he’d made for Robert to practice on. When he got home he would make Robert a new cardboard keyboard and beg him to practice. He might even order him to practice. He might even order him to make his own cardboard keyboard, then practice, although this was unlikely, because when he became forceful with Robert, Robert blubbered, and Morse loved Robert so much he couldn’t stand to see him blubbering, although if he didn’t become forceful with Robert, Robert tended to lie on his bed with his baseball glove over his face. Good God, but life could be less than easy, not that he was unaware that it could certainly be a lot worse, but to go about in such a state, pulse high, face red, worried sick that someone would notice how nervous one was, was certainly less than ideal, and he felt sure that his body was secreting all kinds of harmful chemicals and that the more he worried about the harmful chemicals the faster they were pouring out of wherever it was they came from.

paragraph1: She was very young, shy, scarcely educated, though she had attended an élite girls’ boarding school in Jaipur. After her marriage, her mother-in-law tried to encourage her to study at some New Delhi college, but Naina claimed to be too stupid—yes, even for domestic science. Although Kishen couldn’t help agreeing that she was, to some extent, stupid, she was the only person in the house with whom he was eager to discuss his projected novel. She took no interest in it at all, yet somehow she casually disposed of one of his greatest problems: how to communicate the nuances of Indian life in English, which was the only language in which he could truly express himself. Naina simply jumbled up her languages, English and Hindi. When he tried to talk to her about his work (because he wanted to talk to her about everything), she didn’t even pretend to listen. Instead, she said, “I’m meeting the girls—coffee pina hai. Aoge? Chalo bhai we’ll have some fun—mazza ajaiga.” She had formed her own circle of girlfriends, and Kishen soon became a source of entertainment for them. Naina was proud of the way he amused them and humored all their concerns. They valued his opinion in matters of style, and also of culture, though he laughed at their taste, which hadn’t changed since they were schoolgirls. They held morning coffee parties in the smartest Connaught Place restaurants or watched pirated films together on the giant screens in their giant living rooms. When they cried at a heroine’s onscreen plight, Kishen would murmur some remark into Naina’s ear, converting her tears into giggles, which soon spread to all the weeping girls.
paragraph2: Naina and Kishen's relationship was an intriguing blend of contrasts and unexpected synergy. Naina, a young, shy woman with limited formal education despite attending an elite boarding school in Jaipur, often viewed herself as unintelligent, dismissing the idea of pursuing further studies in New Delhi despite her mother-in-law's encouragement. Kishen, her husband, shared a somewhat similar assessment, yet he valued her immensely as the sole confidante with whom he wished to discuss his novel, even if her interest appeared minimal. In a serendipitous moment, Naina inadvertently aided him in overcoming a writing hurdle by blending English and Hindi, showcasing an intuitive brilliance that even she seemed unaware of. Outside of Kishen's literary world, Naina was more drawn to her circle of girlfriends, frequently inviting Kishen to join their coffee meet-ups and social gatherings. Though he was initially an outsider in these circles, Kishen quickly became a beloved source of amusement for Naina and her friends. His insightful opinions on style and culture, delivered with a dose of humor, often transformed their gatherings into lively events. Kishen's witty remarks had the remarkable ability to turn tears into laughter, endearing him to the group and creating a unique space where his and Naina's worlds intersected harmoniously. Despite their differing interests and Naina's self-doubt regarding her intellectual capabilities, the couple managed to create a dynamic that was as enriching as it was entertaining, offering a glimpse into the subtle ways their lives were intertwined.

When they cried at a heroine’s onscreen plight, Kishen would murmur some remark into Naina’s ear, converting her tears into giggles, which soon spread to all the weeping girls.

Outside of Kishen's literary world, Naina was more drawn to her circle of girlfriends, frequently inviting Kishen to join their coffee meet-ups and social gatherings. Though he was initially an outsider in these circles, Kishen quickly became a beloved source of amusement for Naina and her friends. His insightful opinions on style and culture, delivered with a dose of humor, often transformed their gatherings into lively events. Kishen's witty remarks had the remarkable ability to turn tears into laughter, endearing him to the group and creating a unique space where his and Naina's worlds intersected harmoniously. Despite their differing interests and Naina's self-doubt regarding her intellectual capabilities, the couple managed to create a dynamic that was as enriching as it was entertaining, offering a glimpse into the subtle ways their lives were intertwined.
