paragraph1: She tried to get them to describe the animals. Did the boys speak to them or touch them? Were there birds? There were birds, apparently, but very small ones. Were there horses there? When she was a child, she wanted to be a horse. She had a treasured collection of horses—metal, ceramic, plastic, wood. She had never ridden a horse or cared for one, but she had kept pictures of them and much commentary concerning them in a large black notebook for many years, though the book had been missing for just as long. “Maybe someone’s using it as a barn,” she said. “A corral.” Her son regarded her with disappointment. “Maybe. Not really,” Jerome said politely. “When you’re there, you know that something is going to happen any moment and you wait with them so you can be there when it happens,” Billy said. “You haven’t been invited to stay but you’re welcome to stay. It’s just about to happen.” “But what?” she asked, smiling. “And why?” She remembers smiling. She can feel it still on her lips, the falsity and carelessness of it. Then they spoke no further of the ruined little building and the animals.
paragraph2: She leaned forward, eager to connect with her sons Jerome and Billy about their animal encounters, her voice carrying a mix of maternal curiosity and personal nostalgia. As she inquired about birds and horses, memories of her own childhood fascination with equines surfaced - though she had never actually ridden or tended to one. The missing notebook from her youth, filled with horse-related musings, briefly crossed her mind as she waited for her boys' responses. Jerome's politeness was evident but lacking genuine interest, his replies measured and distant, while Billy's face lit up as he described the anticipation he felt around the animals. She caught herself forcing a smile, aware of its artificiality, as the conversation about the creatures and the deteriorating structure gradually faded into silence. The moment highlighted the delicate balance between her desire to share in her children's experiences and the reality that their interests might diverge from her own childhood passions, creating a subtle undercurrent of disconnection beneath the surface of their exchange.

paragraph1: Living in North Galway has been a peculiar experience, filled with moments that both amuse and perplex me. The locals here seem to carry an air of excessive sensuality, a notion that echoes historical observations, like those of Thackeray, who once commented on the behavior and attire of rural Irish women. While I find these musings amusing, John Murphy, a local acquaintance, often dismisses such romantic pursuits as relics of his past. His indifference is a stark contrast to the vibrant energy that pulses through the town. Lately, I've been contemplating selling my property and moving to Cambodia, a prospect that seems more appealing with each passing day. My thoughts, however, are interrupted by Nadia, who bursts in with a frantic account of an otter in the kitchen. True to her coldhearted nature, her panic is more about the disruption than the creature itself. When I investigate, I find the otter calmly lapping up soup, seemingly unperturbed by my presence. After some effort, I manage to shoo it outside, watching as it makes its way to higher ground rather than the usual tide-line rocks. This deviation concerns me, triggering thoughts of potential flooding. I turn to the locals for reassurance, including Bill Knott, who confidently tells me that it hasn't flooded in sixteen years and won’t now. Despite his reassurances, my anxiety lingers, perhaps fueled by the quiet disdain I sense from the townsfolk. They seem to regard me as an outsider, someone who neglects their property and fails to grasp the rhythm of life here. This perception, whether true or imagined, only adds to my growing discontent. The otter incident, the locals' attitudes, and my own restless spirit converge, leaving me more convinced than ever that my future lies elsewhere, perhaps on the serene shores of Cambodia, far from the watchful eyes and whispered judgments of North Galway.
paragraph2: The people of this part of North Galway are oversexed. That is my belief. I had found a level of ribaldry that bordered on the paganistic. It goes back, of course. They lick it up off the crooked rocks. Thackeray, indeed, remarked on the corsetless dress of rural Irish women, and the fact that they kissed perfect strangers in greeting, their vast bosoms swinging. “It’s not,” John Murphy said, “like I’m goin’ to take a lep at the little bitch. My leppin’ days are long fuckin’ over.” If I sold the place for even three-quarters of what I paid for it, I could buy half of Cambodia and do a Colonel fucking Kurtz on it. Lovely, coldhearted Nadia came running from the kitchen. She was as white as the fallen dead. “Is otter!” she cried. “What?” “Is otter in kitchen!” she cried. He was eating soup when I got there. Carrot and coriander from a ten-gallon pot. Normally, they are terribly skittish, otters, but this fellow was languorous as a surfer. Nervously, I shooed him toward the back door. He took his own sweet time about heading there. Once outside, he aimed not for the tide-line rocks, where the otters all lived, but for the higher ground, south. I looked out toward the harbor. The harbor wall was disappearing beneath spilling sheets of water. I came back into the lounge. “A fucking otter is right,” I said. They looked at me, the locals, in quiet disgust, as if I could expect no less than otters in the kitchen, the way I was after letting things go. I pointed to the harbor. “Will it flood?” I asked, and there was a quake in my tone. “You’d make good time coming out of Sligo, normally,” Bill Knott said. “Unless you had a Thursday on your hands. But of course them fuckers have any amount of a road under them since McSharry was minister.” “I said will it flood, Bill? Will it flood? Are you even listening to me?” A gray silence swelled briefly. “Hasn’t in sixteen years,” he said. “Won’t now.”

paragraph1: Morris's grandfather often recalled the words his mother shared during one of their long walks by the river, where the water always seemed in a hurry but never reached it's destination. She spoke slowly, as if weighing each word before setting it free. "Revenge," she told him, "is like carrying a coal from this fire with your bare hand. You might intend to throw it at someone who hurt you, but it burns you long before it reaches them." Morris could still hear the crackle of the fire that night and see the way the flames danced in her eyes, reflecting wisdom earned through years of silent suffering. She never told him not to feel anger; instead, she helped him understand that anger needed tending, like a fire that could either warm him on cold nights or burn down the whole house if left unchecked. Many years later, when Morris faced his own adversities, he thought about the weight of that coal, the way it singes even before it's thrown, and he made a choice—not to be unscathed, but to heal.

A fire that could warm you on cold nights could burn down the whole house if left unchecked. Many years later, when Morris faced his own adversities, he thought about the weight of that coal. He thought about the way it singed even before it was thrown.

paragraph1: “Wrong number,” he mumbled, and hung up, but was unable to get to sleep again. In the morning, Shelby slid out of bed before he could touch her. She said, “Show me whatever you’re going to show me, then let’s go home.” He drove her to his old neighborhood and then slowly down the street where he had lived as a boy. The trees were gone, the wood-frame houses faded and small. Shelby sat, inattentive, distracted. At one point, he urged her to get out of the car, and he walked her to the side of a garage, where he’d carved a heart on a cinder block with a spike, the petroglyph still visible after all these years. It was here, in the garage between two houses, that he’d kissed a girl—what was her name?—one Halloween night, crushing her against the wall, tasting the candy in her mouth and running his hands over her body. “Hello, stranger.” A great fat woman with wild hair stood, almost filling the space between the garage and the nearby house. She laughed, and put her hands on her hips. She wore bruised sneakers and no socks, and when she opened her mouth Ray could see gaps in her teeth, most of her molars missing. She raised one hand, clapping a cigarette to her lips, then blew smoke at him. “I’ve been waiting for you.” “Is it—” He squinted to remember the name. “Louise?” “Who else?” she said, then, “Who’s that—your daughter?” and laughed again.
paragraph2: Ray found himself wide awake after a wrong number call jostled him from his slumber. Unable to return to sleep, he decided to revisit his old neighborhood later that day, taking Shelby along for company. As he navigated the familiar streets, Ray shared snippets of his past with Shelby, pointing out places that held significant memories for him, including a spot where he once experienced an unforgettable encounter with a girl from his youth. Despite his efforts to engage her, Shelby seemed largely uninterested, her eyes glazing over as Ray recounted tales of his past. Their stroll through the neighborhood took an unexpected turn when they encountered Louise, a woman who recognized Ray immediately. Louise, a large woman with wild, unkempt hair, wore worn sneakers and flashed a smile that revealed several missing teeth. Her familiarity with Ray was evident as she approached them with humor, mistakenly assuming that Shelby was Ray's daughter. The encounter, though brief, was filled with laughter and light-hearted banter, as Louise's jovial nature momentarily lifted the veil of indifference that Shelby wore. Ray found himself chuckling at Louise's mistaken assumption, appreciating her ability to inject humor into the day. Despite Shelby's lack of enthusiasm, Ray felt a sense of nostalgia and connection to his past, brought to life by the vibrant characters and memories that inhabited his old neighborhood. As they continued their walk, Ray couldn't help but reflect on the unexpected twists that life often presented.

paragraph1: Emma sat on the edge of the bed, staring at the wall as if it had the answers she was searching for. She wasn't attracted to Paul, and that truth weighed on her every day. The reasons she stayed with him were scattered, like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle that didn't quite fit together. Paul was dependable, a constant in her life when everything else seemed uncertain. She had grown used to the rhythm of their days, the quiet comfort of his presence. Their conversations weren't electric, but they were honest, and that counted for something. Her mother had said love was about compromise, and Emma wondered if this was the kind of compromise she meant. There was also the sinking feeling of time slipping away, a fear of what she'd lose if she let him go. Paul adored her, and that kind of affection felt rare, like a fragile bird she was afraid to set free. She questioned herself constantly: how much did physical attraction really matter? Maybe love was about more than sparks and butterflies. She felt guilty, knowing Paul sensed her hesitations but chose to ignore them, always hopeful she would come around. Emma stayed because leaving felt like throwing away something she didn't fully understand yet.

paragraph1: Tucked away in the bustling heart of Izmir, Konak Pier and Sevince Lokantasi offer a glimpse into the city's rich culinary tapestry. The pier, a restored 19th-century customs house, now houses a selection of cafes and restaurants where locals and visitors alike gather to savor Aegean flavors. Here, one can indulge in freshly caught seafood while watching fishing boats bob gently in the harbor. A short walk away, Sevince Lokantasi stands as a testament to Izmir's enduring food traditions. This unassuming eatery, with it's worn wooden tables and faded photographs, serves up hearty portions of home-style Turkish cuisine. The menu changes daily, reflecting the seasons and the chef's whims, but always features local specialties like stuffed grape leaves and slow-cooked lamb. What sets these places apart is not just the food, but the stories woven into each dish - tales of family recipes passed down through generations, of ingredients sourced from nearby villages, and of a city's ever-evolving palate. As you dine, you'll find yourself in conversation with neighboring tables, sharing recommendations and swapping anecdotes, becoming part of Izmir's living culinary narrative.

paragraph1: As we sat discussing the latest headlines, I couldn't help but notice his skeptical expression when I mentioned the more sensational stories. "You can't believe everything you read," he said, waving his hand dismissively before abruptly changing the subject to more practical matters. He began detailing his recent updates to his will, the house maintenance that needed attention, and even mentioned securing a cemetery plot – topics that seemed to weigh heavily on his mind lately. When I offered to inform Peggy about these arrangements, he quickly shook his head, explaining that she and Sam were preparing for their conference in Amsterdam, and he didn't want to burden them with such matters. His face brightened noticeably at the mention of Sam, my brother-in-law, and I could see the unmistakable pride in his eyes as he spoke about Sam's achievements in astronomy. "Those three little Sams," he chuckled, referring to his grandsons, "they're all taking after their father – sharp as tacks, every one of them." He went on to detail their academic accomplishments, from science fairs to advanced placement classes, though he couldn't resist adding his characteristic teasing remarks about how they'd inherited their grandfather's good looks rather than their father's. As he spoke, I noticed how he skillfully wove together pride and playful criticism, a trait he extended to all family members, including myself. He'd often follow a compliment with a gentle jab, like reminding me of my failed attempt at growing tomatoes last summer while praising my career achievements. It was his way of keeping us all grounded while showing his affection, and though I sometimes rolled my eyes at his comments, I understood the love behind them. The conversation meandered between serious matters and family anecdotes, reflecting the complex dynamics of our relationship and his role as both a practical-minded patriarch and a doting grandfather who couldn't quite hide his soft spot for his family beneath his critical exterior.
paragraph2: “Did it seem—convincing?” “Oh, I don’t know. It’s all in whether you want to believe that kind of thing or not. And if you are going to believe it, take it seriously, I figure you’ve got to take everything else seriously that they print in those papers.” “What else do they?” “Rubbish—cancer cures, baldness cures, bellyaching about the younger generation and the welfare bums. Tripe about movie stars.” “Oh, yes. I know.” “In my situation you have to keep a watch,” he said, “or you’ll start playing tricks on yourself.” Then he said, “There’s a few practical details we ought to get straight on,” and he told me about his will, the house, the cemetery plot. Everything was simple. “Do you want me to phone Peggy?” I said. Peggy is my sister. She is married to an astronomer and lives in Victoria. He thought about it. “I guess we ought to tell them,” he said finally. “But tell them not to get alarmed.” “All right.” “No, wait a minute. Sam is supposed to be going to a conference the end of this week, and Peggy was planning to go along with him. I don’t want them wondering about changing their plans.” “Where is the conference?” “Amsterdam,” he said proudly. He did take pride in Sam, and kept track of his books and articles. He would pick one up and say, “Look at that, will you? And I can’t understand a word of it!” in a marveling voice that managed nevertheless to have a trace of ridicule. “Professor Sam,” he would say. “And the three little Sams.” This is what he called his grandsons, who did resemble their father in braininess and in an almost endearing pushiness—an innocent energetic showing-off. They went to a private school that favored old-fashioned discipline and started calculus in Grade Five. “And the dogs,” he might enumerate further, “who have been to obedience school. And Peggy . . .” But if I said, “Do you suppose she has been to obedience school, too?” he would play the game no further, I imagine that when he was with Sam and Peggy he spoke of me in the same way—hinted at my flightiness just as he hinted at their stodginess, made mild jokes at my expense, did not quite conceal his amazement (or pretended not to conceal his amazement) that people paid money for things I had painted.

paragraph1: As Wolfe stepped off the train, he had stopped to purchase a bag of plums from a vendor near the station, but they proved to be disappointingly sour. With a flick of his wrist, he tossed them out the window as the train rumbled on, lost in thought about the cardboard disks he had left behind at a café earlier that day. He turned to Natasha with a whimsical glint in his eye, remarking that if only he had taken those disks, they would be soaring through the air like birds by now. Natasha smiled wearily, her exhaustion punctuated by fleeting moments of lightness. She asked Wolfe to refrain from interrupting her when she recounted their outing to her father, hinting that she might just embellish their adventures for his benefit. As they disembarked in town, they opted to walk home, the city's din and chaos enveloping them. Wolfe's silence grew, his displeasure with the noise palpable, while Natasha, despite her fatigue, felt an unexpected buoyancy, her steps light and energized in stark contrast to Wolfe's somber demeanor. The disparity in their moods was a stark reminder of the vastly different ways they experienced the world around them.
paragraph2: Near the train station, Wolfe bought a paper bag of plums, but they turned out to be sour. Seated in the empty wooden compartment of the train, he threw them at intervals out the window, and kept regretting that, in the café, he had not filched some of those cardboard disks you put under beer mugs. “They soar so beautifully, Natasha, like birds. It’s a joy to watch.” Natasha was tired; she would shut her eyes tightly, and then again, as she had been in the night, she would be overcome and carried aloft by a feeling of dizzying lightness. “When I tell Father about our outing, please don’t interrupt me or correct me. I may well tell him about things we did not see at all. Various little marvels. He’ll understand.” When they arrived in town, they decided to walk home. Baron Wolfe grew taciturn and grimaced at the ferocious noise of the automobile horns, while Natasha seemed propelled by sails, as if her fatigue sustained her, endowed her with wings and made her weightless, and Wolfe seemed all blue, as blue as the evening.

paragraph1: When I am feeling hopeless about my life, when my hands hang from my sleeves like dead men dangling, when, catching sight of myself in a plate-glass window, I turn violently away, but not before I’ve seen myself turn violently away, then I know it’s time for me to be in the company of my second wife, who knows how to comfort me. Even as I arrive at the front door, holding my leather laptop case in one hand and reaching for my key with the other, she’s looking at me anxiously and asking about my day, she’s helping me out of my belted trenchcoat and hanging up my hat, she’s placing my case by the umbrella stand. Already she is leading me to an armchair—my favorite one, with the thick armrests—where she places a pillow behind my head and touches my forehead with her hand, while at the same time she’s lifting my feet onto the hassock, she’s removing my shoes and pressing her cheek against my leg. “Are you all right?” she asks, looking at me with tender concern. And gazing at me earnestly she asks, “Have you had a hard day?” Later, when she has undressed me, and bathed me, and laid me on the bed, she bends over me and says, “Do you like this?” and “Do you like this?” Still later, waking beside her, I feel a sudden doubt. Roughly I shake her awake. Staring into her sleepy eyes, I tell her that I could never endure a rival, that I’ll leave her instantly if she ever tries a trick like that, she can’t take advantage of me, I wasn’t born yesterday. During my outburst her large, startled eyes fill with tears. Gradually a relief comes over me, I grow calm, I glance at the clock and see that it’s getting late, a yawn shudders through me, and as I close my eyes and begin to drift toward deep, soothing sleep I feel her lying awake beside me, searching for the cause of my distress, rehearsing the events of the past few hours, reproaching herself for not loving me enough, her eyes wide, her heart racing, her cheek resting tensely against my shoulder.
paragraph2: As I stumble through the door, weighed down by an inexplicable heaviness that seems to have taken permanent residence in my chest, she's there, as always, her eyes scanning my face with that familiar mixture of love and concern. My second wife, my anchor in these turbulent times, immediately springs into action, her gentle hands helping me shed my coat like a second skin of despair. She guides me to the armchair – my refuge – and I sink into its embrace, watching through half-closed eyes as she flutters around me with practiced devotion. Later, her touch remains tender as she undresses me, each movement deliberate and caring, the bathwater she's prepared hitting the perfect temperature that soothes my aching muscles and troubled mind. Yet, even in these moments of pure devotion, my demons refuse to rest. After lying beside her, feeling her warmth and steady breathing, an irrational fear grips me – a sudden, poisonous suspicion that makes me lash out with accusations of future betrayal. I watch helplessly as tears well up in her eyes, my words cutting deeper than intended, and immediately regret floods my consciousness. The absurdity of my outburst slowly dawns on me, and exhaustion finally overtakes the paranoia, allowing me to drift into a troubled sleep. But she remains awake, I can feel it – her body tense beside me, her mind no doubt replaying my words, searching for what she might have done to deserve such distrust. She lies there, shouldering the weight of my baseless accusations, her self-reproach palpable in the darkness. The guilt of knowing I've caused her this pain mingles with the relief of having expressed my fears, creating a complex emotional cocktail that eventually lulls me into slumber, while she continues her silent vigil, her love unwavering despite my emotional turbulence.

paragraph1: Tonight he knocked on my door. He knocked though it wasn’t all the way closed. I was reading. He asked—not in a supplicating way of course but I would say with reasonable respect—if I could give him a hand in the office. The first special since Mrs. B. has been away. I asked what he wanted me to do. “Just more or less to keep her steady,” he said. “She’s young and she’s not used to it yet. Give your hands a good scrub, too. Use the soap in the bottle in the toilet downstairs.” The patient was lying flat on the examining table with a sheet over her from the waist down. The top part of her was fully dressed in a dark-blue buttoned-up cardigan and a white blouse with a lace-trimmed collar. These clothes lay loosely over her sharp collarbone and nearly flat chest. Her hair was black, pulled tightly back from her face and braided and pinned on top of her head. This prim and severe style made her neck look long and emphasized the regal bone structure of her white face, so that from a distance she could be taken for a woman of forty-five. Close up you could see that she was quite young, probably around twenty. Her pleated skirt was hung up on the back of the door. I could see the rim of white panties that she had thoughtfully hung underneath. She was shivering hard though the office wasn’t cold. “Now, Madeleine,” my father said. “The first thing is we’ve got to get your knees up.” I wondered if he knew her. Or did he just ask for a name and use whatever the woman gave him? “Easy,” he said. “Easy. Easy.” He got the stirrups in place and her feet into them. She was still wearing her loafers. Her knees shook so much in this new position that they clapped together. “You’ll have to hold steadier than that,” my father said. “You know, now, I can’t do my job unless you do yours. Do you want a blanket over you?” He said to me, “Get her a blanket. Off the bottom shelf there.” I arranged the blanket to cover the top part of Madeleine’s body. She didn’t look at me. Her teeth rattled. She clenched her mouth shut. “Now, just slide down this way a bit,” my father said. And to me, “Hold her knees. Get them apart. Just hold her easy.” I put my hands on the knobs of the girl’s knees and moved them apart as gently as I could. My father’s breathing filled the room with its busy unintelligible comments. I had to hold Madeleine’s knees quite firmly to keep them from jerking together. “Where’s that old woman?” she said. I said, “She’s at home. She had a fall. I’m here instead.” So she had been here before. “She’s rough,” she said. Her voice was matter-of-fact, almost a growl, not so nervous as I would have expected from the agitation of her body. My father had picked up a thin rod like a knitting needle. “Now. This is the hard part,” he said. He spoke in a conversational tone, milder I think than any I have ever heard from him. “And the more you tighten up the harder it will be. So just—easy. There. Easy. Good girl. Good girl.” I was trying to think of something to say that would ease her or distract her. I could see now what my father was doing. Laid out on a white cloth on the table beside him he had a series of rods, all of the same length but of a graduated thickness. These were what he would use, one after the other, to open and stretch the cervix. From my station behind the sheeted barrier beyond the girl’s knees, I could not see the actual, intimate progress of these instruments. But I could feel it, from the arriving waves of pain in her body that beat down the spasms of apprehension and actually made her quieter. Where are you from? Where did you go to school? Do you have a job? (I had noticed a wedding ring, but quite possibly they all wore wedding rings.) Do you have any brothers or sisters? Why should she want to answer any of that, even if she weren’t in pain? She sucked her breath back through her teeth and widened her eyes at the ceiling. “I know,” I said. “I know.” “Getting there,” my father said. “You’re a good girl. Good quiet girl. Won’t be long now.” I said, “I was going to paint this room, but I never got around to it. If you were going to paint it, what color would you choose?” “Hoh,” said Madeleine. “Hoh.” A sudden startled expulsion of breath. “Hoh. Hoh.” “Yellow?” I said. “I thought a light yellow. Or a light green?” By the time we got to the thickest rod Madeleine had thrust her head back into the flat cushion, stretching out her long neck, and stretching her mouth, too, lips wide and tight over her teeth. “Think of your favorite movie. What is your favorite movie?” A nurse said that to me, just as I reached the unbelievable interminable plateau of pain and was convinced that relief would not come, not this time. How could movies exist anymore in the world? Now I’d said the same thing to Madeleine and Madeleine’s eyes flicked over me with the coldly distracted expression of someone who sees that a human being can be about as much use as a stopped clock. paragraph2: As I stood in my father's office, I couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation as he asked for my assistance with a procedure. His usual assistant, Mrs. Barrie, was still recovering from an injury and was unavailable to help, so I had been called in as a last-minute replacement. I had watched my father perform countless medical procedures over the years, but I had never actually participated in one before. My father, a seasoned doctor with years of experience, seemed to sense my hesitation and gave me a reassuring nod as he began to explain the procedure. We were going to be performing a dilation and curettage, a relatively routine procedure, but one that still made me feel a bit uneasy. The patient, a young woman named Madeleine, was already lying on the examination table, her eyes fixed on the ceiling as she tried to calm her racing heart. My father handed me a pair of gloves and instructed me to hold Madeleine's knees steady, which I did, trying to offer her a reassuring smile as I did so.As the procedure began, I couldn't help but notice the look of distress on Madeleine's face. She was shivering and clenching her teeth, her eyes welling up with tears as my father worked. I tried to distract her with conversation, asking her about her interests and hobbies, but she was too caught up in her own pain and discomfort to respond. My father worked quickly and efficiently, his hands moving with a precision that came from years of practice, but even he couldn't hide the look of weariness that had been etched on his face for weeks. It had been a long and difficult few months, with Mrs. Barrie's injury and a heavier-than-usual patient load taking its toll on him. I couldn't help but feel a pang of guilt as I watched him work, knowing that I was planning to leave soon, to pursue my own dreams and ambitions, and wondering who would be there to help him when I was gone.Despite the difficulties of the procedure, my father worked tirelessly, his focus solely on Madeleine and her well-being. I watched in awe as he expertly navigated the complexities of the human body, his hands moving with a gentle precision that belied the difficulty of the task at hand. As the procedure drew to a close, Madeleine's distress began to subside, replaced by a look of relief and exhaustion. My father smiled wearily and patted her hand, offering her words of comfort and reassurance as he helped her sit up and begin the slow process of recovery. As I watched, I couldn't help but feel a sense of pride and admiration for my father, who had dedicated his life to helping others, often at great personal cost.As the procedure came to an end and Madeleine was helped off the examination table, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief wash over me. It had been a difficult and trying experience, but we had gotten through it, and Madeleine was on the road to recovery. My father smiled wearily and thanked me for my help, his eyes crinkling at the corners as he did so. I smiled back, feeling a sense of pride and accomplishment at having been able to assist him, even if it was just in a small way. As we cleaned up the examination room and prepared for the next patient, I couldn't help but think about the future, and the possibilities that lay ahead. I had always known that I wanted to leave, to pursue my own dreams and ambitions, but now I wasn't so sure. My father needed me, and I couldn't shake the feeling that I was abandoning him by leaving.

Tonight he knocked on my door. He knocked though it wasn’t all the way closed. I was reading. Use the soap in the bottle in the toilet downstairs.” The patient was lying flat on the examining table with a sheet over her from the waist down. The top part of her was fully dressed in a dark-blue buttoned-up cardigan and a white blouse with a lace-trimmed collar. These clothes lay loosely over her sharp collarbone and nearly flat chest. Her hair was black, pulled tightly back from her face and braided and pinned on top of her head. This prim and severe style made her neck look long and emphasized the regal bone structure of her white face, so that from a distance she could be taken for a woman of forty-five. Close up you could see that she was quite young, probably around twenty. Her pleated skirt was hung up on the back of the door. I could see the rim of white panties that she had thoughtfully hung underneath. She was shivering hard though the office wasn’t cold. “Now, Madeleine,” my father said. “The first thing is we’ve got to get your knees up.” I wondered if he knew her. Or did he just ask for a name and use whatever the woman gave him? “Easy,” he said. “Easy. Easy.” He got the stirrups in place and her feet into them. She was still wearing her loafers. paragraph1: “O.K.,” I said. “Sorry I yelled at you. Did I yell? I’m sorry. You’re our friend and you brought me my things and I appreciate it. You’re Ernest’s cousin and you’re our family.” She slipped behind me and her fingers darted into my armpits and she began to tickle me, at first lazily and then furiously. “Aren’t you? Aren’t you?” I tried to get free but I couldn’t. I went into spasms of suffering laughter and wriggled and cried out and begged her to stop. Which she did, when she had me quite helpless, and both of us were out of breath. “You’re the ticklishest person I ever met,” she said. I had to wait a long time for the bus, stamping my feet on the pavement. When I got to the college, I had missed my second class, as well as the first, and I was late for my work in the cafeteria. I changed into my green cotton uniform in the broom closet and pushed my mop of black hair (the worst hair in the world for showing up in food, the manager had warned me) under a cotton snood. I was supposed to get the sandwiches and salads out on the shelves before the doors opened for lunch, but now I had to do it with an impatient line of people watching me. I thought of what Beverly and Kay had said, about spoiling my chances with men, marking myself off in the wrong way. How scornful I’d been when they said it, but maybe they’d been right, after all. It appeared that, except in examinations, I got many things wrong. After I’d finished cleaning up the cafeteria tables, I changed back into my ordinary clothes and went to the college library to work on my essay. An underground tunnel fed from the Arts Building to the library, and on bulletin boards around the entrance to this tunnel were posted advertisements for movies and restaurants and used bicycles and typewriters, as well as notices for plays and concerts. The Music Department announced that a free recital of songs composed to fit the poems of the English country poets would be presented on a date that had now passed. I had seen this notice before, and did not have to look at it to be reminded of the names: Herrick, Housman, Tennyson. A few steps into the tunnel the lines began to assault me: On Wenlock Edge the wood’s in trouble. Had he known? Had he known that I would never think of those lines again without feeling the prickle of the upholstery on my bare haunches? The sticky prickly shame. A far greater shame it seemed now than at the time. He had got me, in spite of myself.
paragraph2: As I stood there, I couldn't help but feel a wave of regret wash over me, and I turned to her, my voice laced with apology, "I'm so sorry for yelling, I feel terrible about it." She smiled, her eyes sparkling with amusement, and I was reminded of the countless times we'd spent together, our bond strengthened by her being my cousin Ernest's partner, making her more than just a friend, but family. She playfully reached out and tickled me, sending me into a fit of laughter, my breath catching in my throat as I tried to squirm away. The moment was a much-needed respite from the chaos that had been my day so far. I had missed my morning classes, and to make matters worse, I was running late for my shift at the cafeteria. As I rushed to get ready, I couldn't shake off the feeling of inadequacy that had been plaguing me lately. I thought back to the advice Beverly and Kay had given me, about how I needed to be more confident, more outgoing, if I wanted to catch the eye of a guy. But every time I tried, I seemed to get it wrong, and I couldn't help but feel like I was stuck in some kind of rut. After a hectic shift at the cafeteria, I decided to head to the library to work on an essay that was due soon. As I walked through the tunnel that connected the buildings, I was bombarded by advertisements plastered on the walls - "Get fit with our gym membership", "Eat healthy with our meal plans" - the usual college fare. But one notice caught my eye, a recital announcement that brought back memories of a poem by Housman we had studied in class. The lines "That is the land of lost content, I see it shining plain, the happy highways where I went and cannot come again" echoed in my mind, and I felt a pang of shame wash over me. It was a memory I had tried to bury, but it still lingered, a reminder of a past experience that I would rather forget. I pushed the thoughts aside and focused on my essay, but the words of the poem lingered, a haunting reminder of the fragility of life and the choices we make.

paragraph1: Henry's new routine with Ellie had an unspoken gravity. The family was moving to Victoria, and Henry tended to be the most anxious of everyone. But when he began joining Ellie for her sunrise runs, his anxiety was mostly dispelled. And it was reflected in the others, a house of mirrors. Henry insisted on practicing yoga with Ellie in the evenings, as well, and he trusted her meticulous approach to packing and logistics more. Because this shift eased familial tension, Ella, the teenage daughter, began to speak her opinions more (or maybe she just spoke them in a less antagonistic manner). Even the family dog seemed to have a little more wag in it's tail. Remarkable how those small, consistent actions changed the household, turning a stressful move into a collective adventure.
paragraph2: Henry's new routine with Ellie had an unspoken gravity that subtly altered the texture of the family's preparations for their move to Victoria. When Henry began waking up early to join Ellie on her sunrise runs, his sense of serenity started to diffuse the anxiety that usually clouded such transitions. The regimented morning rhythm brought an unexpected stillness to the house, as if everyone else was unconsciously mirroring their calm. His insistence on practicing yoga with Ellie in the evenings also introduced a communal quiet time that felt necessary, even to those who didn’t participate. Moreover, Ellie’s meticulous planning habits started rubbing off on Henry, which translated into a more organized approach to packing and logistics. This shift minimized the usual chaos, easing tensions. Ella, the teenage daughter, began to open up more, perhaps influenced by the open communication she observed between her father and Ellie. Even the family dog seemed more at ease, sensing a harmony previously absent. Henry's burgeoning relationship with Ellie, colored by genuine affection and shared moments of tranquility, fortified their collective resilience. It wasn’t so much what they did; it was how those small, consistent actions reverberated through the household, turning a stressful move into a collective adventure.

paragraph1: The road Charles had instructed her to take dwindled from asphalt to gravel to mud, and she began to worry that her economy rental car wasn’t up to the task. Her phone reception shrank to a single bar. Then the road ended. Charles had said, “You will have to park and walk.” She stepped out into woods that smelled like fir and mushrooms, earthy and chilled, and hoped that the tiny clearing between two trees was the start of a trail. She crashed through it, the loudest thing around. Everything else was still, as if some kind of bad magic had blanketed the place. But, before she could get too worried, she saw Angela’s cottage, a normal and well-maintained A-frame with geraniums planted in window boxes. “It is best if you approach her gently,” Charles had said. Bridget didn’t knock on the door. She stood in front of the house, allowing herself to be seen. How she knew to do this she couldn’t have said. It was a calculation made on instinct. There was a flicker of movement at a window, and Bridget turned in a full circle, taking in the dense and quiet woods, the pine branches dripping, the surprisingly rapidly drifting clouds. Sam and the kids were visiting his parents this weekend; they had planned a cookout and a horror-movie marathon with the cousins. They would hardly think of her. Behind her, the reluctant opening of a wooden door. Angela stood silhouetted like a girl in a fairy tale. She was wearing jeans and a T-shirt and her blond hair was in a long braid, the way she used to wear it.
paragraph2: As Bridget followed the directions Charles had given her, she found herself navigating a road that grew increasingly treacherous, the asphalt giving way to mud that sucked at her rental car's tires like a living thing. She felt a growing sense of unease as she wondered if the vehicle was up to the task, her anxiety spiking as her phone lost reception and the road came to an abrupt end. But she recalled Charles's advice to park and walk from here, and so she reluctantly shut off the engine and stepped out into the stillness. The woods seemed to swallow her whole, the silence so profound it was almost eerie, but as she made her way down the winding path, a clearing emerged and with it, Angela's cozy A-frame cottage, its wooden slats weathered to a soft silver. Remembering Charles's suggestion to approach gently, Bridget elected not to knock, instead standing visibly in front of the house, taking in the tranquil surroundings and thinking about her family's various activities elsewhere - her parents' golf game, her siblings' beach vacation. The peacefulness was almost surreal, and it was into this serene tableau that Angela emerged, her long braid swinging behind her like a golden rope, her jeans and T-shirt a practical counterpoint to the whimsical, fairy tale quality that seemed to surround her like an aura. As she stood in the doorway, a gentle smile on her face, Bridget felt a sense of wonder wash over her, as if she had stumbled into a storybook world.

Her phone reception shrank to a single bar. Then the road ended. Charles had said, “You will have to park and walk.” She stepped out into woods that smelled like fir and mushrooms, earthy and chilled, and hoped that the tiny clearing between two trees was the start of a trail. She crashed through it, the loudest thing around. Everything else was still, as if some kind of bad magic had blanketed the place. But, before she could get too worried, she saw Angela’s cottage, a normal and well-maintained A-frame with geraniums planted in window boxes. “It is best if you approach her gently,” Charles had said. Bridget didn’t knock on the door. She stood in front of the house, allowing herself to be seen. How she knew to do this she couldn’t have said. It was a calculation made on instinct. There was a flicker of movement at a window, and Bridget turned in a full circle, taking in the dense and quiet woods, the pine branches dripping, the surprisingly rapidly drifting clouds. Sam and the kids were visiting his parents this weekend; they had planned a cookout and a horror-movie marathon with the cousins. They would hardly think of her. Behind her, the reluctant opening of a wooden door. Angela stood silhouetted like a girl in a fairy tale. She was wearing jeans and a T-shirt and her blond hair was in a long braid, the way she used to wear it.

Paragraph 2:
As Bridget followed the directions Charles had given her, she found herself navigating a road that grew increasingly treacherous, the asphalt giving way to mud that sucked at her rental car's tires like a living thing. She felt a growing sense of unease as she wondered if the vehicle was up to the task, her anxiety spiking as her phone lost reception and the road came to an abrupt end. But she recalled Charles's advice to park and walk from here, and so she reluctantly shut off the engine and stepped out into the stillness. The woods seemed to swallow her whole, the silence so profound it was almost eerie, but as she made her way down the winding path, a clearing emerged and with it, Angela's cozy A-frame cottage, its wooden slats weathered to a soft silver. Remembering Charles's suggestion to approach gently, Bridget elected not to knock, instead standing visibly in front of the house, taking in the tranquil surroundings and thinking about her family's various activities elsewhere - her parents' golf game, her siblings' beach vacation. The peacefulness was almost surreal, and it was into this serene tableau that Angela emerged, her long braid swinging behind her like a golden rope, her jeans and T-shirt a practical counterpoint to the whimsical, fairy tale quality that seemed to surround her like an aura. As she stood in the doorway, a gentle smile on her face, Bridget felt a sense of wonder wash over her, as if she had stumbled into a storybook world.

paragraph1: On a crisp autumn afternoon in Soulsville, the clinking of marbles echoed across the sun-stained pavement as a group of boys huddled close, their eyes glued to the small circle they'd drawn in chalk. Nearby, an old Dodge Caravan, it's once-gleaming paint now dulled by years of mud splatter and summer storms, idled with a low hum. Behind the wheel sat a pastor dressed in a pair of judge's robes that seemed two sizes too big. The van's muffler sputtered as the pastor watched the boys, his expression unreadable. It wasn’t usual to see him here in this outfit, local oratorical habits leaning more towards Sunday bests and worn gospel songs. The eldest boy, Marcus, noticed the pastor and faltered, a marble slipping from his grasp and careening into the creek bed below. The others followed his glance, their laughter fading into uncertain silence. The pastor stepped out, his robes trailing over the dirty rocks and sticks yet somehow eluding their catch, and approached the boys. He said nothing at first, just knelt and picked up the fallen marble, turning it over in his hand. "You know," he finally spoke, voice low and measured, "sometimes you don't need a gavel to lay down the law." He placed the marble gently back into Marcus's hand, gave a nod, and returned to his van.

As he drove off, the boys watched, puzzled but somehow reassured, until the lonely street noise filled the void he left behind.

paragraph1: Jamie trudged up the narrow staircase, his shoulders straining under the weight of two overstuffed duffel bags. The worn wooden steps creaked beneath his feet, echoing in the musty air. As he reached the first floor, he paused to catch his breath, eyeing the apartment door with it's gleaming new lock—a stark contrast to the peeling, garishly painted surface surrounding it. With a deep sigh, he fumbled for his keys and pushed the door open. The room beyond was a study in contradictions. A once-grand marble fireplace dominated one wall, it's elaborate carvings now chipped and stained. Tattered drapes hung limply from ornate curtain rods, their faded patterns barely discernible in the dim light. Scattered throughout the space were an assortment of mismatched furnishings and curios: a crystal chandelier missing half it's pendants, a threadbare chaise lounge draped with a silk shawl, and shelves lined with dusty porcelain figurines. Jamie couldn't shake the feeling that someone had deliberately curated this eclectic mix to create an illusion of faded opulence. As he set down his bags, he wondered about the previous tenants and what stories these walls might tell if they could speak.
paragraph2: Jamie trudged up the narrow staircase, his shoulders straining under two overstuffed duffel bags. The wooden steps creaked beneath his feet, echoing in the musty air. As he reached the first floor, he paused to catch his breath, eyeing the apartment door with it's gleaming new lock—a stark contrast to the peeling, garishly painted surface surrounding it. With a heaving sigh, he fumbled for the keys before finally pushing the door ajar. The room was a study in contradictions: a once-grand marble fireplace dominated one wall with it's chipped but elaborate carvings, and the window's tattered drapes were hung from ornate brass rods. The metal etchings were barely discernible in the dim light. Scattered throughout were mismatched furnishings and curios: a crystal chandelier missing half it's pendants, a threadbare chaise lounge draped with a silk shawl, and shelves lined with dusty porcelain figurines. Whoever came before, Jamie thought, must have deliberately curated the space to mimic a scene of faded opulence. He wondered about the previous tenants - how spectacular their dinner parties must have been, what joys the room could have witnessed - as he set down his bags.

paragraph1: After that, she bought a small icebox for the bedroom where she slept, though she continued to keep the larger items in the kitchen refrigerator. He bought a separate telephone, because he complained that she wasn’t giving him his messages from his “associates.” “I have never been a secretary for whores,” she said, watching him set up an answering machine next to the hide-a-bed couch where he slept. “Oh, don’t get me started bout whores. I’d say you wrote the damn book.” “It was dictated by you.” Their one child, Alonzo, lived with his wife and son in Baltimore. He had not been close to his parents for a long time, and he could not put the why of it into words for his wife. Their boy, Alonzo, Jr., who was twelve when his grandparents moved into Sunset, loved to visit them. Horace would unplug and put away his telephone when the boy visited. And Loneese and Horace would sleep together in the bedroom. She’d put a pillow between them in the double bed to remind herself not to roll toward him. Their grandson visited less and less as he moved into his teen-age years, and then, after he went away to college, in Ohio, he just called them every few weeks, on the phone they had had installed in the name of Horace and Loneese Perkins. In 1987, Loneese’s heart began the countdown to its last beat and she started spending more time at George Washington University Hospital than she did in the apartment. Horace never visited her. She died two years later. She woke up that last night in the hospital and went out into the hall and then to the nurses’ station but could not find a nurse anywhere to tell her where she was or why she was there. “Why do the patients have to run this place alone?” she said to the walls. She returned to her room and it came to her why she was there. It was nearing three in the morning, but she called her own telephone first, then she dialled Horace’s. He answered, but she never said a word. “Who’s this playin on my phone?” Horace kept asking. “Who’s this? I don’t allow no playin on my phone.” She hung up and lay down and said her prayers.
paragraph2: Loneese and Horace lived together, yet their lives had become a labyrinth of solitude, each navigating their own separate existence within the confines of their shared home. The chasm between them had grown so vast that it seemed insurmountable, a constant reminder of the love and connection they once shared, now lost to the passage of time. In a poignant manifestation of their estrangement, Loneese purchased a small icebox for her bedroom, a symbol of her desire for independence and self-sufficiency. Horace, fueled by a deep-seated distrust, acquired a separate telephone, a tacit acknowledgement of the breakdown in communication that had come to define their relationship. Their son, Alonzo, lived in Baltimore, a physical and emotional distance that seemed to mirror the gulf between his parents. Though his son, Alonzo Jr., had once been a frequent visitor to his grandparents' home, as he grew older, his visits became increasingly sporadic, leaving Loneese and Horace to confront the isolation that had taken hold of their lives. In 1987, Loneese's health began to decline, necessitating frequent hospital stays that only served to underscore the fragility of her existence. As the years ticked by, her condition continued to deteriorate, until finally, in 1989, she succumbed to her illness. On her final night, feeling disoriented and alone in the sterile hospital environment, Loneese reached out to Horace in a poignant, wordless phone call, a desperate attempt to reconnect with the man she had shared her life with. Though Horace was left bewildered by the silence on the other end of the line, Loneese, having made her peace, returned to her room, said her prayers, and quietly slipped away, leaving behind a legacy of love, loss, and longing.

paragraph1: Louisa doubted her aunt felt this way. Until she and her mother had moved here, Louisa had never heard of this aunt or uncle—her mother’s brother, whom Louisa was now meant to pretend she’d known about her whole life. Her whole ten years of life, during which she had never heard their names, or seen their photos, or received a card or a gift from them on her birthday, had never answered the telephone to hear either one of them ask for her mother or her father. Now she lived in their house and drank orange juice with them staring at her. They behaved toward her the way all adults had since her father had died: with a combination of hearty attention and squeamish discomfort. “Brick-ner, like this ugly brick building we’re in,” the man had added heartily. “That’s how you can remember! But my first name is Jerry, and I’d like you to just call me that. Can I call you Louisa?” “So I don’t need to remember,” she said. “What’s that?” He pointed his grin at her. “What did you say?” “I said I don’t need to remember ‘Brickner, like this ugly brick building,’ because you said I should just call you Jerry.” The man reared back and raised his eyebrows. “Let me guess—you’re a very smart girl.” “At least smart enough to be in fifth grade.” “Oh, I’ll bet. Oh, I’m sure there’s no doubt about that,” “Jerry” blathered, not listening, which was how she had understood that the appointment was not about her grade level. The room was full of admittedly interesting things: art supplies and those faceless wooden figures meant for posing, as well as actual dolls of different sorts, ranging from the sloppy-floppy Raggedy Ann style to the “realistic infant” style, with a hard plastic head, hands, and feet and a queasily soft trunk, arms, and legs, to wild-haired Barbies and those soldier Barbies for boys, the G.I. Joes. There was an intriguing if off-kilter doll house, the kind that was meant to be played with and not just admired, with cluttered furnishings in slightly different sizes, as if there had been disagreement about which scale to use. Louisa knew about scale, about one foot = one inch. Her father had made her a doll house the year she turned six. First grade had been the year of her passion for a store at the mall called It’s a Small World, which sold elaborate miniature homes that she would gaze into, mesmerized, with the peculiar sensation of leaving her body and slipping in amid those wee wonderful things, things she lacked the words for and so had to learn one by one—fireplace irons and grandfather clocks and hat stands and claw-footed armoires.
paragraph2: Perched on the edge of her new bed, Louisa traced her fingers along the unfamiliar quilt pattern while stealing glances at the art supplies scattered across the wooden desk by the window, their presence both inviting and somehow intrusive in this strange space she was expected to call home. The death of her father three weeks ago had thrust her into a world populated by relatives she'd never known existed – her Aunt Marie and Uncle Jerry Brickner – whose sudden appearance in her life felt like characters stepping out of a book she'd never meant to read. Uncle Jerry, with his forced smiles and awkward attempts at conversation over breakfast, seemed to be trying too hard to bridge a gap that felt more like a chasm to Louisa, his questions about her school preferences and favorite foods landing like pebbles tossed into a deep well, echoing but never quite reaching the bottom. The room they'd prepared for her was thoughtfully arranged, she had to admit, with watercolors, colored pencils, and pristine sketchbooks laid out as if in anticipation of an artist's touch, but it was the collection of dolls on the shelf that truly caught her attention. Their tiny, perfect features and miniature clothes transported her back to the dollhouse her father had crafted for her sixth birthday – a labor of love that had taken him months to complete, with its hand-painted walls and tiny furniture he'd carved himself. She remembered how she'd spent countless hours arranging and rearranging the diminutive rooms, creating elaborate stories for the tiny family that lived there, each piece of furniture holding its own significance in her carefully constructed world. That dollhouse had been her sanctuary, a place where she could control every aspect of life in a way that real life never allowed, and now, sitting in this room filled with well-meaning strangers' attempts to make her feel at home, she longed for that sense of control again. The art supplies and dolls, while generous gestures from her aunt and uncle, served as bittersweet reminders of a life she'd lost, a life where her father's presence had made even the smallest spaces feel like home. Now, surrounded by these new possessions in this unfamiliar room, Louisa felt more than ever like a doll herself, placed carefully in a new house but somehow not quite belonging to the scene around her.

paragraph1: Anthony leaned against the counter, his eyes squinting as he gazed out the window at the quiet street. "You know, people always ask about the days we're closed," he said, his voice low and conversational. "They think it's some kind of trick, like we're hiding something. But the truth is, we just need a break." He paused, his fingers drumming a slow rhythm on the counter. "I've seen people wait outside on those days, thinking we'll magically open up just for them. But it's not about that. It's about us, the owners, needing a moment to recharge." He smiled wryly. "We're not machines, you know. We get tired too." Anthony's gaze drifted back to the present, his eyes locking onto mine. "I've seen them, sitting on the bench outside, checking their watches every five minutes. They think we're just playing some kind of game, but really, we're just living our lives." His voice dropped to a whisper. "Sometimes, I wonder what they're waiting for. Is it really just a ribbon, or is it something more?" The question hung in the air, a subtle challenge to the notion that people only came to the shop for it's wares.
paragraph2: Anthony leaned against the counter, eyes squinting at the quiet street. "You know, people always ask about the days we're closed," he said, voice low and conversational. "They think it's some kind of trick, like we're hiding something. But truth is, we just need a break." His drumming fingers filled the pause with a slow, deliberate rhythm. "I've seen people wait outside, thinking we'll magically open up just for them. But it's not about that. It's about us, the owners, needing a moment to recharge." He smiled wryly. "We're not machines, you know." Anthony's gaze drifted back to the scene before him. His beady, focused eyes locked onto my face. "They sit on that bench outside, checking their watches every five minutes. Maybe they think it's some kind of game, but really, we're just living our lives." He hesitated, the tendons in his neck tensing before lowering his voice even further, as if what he said next was precious or volatile. "Do you know what they're waiting for? I have my own guess." The question hung in the air, silently challenging the assumption that people only came to the shop for it's wares.

They think we're just playing some kind of game, but really, we're just living our lives." His voice dropped to a whisper. "Sometimes, I wonder what they're waiting for. paragraph1: As they sat together in the quiet, intimate setting, Jack couldn't help but feel a mix of excitement and nervousness. He had spent hours preparing for this moment, pouring his heart and soul into a drawing he had created in a library book, hoping to impress Della with his artistic skills. His father's words of caution echoed in his mind, acknowledging Jack's cleverness while also expressing doubt about his potential. Despite this, Jack was determined to make a good impression, and he had taken extra care to dress nicely, donning a new tie that he hoped would catch Della's eye. Della, on the other hand, seemed effortlessly beautiful, her new hat perfectly framing her face as she playfully mentioned it to Jack. As they conversed, Jack found himself struggling to find the right words, his mind racing with thoughts of how to impress Della while also being genuine. He made a misstep, asking her about a cemetery, and immediately regretted it, feeling a pang of embarrassment. Della, however, seemed to take it in stride, and Jack was relieved when she steered the conversation in a different direction. Despite the awkwardness, Jack couldn't help but feel drawn to Della, his love for her growing with each passing moment. As he gazed at her, he felt his heart swell with emotion, and he knew that he would do anything to make her happy. Little did he know, Della was also taking notice of him, her eyes sparkling with amusement as she watched him fumble through their conversation.
paragraph2: They had the place almost to themselves. They could talk in the ordinary way of conversation, at least till later, when the piano started up and the crowd came. He had spent days in the library thinking about what he would say to her, drawing the map and the heavenly host on the flyleaf of a big travel book that had not been checked out for years, since before the war, and then only twice. The page pulled loose from its binding very cleanly. Whenever his father had found one of his drawings, he’d say, “He’s the clever one. He’s going to surprise us all one day.” He heard his mother say once, “I guess you’re never going to give up on him.” His father seemed to consider, and then he said, “I’m just not sure there would be any point in it.” But the angels went well—they were fat and buoyant, cumulous. Della had to like them, he thought. And she did. Cleverness has a special piquancy when it blooms out of the fraying sleeve of failure. That was his experience, the magic trick he could usually play when he had to. And here she was. He said, “New tie,” when he realized he was smoothing it. She smiled and said, “New hat.” He was in love with her. That did it. That hat brought out glints of rose in the warm dark of her skin. Women know that kind of thing. She, Della, wanted him, Jack, to see that particular loveliness in her. These thoughts interfered considerably with the efforts at conversation he should have been making. She said, “That bridge you talk about really is handsome. Those huge stones. The walls of Troy must have looked like that.” “Yes. Herod’s temple.” Then he said, “Have you ever been to Bellefontaine?” “The white cemetery? Why, no. I haven’t had much occasion.” Of course. What a stupid question.

paragraph1: She leaned forward, eager to connect with her sons Jerome and Billy about their animal encounters, her voice carrying a mix of maternal curiosity and personal nostalgia. As she inquired about birds and horses, memories of her own childhood fascination with equines surfaced - though she had never actually ridden or tended to one. The missing notebook from her youth, filled with horse-related musings, briefly crossed her mind as she waited for her boys' responses. Jerome's politeness was evident but lacking genuine interest, his replies measured and distant, while Billy's face lit up as he described the anticipation he felt around the animals. She caught herself forcing a smile, aware of its artificiality, as the conversation about the creatures and the deteriorating structure gradually faded into silence. The moment highlighted the delicate balance between her desire to share in her children's experiences and the reality that their interests might diverge from her own childhood passions, creating a subtle undercurrent of disconnection beneath the surface of their exchange.
paragraph2: She tried to get them to describe the animals. Did the boys speak to them or touch them? Were there birds? There were birds, apparently, but very small ones. Were there horses there? When she was a child, she wanted to be a horse. She had a treasured collection of horses—metal, ceramic, plastic, wood. She had never ridden a horse or cared for one, but she had kept pictures of them and much commentary concerning them in a large black notebook for many years, though the book had been missing for just as long. “Maybe someone’s using it as a barn,” she said. “A corral.” Her son regarded her with disappointment. “Maybe. Not really,” Jerome said politely. “When you’re there, you know that something is going to happen any moment and you wait with them so you can be there when it happens,” Billy said. “You haven’t been invited to stay but you’re welcome to stay. It’s just about to happen.” “But what?” she asked, smiling. “And why?” She remembers smiling. She can feel it still on her lips, the falsity and carelessness of it. Then they spoke no further of the ruined little building and the animals.

paragraph1: In the small town of Farnham, whispers began to replace news, each retelling more exaggerated than the last. It started with murmurs about the old mill's shadowy figures at night, then shifted to tales of an unseen sickness. Residents stopped trusting one another, avoiding eye contact and skipping town meetings. The main road, once busy with cars heading to the city, became a sparse, cracked stretch. Fewer vehicles meant fewer supplies, and the corner store shelves grew barer each week. Instead of waiting for scarce deliveries, the town turned inward. Families gathered to jar whatever produce they could salvage from late harvests, reinforce aging window frames, and sort through old woolens. The air was heavy with the scent of wood smoke and the distant promise of snow. As autumn winds blustered, they spoke of nothing but the coming cold, working side by side but each lost in their own silences, haunted by the weight of uncertainty and the stories that drifted like the falling leaves.
paragraph2: In the small town of Farnham, whispers began to replace printed news, with each transmission more exaggerated than the last. Originally harmless murmurs about the old mill's shadowy figures at night shifted to suspicions of an unseen sickness. Residents stopped trusting one another, avoiding eye contact and skipping town meetings. The main road, once busy with cars heading to the city, became a sparse, cracked stretch. Fewer vehicles meant fewer supplies, and the corner store shelves grew barer each week. Instead of waiting for deliveries which never came, the residents turned toward self-sufficiency. Families gathered to jar whatever produce they could salvage from late harvests, reinforce rotting window frames, and sort through old woolens. The town was enveloped in the sweetness of wood smoke and the distant promise of snow. As autumn winds crept into town, conversations featured only the coming cold; the residents worked side by side, often wordlessly. The stories that had pervaded every household now left residual silence, haunted by uncertainty.

paragraph1: Anton stood before Hadley with a peculiar mix of triumph and anxiety, his large, chafed hands cradling a meticulously carved pumpkin head that, moments before, had served as his makeshift mask. The two-thirds shell, thoroughly gutted and expertly carved, seemed to glow with an almost ethereal quality in the ambient light, though Hadley's barely concealed exasperation threatened to dim its charm. Despite detecting her less-than-enthusiastic response, Anton maintained his cheerful disposition, his big-knuckled fingers nervously adjusting the position of his offering. Hadley's surprise was evident, not merely at the unexpected gesture but at its timing – Halloween was still some distance away – and her thoughts drifted momentarily to her late husband, creating an unspoken comparison with the various men who had since crossed her threshold. Anton's demeanor, characterized by a curious blend of shy aggression and obvious anticipation, manifested in his reddened face and slightly slouched posture as he extended the pumpkin toward her. When their hands briefly touched during the exchange, the contact seemed to amplify Anton's already quickened breathing, his chest rising and falling with an urgency that betrayed his nervous state. His physical awkwardness, combined with his determined effort to appear composed, spoke volumes about his unvoiced intentions, creating a moment charged with both possibility and uncertainty. Through it all, the carved pumpkin served as both a bridge and a barrier between them, its hollow grin a silent witness to this delicate dance of tentative courtship.
paragraph2: In a kind of anxious triumph, sensing his hostess’s exasperation yet determined not to acknowledge it, Anton swung the lurid pumpkin head down from his shoulders, holding it in his chafed-looking, big-knuckled hands. Now Hadley could see that the pumpkin was only two-thirds of a shell. It had been gutted and carved and its back part cut away—the back of what would be, in a human, the cranium. So the uncanny pumpkin head was a kind of pumpkin mask set on Anton’s shoulders and held in place by hand. Yet it was so lifelike; as the scarecrow figure had lurched up the walk in her direction, the face had appeared alive. “Is good? Is—surprise? ‘Happy Halloween’ is right?” Was it Halloween? Hadley was sure it was not. October 31st wasn’t for several more days. “Is for you, Hedley. To set here.” He was red-faced now and smiling in a shyly aggressive manner. On his angular face and in the stiff, wiry hair that receded sharply from his forehead were bits of pumpkin flesh and seeds, at which Anton wiped, surreptitiously, the way a boy might wipe at his runny nose. Hadley thought, If he kisses me, he will smell of pumpkin. Her husband had died and abandoned her. Now other men would drop by the house. Anton presented Hadley with the misshapen pumpkin. The damned thing must have weighed fifteen pounds. It almost slipped from her hands. Hadley thought it would have served Anton Kruppev right if she’d dropped the pumpkin and it had smashed on the brick. No doubt, he’d have offered to clean it up. “Anton, thank you! This is very. . . ” Their hands brushed together. Anton was standing close beside her. He was several inches taller than Hadley, though his posture was slouched, his back prematurely rounded. Perhaps there was something wrong with his spine. And he breathed quickly, audibly, as if he’d been running. Or as if he’d been about to declare something and then thought better of it.

paragraph1: As he stepped into the vast, fluorescent-lit expanse of the Wal-Mart, the man felt a sense of disorientation wash over him. The sheer scale of the store seemed to stretch on forever, a boundless sea of consumerism that threatened to engulf him whole. Everywhere he looked, people of all ages and backgrounds milled about, their faces a blur as they went about their shopping. Families with rambunctious children, individuals navigating the aisles in wheelchairs, and harried parents clutching lists and coupons all swirled together in a kaleidoscope of humanity. The man, however, was on a singular mission: to find the perfect greeting card for Louise. He knew it was a daunting task, as Louise had a keen eye for the nuances of sentiment and aesthetics, and he worried that his choice would inevitably fall short. As he scanned the rows of cards, he couldn't help but feel a sense of disconnection from the process. Most of the cards seemed to cater to specific occasions - birthdays, anniversaries, graduations - leaving little room for genuine personal expression. He noted, too, the cards featuring idealized depictions of black people, their airbrushed smiles and sanitized settings a far cry from the vibrant diversity of the shoppers surrounding him. The disconnect between the commercialized sentimentality of the cards and the messy, beautiful chaos of real life seemed to yawn open like a chasm, leaving the man feeling lost and uncertain. As he stood there, frozen in indecision, the Wal-Mart's endless sprawl seemed to stretch out before him like a void, a reminder of the impersonal, cookie-cutter nature of the world he inhabited.
paragraph2: The general feeling inside the great merchandise biosphere, stretching in hazy light almost, but not quite, farther than you could see, was of people—citizens, families, shoppers, people in wheelchairs, people in motorized carts, children wandering on their own—all staying on, making an afternoon of Wal-Mart, taking their leisure as if this were home, letting Wal-Mart be what their day offered them. He asked the merchandise checker at the entrance where the greeting cards could be found and went straight there—to a long single aisle between the party supplies and the discount luggage. There was no reason to make a difficult assignment of this. The one he chose wouldn’t please Louise anyway. Left to herself, she would spend an hour scrutinizing everything, and then would find the exactly perfect card. Whereas he would never even see the correct one if he stayed here in the frigid, chlorinated air till midnight—which was possible to do. Most of the cards in the tiers were for regular, identifiable occasions—graduation, birthday, anniversary, confirmation, sympathy over a mother’s death, illness, events requiring humor. There were a lot of these occasions. But there were no blank cards except two with sex themes—one that somebody had already written on and drawn a picture of a large, smiling penis with a mustache. Everything else required adaptation and compromise. You fitted your need for human expression into a category somebody else had thought up in advance and found words for, and then you bought the card, signed it, sealed it up, and tried to think it was just right. There were lots of cards on which the people depicted were black people, although they were mostly tan-colored, clean-cut black people, men wearing chinos and oxford-cloth shirts, women smiling out at fields of dazzling spring flowers, wearing Peter Pan blouses and gold wedding bands, and children looking like they’d done very well on their science projects and were ready for Harvard a year early. They weren’t much like the people in Wal-Mart today.
