paragraph1: Audio: Curtis Sittenfeld reads. Irene’s medium, the one in which she has exhibited at galleries, is textiles, but for “Interrogating Graham/Pence” she decides to use Polaroid photos and off-white Tintoretto paper. Even though the questions will be the same for all the men, she handwrites them in black ink, because the contrast of her consistent handwriting with the men’s varied handwriting will create a dialogue in which she is established as the interrogator. Before her lunch with Eddie Walsh, she writes: Date Name Age Profession When, prior to lunch today, did you last spend time alone with a woman who is not your wife? Are you aware of the Modesto Manifesto, also known as the Billy Graham Rule, also known as the Mike Pence Rule? If so, what is your opinion of this rule? When I invited you to lunch, what was your reaction? She and Eddie are meeting at a Thai restaurant downtown. Unless it feels organically relevant, she plans to make no mention of the project until after the arrival of the check, which she will pay. Curtis Sittenfeld on politics and ambiguity. Almost thirty years ago, as undergraduates at the U, Irene and Eddie both took Introduction to Ceramics. The studio featured two potter’s wheels and was open until midnight, and Irene and Eddie spent many more hours there than was necessary—not because of each other but because of the wheels. Over time, as they chatted intermittently, it emerged that both of them would have preferred majoring in studio art—Irene’s major was product design and Eddie’s was economics—and that neither of them had parents who would have been O.K. with this. Eddie had grown up on a farm in southwest Minnesota, and Irene was a dentist’s daughter from St. Cloud. In the ceramics studio in 1988, a white-paint-splattered radio and cassette player sat on the sill of the huge window overlooking Twenty-first Avenue, and stuck inside the cassette slot was Cat Stevens’s “Greatest Hits,” turned to side two. Though every so often a person more foolish or enterprising than Irene would attempt without success to remove it, she never tired of the songs. She and Eddie both took more ceramics courses. After graduation, they lived in group houses two blocks apart in the Kingfield neighborhood and regularly saw each other at parties. Eddie was affable, funny, and good-looking, and always had a serious girlfriend (the third of whom, a woman named Fara, he married). Following college, Irene was hired in product development at Target and Eddie by an investment firm. Irene was twenty-five when she married Peter; they moved to Ann Arbor for him to attend medical school, then to Pittsburgh for his orthopedic-surgery residency, then to San Francisco for his fellowship. By the time they moved back to Minnesota, she was thirty-five and the mother of seven-year-old twin boys. Eddie had started his own investment firm, and he and Fara had a daughter and a son and lived in a gigantic house out on Lake Minnetonka; apparently, though still affable, he had become enormously rich and successful.
paragraph2: Irene stood in her studio, surrounded by swaths of colorful textiles that normally dominated her artistic endeavors, but on this day, her attention was focused on a new medium - Polaroid photos and Tintoretto paper. Her latest project, "Interrogating Graham/Pence," had been percolating in her mind for months, and she was eager to share it with an old acquaintance, Eddie Walsh, over lunch at a nearby Thai restaurant. As she carefully placed a few of the Polaroids on the paper, she thought back to their time as undergraduates, when they had bonded over late nights spent covered in clay and glaze in their ceramics class. Irene had always been drawn to Eddie's charismatic personality and sharp wit, and though they had lost touch after graduation, she had kept tabs on his successful career in investment. Meanwhile, Irene had taken a more circuitous route, initially pursuing a career in product development before eventually returning to her artistic roots. As she packed up her bag with the handwritten questions she planned to ask Eddie, she couldn't help but think about the divergent paths their lives had taken - Eddie, with his high-powered job and beautiful family, and Irene, with her more unconventional career choices and own family, which included two rambunctious kids and a loving partner. Despite their differing trajectories, Irene was excited to reconnect with Eddie and hear his thoughts on the Modesto Manifesto, also known as the Billy Graham Rule or the Mike Pence Rule, which was the central theme of her project. She had carefully crafted a series of questions, ranging from the personal to the philosophical, and was eager to hear Eddie's responses, but she planned to wait until after they had eaten to broach the subject. As she headed out the door, Irene felt a sense of anticipation building - what would Eddie think of her project, and how would he respond to her probing questions? She pushed the thoughts aside, focusing instead on the prospect of a delicious meal and some much-needed catch-up time with an old friend. The Thai restaurant was already bustling with activity when Irene arrived, and she spotted Eddie chatting with the hostess, his trademark smile lighting up the room. As they hugged hello, Irene felt a sense of ease wash over her - despite the years that had passed, their connection remained strong, and she knew that their conversation would be just as engaging as it had been all those years ago in ceramics class. For now, though, they would just enjoy each other's company, savoring the flavors of their meal and the warmth of their reunion, before diving into the more serious topics that Irene had in store.

paragraph1: As I sit here, surrounded by the quiet chaos of my home, I'm reminded of the intricate web of relationships that has become my life. My partner, Connie, is pregnant, and I couldn't be more thrilled - or so I thought, until our neighbor, Allison, announced she was also expecting. The irony isn't lost on Connie, who finds the situation endlessly amusing, often making lighthearted comments about Allison's growing belly, completely unaware of the complicated history between us. I try to laugh along with her, but it's a forced smile, a desperate attempt to conceal the turmoil brewing inside me. You see, I've known Allison for a while, and our relationship has always been... complicated. When she first told me she was considering having a child, I tried to dissuade her, citing all the reasons why it wasn't the right time, but she was resolute. She had her reasons, personal and deeply rooted, and I couldn't sway her, no matter how hard I tried. Now, as I watch her waddle around her yard, a constant reminder of my own impending fatherhood, I'm forced to confront the consequences of my actions. It's days like today, when I'm working from home, that I get lost in my thoughts. I spent the morning deeply engrossed in my work, the hours ticking by in a blur, until my bladder finally protested, forcing me to take a break. As I stood in the bathroom, staring blankly out the window, I noticed a commotion on my lawn - the Cherry Pit, a rambunctious little dog with a penchant for trouble, was causing a scene. My heart sank as I watched it dig up the grass, its antics transporting me back to the events that led us to this point. It was the Cherry Pit, after all, that had brought Allison and me together, our shared concern for its well-being sparking a connection that would eventually lead to... well, to this. I sighed, feeling the weight of my secrets bearing down on me, and wondered how I'd managed to get myself into this mess. As I stood there, frozen in thought, the Cherry Pit looked up, its big brown eyes meeting mine, and for a moment, I felt like it was the only one who truly understood the complexity of my situation.
paragraph2: Fast-forward seven and a half months. I am living in a house with a pregnant woman next door to a house in which there is another pregnant woman. Connie seems to find this amusing, never suspecting the truth of the matter. We’ll glance up from the porch and see Allison emerging heavily from her car with an armload of groceries, and Connie will say things like “I hope she doesn’t have to pee every five minutes the way I do” and “She won’t say who the father is—I just hope it’s not that a-hole from Animal Control, what was his name?” This is problematic on a number of levels. I play dumb, of course—what else can I do? “Maybe she went to GenLab,” I say. “Her? You’re kidding me, right? I mean, look at that string of jerks she keeps dating. If you want to know the truth, she’s lower-class, Roy, and I’m sorry to have to say it—” I’m not about to argue the point. The fact is I tried everything I could to talk Allison out of going through with this—finally, to my shame, falling back on the same argument about the whole Übermensch-Untermensch dynamic that Connie used on me—but Allison merely gave me a bitter smile and said, “I trust your genes, Roy. You don’t have to be involved. I just want to do this, that’s all. For myself. And for nature. You believe in nature, don’t you?” You don’t have to be involved. But I was involved, though we’d had sex only the one time (or two, actually, counting the night I brought her the pupkit), and if she had a boy and he looked like me and grew up right next door playing with our daughter, how involved would that be? So there comes a day, sometime during that eighth month, a Tuesday, when I’m working at home and Connie’s at the office, and I’m so focussed on the problem at hand that I keep putting off my bathroom break until the morning’s nearly gone. That’s the way it always is when I’m deeply engaged with a problem, a kind of mind-body separation, but finally the body’s needs prevail and I push myself up from my desk to go down the hall to the bathroom. I’m standing there, in mid-flow, when I become aware of the sound of a dog barking on the front lawn and I shift my torso ever so slightly so that I can glance out the window and see what the ruckus is all about. It’s the red dog, the Cherry Pit that set all this in motion, and it’s tearing around on my hybrid lawn, chasing something.

paragraph1: Kit and Rafe's descent was imperceptible at first. Their shared causes—environmental activism, social justice—once bound them tightly, but small disagreements over tactics grew into ideological chasms. Kit's pragmatism clashed with Rafe's increasing radicalism. They began to see each other as hindrances rather than partners. Resentment crept in, fed by late nights and mounting frustrations. Their home, once a haven of shared dreams, became a battleground of unspoken grievances. In public, they maintained a united front, their performance of solidarity a bitter irony. Behind closed doors, they had become experts in wielding their intimate knowledge as weapons, each barb carefully aimed at the other's vulnerabilities. At night, they wrote sprawling diatribes about one another, tucking them away in a folder to be revealed at the moment the other finally made a name for themselves. A fact which, in perhaps a final bout of tenderness, they both felt inevitable.
paragraph2: Kit and Rafe's descent from passionate allies to bitter adversaries was a gradual erosion, imperceptible at first. Their shared causes—environmental activism, social justice—once bound them tightly, but over time became wedges driving them apart. Small disagreements over tactics grew into ideological chasms. Kit's pragmatism clashed with Rafe's increasing radicalism. They began to see each other as hindrances rather than partners. Resentment crept in, fed by late nights and mounting frustrations. Their home, once a haven of shared dreams, became a battleground of unspoken grievances. They clung to their anger, finding a perverse comfort in mutual antipathy. It was easier than admitting defeat, easier than walking away from years of shared history. In public, they maintained a united front, their performance of solidarity a bitter irony. Behind closed doors, silence reigned, punctuated by caustic remarks and cold shoulders. They had become experts in wielding their intimate knowledge as weapons, each barb carefully aimed at the other's vulnerabilities. In the end, their hatred was the only thing they still shared completely, the last vestige of their once-passionate connection.

paragraph1: No. And then, feeling sure that it will cause no trouble—why would it?—Flavia volunteers information about the supposed talking-monkey movie. Veronica looks grim. And Flavia gets the distinct sensation that their talk has rounded a corner. She is glad that she kept Roscoe’s exhortations to the dead Bill to herself. Interactions with Roscoe go on as before. He is a man of whims, and nobody knows this better than Flavia. Walks, exercise (or not), the constantly blaring TV (because Roscoe’s hearing is another diminishment in his life)—Roscoe is the master of his days. What he says always, always goes. Even the infrequent bathing, for which he turns down Flavia’s help. Even when she tells him, There’s nothing I haven’t seen before. Even the undriven car, sitting in the garage. It’s there because there is a property upstate, what Roscoe calls “the cottage” and Veronica “the country house.” The few times a drive there is proposed, there is little energy in the idea. And Flavia understands that Roscoe is simply reminding himself that, even at his advanced age, he still has choices in his life—that his days as a dashing inventor have bought for him this atypical American fate. And then, one day and without any warning, Roscoe refuses to engage with Flavia. Not answering her questions about his sleep, about whether he is ready for a walk, or some exercise. Even when the price of keeping his mouth shut is being served a lunch that he doesn’t want—in this case, reheated minestrone soup—he will not speak. Flavia tells herself it’s nothing personal. This, too, is part of a patient’s deterioration. His pointed silence is repeated on her next visit.
paragraph2: As Flavia conversed with Roscoe and Veronica, she couldn't help but share a tidbit of information about a supposed talking-monkey movie, which she had come across earlier. However, upon noticing Veronica's grim expression, Flavia immediately sensed a shift in the conversation and was relieved that she hadn't shared Roscoe's exhortations to the deceased Bill, which would have undoubtedly led to a more somber tone. Roscoe, a whimsical man with a penchant for controlling his daily activities, was struggling to cope with his hearing issues, which necessitated a strict routine of walks, exercise, and watching TV with subtitles. Despite Flavia's offers to assist him with bathing, Roscoe insisted on maintaining his independence, a trait that was both admirable and frustrating. The conversation also touched on Roscoe's reluctance to visit a property upstate, which he referred to as "the farm," much to Veronica's chagrin, who instead called it "the country house." As the days went by, Roscoe's engagement with Flavia began to wane, and he eventually stopped responding to her questions or expressing his preferences, even when it resulted in an unwanted lunch. Flavia rationalized his silence as a natural part of his deterioration, a trend that continued during her subsequent visits, leaving her to wonder about the complexities of Roscoe's character and the intricacies of his relationships with those around him. As she observed his gradual withdrawal, Flavia couldn't help but feel a sense of sadness and loss, knowing that the Roscoe she once knew was slowly slipping away.

paragraph1: Quinn lived at the periphery of chaos. She managed this chaotic force through the quiet precision of list-making, a ritual that gave shape to her days. Her notebook, filled with numbered tasks and bullet points, became a bulwark against downward spirals of uncertainty. Each item she crossed off provided a small but significant sense of control. In the spaces between words, she found order, as though taming chaos into rows of legible script. Organizational thinking wasn't a sterile exercise but an act of creative rebellion, a way to filter out the noise. It allowed her to carve out moments for writing, imbuing her stories with a clarity her daily life often lacked. It wasn't a complicated system. But it helped her move forward, where previously each day led confusingly into fog. Creating this basic structure for herself, deciding certain things in advance, helped her to feel that she actually had more choice, not less.
paragraph2: Quinn’s world teetered on the brink of disarray each morning, threatening to engulf her. She managed this relentless tide through the quiet precision of list-making, a ritual that gave shape to her days. Her notebook, filled with numbered tasks and bullet points, became a bulwark against downward spirals of uncertainty. Each item she crossed off provided a small but significant sense of control. In the spaces between words, she found order, as though taming chaos into rows of legible script. Organizational thinking wasn't a sterile exercise but an act of creative rebellion, a way to filter out the noise. It allowed her to carve out moments for writing, imbuing her stories with a clarity her daily life often lacked. This system, deceptively simple, was her compass in a landscape where the path forward frequently vanished into fog. text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Quinn lived at the periphery of chaos. She managed this chaotic force through the quiet precision of list-making, a ritual that gave shape to her days. Her notebook, filled with numbered tasks and bullet points, became a bulwark against downward spirals of uncertainty. Each item she crossed off provided a small but significant sense of control. In the spaces between words, she found order, as though taming chaos into rows of legible script. Organizational thinking wasn't a sterile exercise but an act of creative rebellion, a way to filter out the noise. It allowed her to carve out moments for writing, imbuing her stories with a clarity her daily life often lacked. It wasn't a complicated system. But it helped her move forward, where previously each day led confusingly into fog. Creating this basic structure for herself, deciding certain things in advance, helped her to feel that she actually had more choice, not less.

paragraph1: Loneliness is endemic to writing, even while the heart of writing is connection. Writers come from all sorts of backgrounds yet they share this weird compulsion toward naming, toward language. Writers use the same cracked ship to reach different equidistant shores. The drive comes from trauma, for some, and from a pleasure in entertainment or a love of wisdom for others. You can tell when someone has fought with their sentences like a stray dog. The purpose, then, isn’t singular. It’s this blurry mix of personal and collective ambition. And maybe that’s why readers resonate with well-wrought stories—they feel the echoes of that shared drive, and it speaks to their own. So, while our backgrounds might diverge wildly, this shared path of relentless crafting somehow unites us, quietly pushing each of us to keep writing, to keep reaching.
paragraph2: At the heart of writing is a kind of loneliness, even though it's often about connection. Writers come from all sorts of backgrounds, carrying their own unique baggage and desires, yet they share this weird compulsion to throw words at the page, hoping something sticks. It's like we’re all on this cracked, old ship, riding different waves but aiming for the same distant shore, though we might not even agree on what that shore looks like. The drive comes from some deep place—some of us from a need to make sense of trauma, others just wanting to entertain or enlighten. This drive welds us together in a way; it’s a shared struggle, an invisible tether. And that struggle shapes the work. You can almost always tell when someone has fought tooth and nail with their sentences. The purpose, then, isn’t singular. It’s this blurry mix of personal and collective ambition. And maybe that’s why readers resonate with well-wrought stories—they feel the echoes of that shared drive, and it speaks to their own. So, while our backgrounds might diverge wildly, this shared path of relentless crafting somehow unites us, quietly pushing each of us to keep writing, to keep reaching.

paragraph1: A couple weeks later, Rafa disappeared. Took the Monarch and vanished. No note or telephone call, nada. Gone for one day, gone for two. By then Mami was starting to flip seriously out. Had the Four Horsefaces putting out an A.P.B. on the godline. Walked around the neighborhood asking everybody if they’d seen my brother, even the gringos, and my mother had to be under serious duress to speak to a gringo. I was starting to worry, too, remembering that when he was first diagnosed he’d jumped into his ride and tried to drive to Miami, where he had some boy or another. He hadn’t made it past Philly before his car broke down. I wondered if he was on his way to Cali or something. He’d always wanted to see L.A. One of his dreams. I got worried enough that I walked over to Tammy Franco’s house, but when her Polack husband answered the door I lost my nerve. I turned around and walked away. On the third night we were in the apartment just waiting when the Monarch pulled up. My mother ran over to the porch. Holding the curtains until her knuckles were white. No, she said finally. Rafa stomped in with Pura in tow. He was clearly drunk, and Pura was dressed as if they’d just been at a club. Where have you been? Mami said. Check it out, Rafa said, holding out both his and Pura’s hands. They had rings on. We got married! It’s totally official, Pura said giddily, pulling the license from her purse. You should have seen the expression on my mother’s face. It was worse than when my father ran off with his putika. Worse than when the doctor had first said the word “leukemia.” Her face drained of everything. Is she pregnant? Not yet, Pura said. Is she pregnant? My mother looked straight at my brother. No, Rafa said. I’m going to be moving in, cuñada. Pura went to hug my mother. Let’s have a drink, my brother said. My mother stopped Pura with an upraised finger. No one is drinking in my house. I’m having a drink. My brother walked toward the kitchen but my mother stiff-armed him. Ma, Rafa said. No one is drinking in this house. She pushed Rafa back. If this—she threw her hand in Pura’s direction—is how you want to spend what might be the last months of your life, then, Rafael Urbano, I have nothing more to say to you. Please, I would like you and your puta to leave my house. My brother’s eyes went flat. I ain’t going anywhere. I want you—and this is when she started shrieking—out of here! For a second I thought my brother, who had punched every fucking thing that had ever crossed him—boys, girls, men, women, viejos, white boys, morenos, Boricuas, Filipinos, chinos, teachers, policemen—but had never in his life put his hand on my mother, was going to pop her. I really did. And for an instant I think he considered it. But then all the swolt went out of him. He put his arm around Pura (who, for once, looked as if she understood that something was wrong). I’ll see you later, Ma, he said. Then he got back into the Monarch and drove away.
paragraph2: The tension in our house reached its breaking point when Rafa finally returned after three days of complete silence, during which Mami had barely slept, constantly pacing between the window and the phone. When he walked through the door with Pura by his side, something in Mami's eyes changed – a mixture of relief instantly morphing into confusion, then anger. "We got married," Rafa announced, his voice carrying a defiant pride that made my stomach twist. Mami's face drained of color as she processed the news, her hands gripping the kitchen counter so hard her knuckles turned white. I stood in the corner, watching the scene unfold like a witness to an inevitable crash. "¿Estás loco?" Mami's voice trembled, barely above a whisper at first, then rising like a storm. "How could you do this? With your condition? Without telling me?" Rafa's health had always been a source of worry for all of us, but he hated being reminded of it, and I could see his jaw tightening at Mami's words. Pura stood slightly behind him, her face a mask of discomfort and determination. The argument escalated quickly, with Mami's words becoming sharper, more cutting, as she demanded they leave her house immediately. "You want to play husband? Then go be a man and provide for your wife somewhere else!" she shouted, her accent thickening with emotion. Rafa started to argue back, his voice matching her intensity, but there was a hint of desperation in it that I hadn't heard before. I wanted to intervene, to say something that would make everything okay, but the words stuck in my throat. The air in the room felt thick with unspoken feelings and years of complicated history. Finally, after what seemed like hours but was probably only minutes, Rafa grabbed Pura's hand and headed for the door. He paused briefly, looking back at Mami with a mixture of hurt and anger that made him seem both older and younger than his years. "Vámonos," he said to Pura, his voice now eerily calm. As they left, Mami turned away, her shoulders shaking slightly, but she didn't make a sound. I stood there, torn between following my brother and comforting my mother, feeling the weight of family loyalty pulling me in opposite directions. The sound of the front door closing echoed through the house like a gunshot, marking the moment our family dynamic changed forever. The silence that followed was deafening, filled with all the things we should have said differently, all the ways we could have handled it better, and all the love that somehow got lost in translation between generations and expectations.

paragraph1: To experience London's essence in 36 hours, start your morning early at Borough Market, where centuries-old arches house an array of global and local flavors. From there, stroll across the Thames via the Millennium Bridge, taking in both St. Paul's Cathedral's historical grandeur and the Tate Modern's contemporary innovation. Continue your city-wide exploration by hopping on a red double-decker bus toward the East End, and wander through Brick Lane, where street art narrates the evolving story of the area’s diverse communities. By late afternoon, head to the West End to rest your legs and catch a matinee. Once the curtain falls, weave through Covent Garden as dusk settles, soaking in the street performances and boutique shops. End your night with a midnight snack at Duck & Waffle, overlooking the cityscape. Capturing the youthful vibrancy and ancient foundations of London in a short amount of time comes down to syncing up your curiosity to the already thumping rhythm of the city.
paragraph2: To experience London's essence in 36 hours, start your morning early at Borough Market, where centuries-old arches house an array of global and local flavors. From there, stroll across the Thames via the Millennium Bridge, taking in both St. Paul's Cathedral's historical grandeur and the Tate Modern's contemporary innovation. Hop on a red double-decker bus toward the East End, and wander through Brick Lane, where street art narrates the evolving story of the area’s diverse communities. A lunch of bagels or curry from a food stall keeps your pace moving. By late afternoon, head to the West End for a matinee. Once the curtain falls, weave through Covent Garden as dusk settles, soaking in the street performances and boutique shops. Your evening can take a turn towards either history or nightlife: a pint at a pub that Dickens once frequented or a sleek cocktail bar in Shoreditch. End your night with a midnight snack at Duck & Waffle, overlooking the cityscape. To capture both the youthful vibrancy and ancient foundations, your journey needs a rhythm that listens as much as it explores.

paragraph1: Every morning before dawn, he loaded his Nissan Maxima with stacks of newspapers, methodically preparing for his delivery route while maintaining contact with his wife through unreliable phone cards that often cut their precious conversations short. The news of her pregnancy brought both joy and complexity to their situation, as it further complicated the already challenging visa process they were navigating. After meticulously completing the necessary paperwork and bidding farewell to his newspaper delivery job, he made the journey to Pakistan, where he finally reunited with his wife and their newborn child. His life took a new direction when he began working for Agha Sahib, a prominent businessman in the rug trade, where his responsibilities extended beyond merely showcasing and selling luxurious carpets. While managing his household duties, he found himself entangled in elaborate schemes against Agha Sahib's business rival, Sayeed Sahib, adding an unexpected dimension to his professional life. The birth of his second son marked another milestone in his journey, but the joy was later tempered by the somber task of escorting the deceased Hajji Atal back to Pakistan for burial, a duty that reminded him of life's impermanence. His career as a rug seller, which had become central to his identity and financial stability, eventually came to an end, forcing him to once again adapt to changing circumstances and seek new opportunities.
paragraph2: Duties included: filling the trunk and back seat of a Nissan Maxima with copies of the Hayward Daily Review; delivering papers from 3 A.M. to 6 A.M.; calling wife every other night with shitty phone cards that always ate two minutes out of every five; finding out wife was pregnant; learning that the pregnancy would delay the visa process; delivering more papers; completing wife’s visa paperwork after she passed her interview at the embassy in Peshawar; quitting job as a newspaper deliveryman in order to fly back to Pakistan to pick up wife and child. Duties included: showcasing rugs; lifting two-hundred-pound rugs onto racks mounted along walls; cooking and cleaning for Agha Sahib, a wealthy Hazara businessman from Kabul; coming up with absurd plans to sabotage Agha Sahib’s brother and main rival, Sayeed Sahib, who owned a different rug shop one block away; hosting parties at the store; serving the legendary Ustad Mahwash; hearing her sing in person; witnessing the birth of a second son and the death of Hajji Atal; escorting Hajji Atal’s body back to Pakistan because the mujahideen were now at war with the Taliban, and there was no way to enter Logar; locating a graveyard atop a steep hill in Peshawar, where Hajji Atal was born a hundred and four years earlier, the eldest son of the nomad Lahore, who was the son of the nomad Sayed Akbar, who was the son of the nomad Mahdat, who was the son of the nomad Azmat, who was the son of the nomad Shahee, who died attempting to kill a tiger with his bare hands; losing job as a rug seller in the process.

paragraph1: He offered the dish—a silver porringer given to the Maples as a wedding present and until yesterday, for lack of space, never unpacked—to his wife, who took a greedy handful. She looked so pale that he asked, “How do you feel?,” not so much forgetting the presence of their guest as parading his concern—quite genuine, at that—before her. “Fine,” Joan said, edgily, and perhaps she did. Though the Maples told some stories—how they had lived in a log cabin in a Y.M.C.A. camp for the first three months of their married life, how Bitsy Flaner, a friend of them all, was the only girl enrolled in Bentham Divinity School, how Richard’s advertising work brought him into contact with Yogi Berra—they did not regard themselves (that is, each other) as raconteurs, and Rebecca’s slight voice dominated the talk. She had a gift for odd things. Her rich old cousin lived in a metal house, furnished with auditorium chairs. He was terribly afraid of fire. Right before the depression, he had built an enormous boat to take himself and some friends to Polynesia. All his friends lost their money in the crash. He did not. He made money. He made money out of everything. But he couldn’t go on the trip alone, so the boat was still waiting in Oyster Bay—a huge thing, rising thirty feet out of the water. The cousin was a vegetarian. Rebecca had not eaten turkey for Thanksgiving until she was thirteen years old, because it was the family custom to go to the cousin’s house on that holiday. The custom was dropped during the war, when the children’s synthetic heels made black marks all over his asbestos floor. Rebecca’s family had not spoken to the cousin since. “Yes, what got me,” Rebecca said, “was the way each new wave of vegetables would come in as if it were a different course.”
paragraph2: Richard Maple extended the serving dish toward Joan, his wife, who reached out with a noticeably pale hand to take a modest portion of food. His eyes lingered on her with apparent concern, a gesture that seemed both genuine and performative in the presence of their dinner guest, Rebecca. The Maples, though not particularly gifted in the art of storytelling, attempted to contribute to the evening's conversation by sharing snippets from their early marriage and mutual acquaintances, but their narratives fell flat in comparison to Rebecca's animated tales. She commanded the dinner table's attention with stories about her wealthy and eccentric cousin, who had chosen to reside in an unconventional metal house. Rebecca's voice grew more enthusiastic as she described her cousin's ambitious yet unfulfilled projects, including the construction of an enormous boat for a voyage that never materialized. The evening air filled with her reminiscences of peculiar family traditions and the gradual unraveling of their relationship, which had ultimately led to estrangement. Her stories painted a vivid picture of wealth mixed with eccentricity, family dynamics tinged with complexity, and traditions that seemed both cherished and strange. As the dinner progressed, Rebecca's narratives continued to captivate her hosts, culminating in an amusing observation about the unique way vegetables were presented at her cousin's metal abode, a detail that somehow encapsulated the overall oddity of her family history. Throughout the evening, Joan remained quiet and pale, while Richard alternated between showing concern for his wife and engaging politely with their guest's fascinating stories.

He made money out of everything. But he couldn’t go on the trip alone, so the boat was still waiting in Oyster Bay—a huge thing, rising thirty feet out of the water. The cousin was a vegetarian. Rebecca had not eaten turkey for Thanksgiving until she was thirteen years old, because it was the family custom to go to the cousin’s house on that holiday. The custom was dropped during the war, when the children’s synthetic heels made black marks all over his asbestos floor. Rebecca’s family had not spoken to the cousin since. “Yes, what got me,” Rebecca said, “was the way each new wave of vegetables would come in as if it were a different course.”

Paragraph 2:
Richard Maple extended the serving dish toward Joan, his wife, who reached out with a noticeably pale hand to take a modest portion of food. His eyes lingered on her with apparent concern, a gesture that seemed both genuine and performative in the presence of their dinner guest, Rebecca. The Maples, though not particularly gifted in the art of storytelling, attempted to contribute to the evening's conversation by sharing snippets from their early marriage and mutual acquaintances, but their narratives fell flat in comparison to Rebecca's animated tales. She commanded the dinner table's attention with stories about her wealthy and eccentric cousin, who had chosen to reside in an unconventional metal house. Rebecca's voice grew more enthusiastic as she described her cousin's ambitious yet unfulfilled projects, including the construction of an enormous boat for a voyage that never materialized. The evening air filled with her reminiscences of peculiar family traditions and the gradual unraveling of their relationship, which had ultimately led to estrangement. Her stories painted a vivid picture of wealth mixed with eccentricity, family dynamics tinged with complexity, and traditions that seemed both cherished and strange. As the dinner progressed, Rebecca's narratives continued to captivate her hosts, culminating in an amusing observation about the unique way vegetables were presented at her cousin's metal abode, a detail that somehow encapsulated the overall oddity of her family history. Throughout the evening, Joan remained quiet and pale, while Richard alternated between showing concern for his wife and engaging politely with their guest's fascinating stories.

{"preference": "1|2"}

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: I remember the day my parents took us to the mall for new school clothes. It was late August, humid and sticky. My older sister breezed through the stores, effortlessly picking out trendy outfits. I lagged behind, overwhelmed by the racks of clothes and the pressure to choose something "cool." Mom tried to help, holding up shirts she thought I'd like, but her suggestions only made me feel more out of place. Dad waited patiently by the dressing rooms, offering awkward thumbs-ups as we emerged in various ensembles. I finally settled on a pair of jeans and a plain T-shirt, feeling defeated. As we left the mall, my sister chatted excitedly about her new wardrobe while I stayed quiet, clutching my shopping bag. On the drive home, I noticed Dad glancing at me in the rearview mirror. He didn't say anything, but he reached back and squeezed my knee. It was a small gesture, but it made me feel less alone in my fashion frustration. That night, I carefully hung up my new clothes, wondering if I'd ever feel as comfortable in them as my sister seemed in hers.
paragraph2: I remember when I was starting middle school and my dad took my sister and me to the mall for new school clothes. It was late August, humid and sticky. My older sister already knew who she was, breezed through the stores picking out her black-on-black outfits. I felt overwhelmed. Mom tried to help, holding up shirts she thought I'd like, but her suggestions only made me feel more out of place. Dad waited patiently by the dressing rooms, offering awkward thumbs-ups as we emerged in various ensembles. I finally settled on a pair of jeans and a plain T-shirt. I knew it was what I was supposed to like. As we left the mall, my sister chatted excitedly about her new wardrobe while I stayed quiet, clutching my shopping bag. On the drive home, I noticed Dad glancing at me in the rearview mirror. He didn't say anything, but he reached back and squeezed my knee. It was a small gesture, but it made me feel less alone. That night, I carefully hung up my new clothes, wondering if I'd ever feel as comfortable in them as my sister seemed in hers.

paragraph1: And then, miraculously, I made the acquaintance of Régine. “How did you find me?” “By chance and persistence, which is to say that the tenacity I devoted not to finding you, exactly, since I had no idea you existed, but to following the trail of the good Denis led me to you, by accident, by fortune.” “Yes, Denis. Why do you call him the good Denis?” “That’s how people speak of him to me. Is it not true?” “Oh, it is, it is. Oh, yes, yes. The too good Denis, if you see what I mean, the excessively good Denis, perhaps, but, yes, he was good, I suppose.” “You’re not sure?” “Oh, I am, I am. His goodness was like a thunderbolt, you see. No, I’m wrong, his goodness was like the slow fire that descends from the heavens and settles over your soul and convinces you, numbs you, makes you feel you’re nothing much but gives you hope that with meditation, integrity, and honor you may eventually become blessed yourself. You see, Denis, without knowing it or wanting it, was truly a saint. Like any saint, I suppose, he could be fearsome and terrifying in his greatness, that greatness of which he was unaware. Implacably rigorous in pursuing a goodness he clearly didn’t register. That’s where you come in.” “Me? But, you understand, I don’t know him.” “You did, though, even if you were too young to remember. And what matters in all this is that he knew you well, he raised you, he cared for you like his own daughter, and he loved you the same way, happily, passionately. It was because of you that he refused to have a child with me, out of a monstrously virtuous fidelity to his memory of that tiny girl, you. ‘I can’t let another child into my memory,’ he would tell me. ‘I can’t think of creating any competition between my memory of Mimi and the memory I might have of another little girl.’ And I answered, ‘But what makes you think you’d lose our child, too?’ And he said, ‘It happens. I owe it to Mimi to forever think of her as the only child I ever loved.’” “But I’m not dead!” “He lost you—it’s the same thing. As I understand it, your mother took you away one day, left him just like that, and of course you went with her. Denis’s glorious simplicity shielded him from hard feelings, and even from pointless anguish, from vainly protracted grief. He endured his lot with a smile. And, at the same time, he resolved to remain forever the father of only one child, you. Oh, not, as you must already understand, to spare himself other sorrows. He never gave that a thought. He had no fear of sorrow, and he didn’t wallow in it. It’s just that the inexorable, unyielding nature of his marvellous humanity had led him to decide that because he’d loved you desperately, and because you’d been taken away from him without your wanting it at all, he owed it to you never to attach himself to any other child, ever.” “That’s ridiculous! It’s absurd!” “I don’t know. That was Denis. That was why I left him. I went on to have the children I wanted, of course, with other men. But I miss the child Denis and I would have had, so I can’t help resenting you a little. Forgive me, it’s not your fault.” The strange damage that goodness can do! When I asked Régine how she felt about my wish to meet in person, she seemed surprised and shocked, as if I were proposing something utterly immoral. “What reason would I have for meeting you? The adult that you are has no place in my life, you don’t interest me. And also I want to forget the good Denis—I’ve been working on that all this time. Meet you? Who do you think you are? How indecent! You do not interest me, Madame. To me, Madame, you are only the faded reflection of a child who caused my unhappiness. I couldn’t hate the little girl Denis so loved that he couldn’t imagine giving the smallest share of his unlimited tenderness to any other, even his own—I couldn’t hate her, because you can’t hate a child. But the woman you’ve become I can only resent, however unfair that may be.” Although it was hard, I decided not to ask for Régine’s forgiveness. I asked only if she knew where the good Denis lived. “I do not, and I have no wish to. I’m not good. I haven’t entirely freed myself from anger and acrimony, brooding and pointless self-pity. I’m quite sure that Denis, in his radiant, indifferent goodness, never broods. Happy are the blessed! Does he remember me? Or has he, for my own good, erased me from his memory? If you meet him, tell him about me, I’m begging you, mention Régine. . . .” I wasn’t good, either. If ever I did have the chance to meet Denis, I would certainly not speak the name of this Régine, who had, there’s no other word for it, cursed me. I wasn’t good, either. I tried not to be proud of that. I would have been ashamed of my pride, but still proud.
paragraph2: I first learned about Régine through a series of peculiar circumstances that revolved around Denis, whom everyone referred to as "the good Denis," and this encounter would ultimately reveal a complex web of emotions and unspoken histories that I never could have anticipated. The story unfolded gradually, with Régine eventually sharing the profound impact Denis had on her life, but what she revealed next shook me to my core – Denis had harbored an intense, almost sacred love for me when I was a child, so much so that it had prevented him from having children with her, a fact that had caused her immense pain and resentment over the years. As she recounted her story, I could feel the weight of her words, heavy with years of suppressed emotions and unfulfilled dreams, all somehow connected to my unknowing presence in Denis's life. Her revelation was both touching and disturbing, painting a picture of Denis as a man whose capacity for love had somehow become fixated on a child – me – to the detriment of his adult relationships, particularly his relationship with Régine. The complexity of her feelings was evident in how she spoke about Denis, mixing reverence for his saintly nature with the bitter acknowledgment of how his devotion to me had ultimately led to her own unhappiness. When I expressed a desire to meet her in person, perhaps hoping to bridge this unexpected gap between us or offer some form of reconciliation, she firmly rejected the idea, making it clear that she preferred to forget both Denis and her resentment towards me as an adult. Her rejection forced me to confront my own role in this complicated narrative, though I had been merely a child and unaware of the impact my presence had on their lives. As I reflected on this situation, I became acutely aware of my own lack of goodness, particularly in comparison to Denis's apparent saintliness, and I made the conscious decision not to seek Régine's forgiveness, understanding that some wounds are better left untouched. This experience left me with a peculiar resolution: if I ever were to encounter Denis again, I would keep my knowledge of Régine and her story buried deep within me, maintaining the silence that she so desperately sought. The whole situation had revealed layers of human complexity I hadn't expected to encounter – how one person's pure love could inadvertently cause another's suffering, how childhood innocence could unknowingly cast long shadows into adult lives, and how the past continues to shape our present in ways we can never fully understand. The story of Régine, Denis, and my unwitting role in their narrative became a testament to the intricate ways in which human lives intersect and affect one another, often without our knowledge or consent, and how some relationships, despite their significance, are better left in the realm of memory rather than pursued into the present. This realization came with a certain melancholy, an understanding that sometimes the kindest action is to respect the distances that others choose to maintain, even when those distances are born from pain and resentment that we didn't intentionally cause. The entire experience left me with a profound appreciation for the complexity of human relationships and the way that love, even in its purest form, can sometimes lead to unexpected consequences that ripple through time, affecting lives in ways we could never predict or fully comprehend. The situation with Régine and Denis had become a lesson in the delicate balance between understanding and action, between the desire to make amends and the wisdom to know when to step back, and ultimately, about the complicated nature of human

paragraph1: Their friends found him charming; he was famous for his passionate arguments, his stormy exits, followed by exorbitant apologies, heartfelt embraces, exquisite handwritten notes. Beloved, he was, flaws and all. He said one more thing before hanging up: “I don’t care if you sleep with him, but you have to tell me. Agreed?” “I’m not going to sleep with him,” Nana said. She closed the cell phone and held it to her throat, shut her eyes, and felt Pete all around her. Now she debated phoning Helen. One wanted to tell, she realized. After the initial crucial privacy, one wished to speak aloud what had transpired. As an excuse, as an opening gambit, she could ask Helen to keep an eye on her husband’s drinking at the Merrills’; also, she could thank Helen for the flowers, which had arrived that afternoon, lurid non-native blossoms that vaguely alarmed Lil. Nana could ask what Helen would be wearing tonight, what had happened at Libby’s, two evenings before. Rebecca answered at Helen’s house. “She’s over at your place,” the girl said. “No, I’m in Kansas. My father was in an accident.” Nana started to fill in with the information about his hospitalization, when Rebecca cut her off with an exasperated sigh. “Come on, Nana. Do you really not know what’s going on with them? Are you really so totally out of touch?” “I’m sorry?” Nana’s first thought was that Rebecca was drunk or high, that she had regressed to the terrifying adolescence that her parents believed had, thank God, passed. “It’s been, like, years,” Rebecca went on. “If I know, if my brothers know, it just seems impossible that you don’t know. Doesn’t it?” The girl paused. Nana had pushed herself back to the window that led onto the roof, was beginning to climb inside. Fear had gripped her; she felt as if she might suddenly, after all these years, truly be at risk of falling from her perch. “O.K., whatever,” Rebecca said. “I’ll tell her you called.” Nana was out the front door before she realized she’d gone down the stairs. They’d flown beneath her feet, lightly, as if she had floated from second to first floor, noting on her way the purple-and-black flowers from Helen, obscene red stamens lingering on her retina as she left her parents’ porch. She went straight to the Dixons’ house, stepping up Pete’s walkway and to his front, rather than side, door. Her mother did not have a view of the front door from her kitchen window. Her father could not see it from where he was propped before the television in the den.
paragraph2: Nana held the phone away from her ear as Pete's voice crescendoed with his familiar mix of charm and volatility, a combination that had drawn her in countless times before. His latest demand echoed through the receiver – an insistence on knowing about any future intimate encounters she might have with other men – to which she firmly declined, recognizing the possessiveness that often masked itself as concern in his words. As the call ended, her thoughts drifted to Helen, contemplating whether to reach out about her husband's drinking problem or simply express gratitude for the flowers she'd recently sent. The decision to dial Helen's number led to an unexpected conversation with Rebecca, whose cryptic revelation that Helen was already at Nana's place sent a chill down her spine. Rebecca's tone carried an undercurrent of knowledge about something Nana herself seemed oblivious to, transforming what should have been a simple phone call into a moment of mounting dread. The weight of unspoken words and hidden meanings in Rebecca's voice propelled Nana into action, her heart racing as she gathered her belongings and prepared to leave her parents' house. With the practiced stealth of someone accustomed to avoiding difficult conversations, she carefully maneuvered her way out, taking extra precautions to remain unseen by her parents, who would undoubtedly have questions she wasn't prepared to answer. The journey to Pete's house felt like walking through a minefield of potential revelations, each step bringing her closer to whatever truth awaited her there. Her mind raced with possibilities, trying to piece together the puzzle of Helen's unexpected presence at her place and Rebecca's knowing tone, all while grappling with the emotional aftermath of Pete's possessive phone call. The convergence of these elements – Pete's turbulent nature, Helen's mysterious whereabouts, and Rebecca's loaded words – created a perfect storm of anxiety that threatened to overwhelm her as she made her way through the familiar streets, each step heavy with the weight of impending discovery.

paragraph1: It didn’t take us all that long to find Wagner, though time had grown a bit fishy at this point. We scrabbled through doors and rooms, and when we got to the library a voice said, “Come in, come in,” as if it had been expecting us. The voice belonged to a man of perhaps seventy-one, who was sitting low behind a desk, sipping from a snifter of what looked like corrupted urine and talking on a phone that for an instant I took to be a large kitten. It was such a striking sight that I almost missed the Amazonian woman standing to the side in a studded black leather bra and garters. I did a double take, but she didn’t seem to register my gaze, just looked off glassily with impassive disgust and worked the tassels of her riding crop like a rosary. “Satellite,” Wagner told us, covering the mouthpiece with his hand. Then: “Yeah, yeah, go fuck yourself, Fred. Ten A.M.” “Mustique,” he said, putting the phone down. “I’m supposed to fly out tonight.” “Frank,” Eli said, and took a few larger-than-normal steps toward Wagner and held out his hand, smiling as if they were old war buddies whom a comedy of errors had kept apart for years. “Do I know you?” Wagner said. “I don’t think I know you.” Eli laughed his public laugh. “Eli. Eli Geller-Frucht,” he said. “I’m the writer on the Hirschman film. ‘Philosopher’s Whetstone’? Actually that title sucks, but Marley Jones at Buzzard told me her people talked to your people, she said you had a personal connection to the story—tell me if I’m making this up? Your wife’s family? So we’re thinking sort of a John Nash in ‘The Good Shepherd’ thing, but without all the schizophrenia, of course, and David’s got this big fucking man-crush on Louis Malle, so we’re doing kind of an ‘Au Revoir les Enfants’ open, very faithful to the spirit of Hirschman’s story, you know, but—” Wagner held up a hand as though in some vague pain. “Yeah, yeah, I get it. I talked to David. Look, I’m on board. I don’t give a fuck about Hirschman, but my wife, Lydia, she won’t shut up about ‘Nana would have wanted to see her Albie as Zac Efron’ or whatever. It’s fucking ridiculous, but you get to the point of certain understandings”—Wagner inclined his head toward the half-dressed woman in the corner—“and, well, you get the picture.” He put his hands on the desk and raised himself, and he must have been sitting in a comically small chair, because when he stood, far from being the wizened troll I had come to imagine, he loomed over both of us, six-four easy, with an elegant and gawky grace. “Here,” he said, “give me some of that blow you’re on and I’ll let you in on a secret.” Eli reached into his pocket without taking his eyes off Wagner and passed him the bag. The man looked at us like we had to be joking but then produced a two-inch piece of straw from the breast pocket of his jacket and snorted everything that was left, right from the plastic. He thumbed his nose and sniffed a few times, then gave a small shrug of disdain and settled, half sitting, on the front of the desk. “That coke sucks, but I’ll tell you, anyway,” he said. “Here’s what I was going to say: Stop giving so much of a shit.” We blinked at him. “What do you mean?” I said. I love that you can ask people what they mean right after they’ve said the most obvious things and almost invariably they’ll assume that they are the ones who’ve failed to be clear and go to elaborate lengths to make themselves understood. Wagner looked at me, then turned to Eli. “Your friend’s retarded,” he said. “What I mean is—look, if you care about something, like horses, go raise horses. Go ride them and fuck them or whatever people do with horses. Sell them to Arabs, I’d guess. But if you’re going to stay in this crappy business, and they’re all crappy, stop giving a shit. Because you’re here for one reason and you should know what that reason is. Do you?” He looked from one of us to the other, then barked “Sonia!,” and we jumped, but Sonia didn’t. She just walked over and spanked us both insanely hard on the ass with her riding crop. “The reason you’re here,” Wagner said, “is that you already have nice cars”—I didn’t, but I went along with the spirit of his admonition—“and girlfriends with that taut skin, and nice rentals in the hills—or maybe you own?” He looked at us doubtfully. “But you don’t have the good stuff, do you, the really hard-to-come-by shit. You know what I’m talking about: Envy. Serious, irrefutable reasons for people to envy you. And not just any sort of people, of course. You need people well informed enough to understand just how enviable you are. And people clever enough to know how to show their envy without being sycophants, and worldly enough to be charming company while they’re envying you. . . . You need courtiers, see? Oh, they’re better and worse than friends. They don’t care about you, sure, but they understand the terms of your success far better than a friend ever could. paragraph2: As I followed Eli through the musty aisles of the library, the scent of old books and stale air filled my nostrils, and the soft hum of fluorescent lights overhead seemed to reverberate through my entire being. We had been working on our film project for months, and Eli, ever the networker, had insisted that we needed to get out and meet people, make connections, and get our names out there. I had reluctantly agreed, and so here we were, surrounded by dusty tomes and whispering patrons, on the hunt for someone, anyone, who might be able to help us break into the industry. That's when we saw him - Wagner, an older man with a commanding presence, sipping a drink from a flask and talking on his phone in hushed tones. He was a striking figure, with a wild shock of white hair and a bushy beard to match, and his eyes seemed to gleam with a knowing intensity that made me feel like an insect under a microscope. Nearby, an Amazonian woman with long, curly hair and a bright smile stood watching him, her eyes never leaving his face. Eli, undaunted by Wagner's formidable appearance, strode right up to him and introduced himself, explaining our film project and asking if he might be willing to offer some advice. At first, Wagner was dismissive, barely looking up from his phone as he muttered a few curt words, but Eli persisted, and eventually, Wagner's demeanor softened, and he began to engage with us. As we talked, I found myself drawn into Wagner's orbit, captivated by his world-weary cynicism and the way he seemed to see right through the façade of the industry we were trying to break into. "Don't care too much," he told us, his voice dripping with disdain. "That's the secret to success. Don't get too attached, don't get too invested. Because the minute you do, someone will come along and rip it all away from you." Eli and I exchanged a skeptical glance, but Wagner just chuckled, a dry, mirthless sound, and continued, "You think I'm kidding, but I'm not. I've been around the block a few times, and I've seen it happen to the best of them. You want to make it in this business? Learn to not care." As he spoke, Sonia, the Amazonian woman, watched him with an intensity that bordered on devotion, and I found myself wondering what her story was, how she had ended up in Wagner's orbit. Wagner, seeming to sense my curiosity, smiled wryly and said, "Sonia here knows all about pain. Real pain, not the fake stuff they peddle in the movies. She's been through hell and back, and she's still standing." Sonia's eyes never left Wagner's face, but I could sense a flicker of emotion behind them, a deep well of feeling that seemed to underscore Wagner's words. Eventually, Eli and I bid Wagner farewell, thanking him for his time and advice, and made our way out of the library, into the bright, cold sunlight. The encounter had left me feeling unsettled, unsure of what to make of Wagner's jaded perspective, and I couldn't shake the feeling that we were just pawns in a much larger game. Later that night, at a New Year's Eve party, I found myself lost in thought, replaying the conversation with Wagner in my head. I had also been thinking about a conversation I had with Lily, a friend from college, about the futility of pursuing a romantic relationship. She had been going through a tough breakup, and I had

paragraph1: You watch as the family's life unfolds like a carefully orchestrated dance of daily routines and quiet struggles. After Hajji breaks a window and attempts to repair it, the cold seeps in relentlessly, forcing Bibi to seek refuge in the boys' room while Marvin and Mo relocate to the living room. Their nightly snoring creates an unwanted symphony that draws constant complaints from the girls in the adjacent room. The brothers share whispered conversations about money troubles, speculating about their father's mysterious handling of bills, though they never muster the courage to ask him directly. Mo's private battle with his health – the worrying sight of blood in his stool – remains unaddressed as he stubbornly avoids medical attention. Meanwhile, Mary's academic success brings a bright moment to the household when she achieves an impressive GPA. Hajji celebrates this achievement by bringing home doughnuts, and Bibi lightens the mood with a culturally pointed joke about not having to trade Mary for goats. The family erupts in laughter, and for a moment, they could be any sitcom family, their problems temporarily forgotten in shared mirth. Yet beneath this scene of domestic harmony, the undercurrents of their various struggles continue to flow, binding them together in ways both complex and profound.
paragraph2: When the family finally sleeps, you listen to them dream. In the course of the next few weeks, you search for clues, signs, evidence of evil intentions. But to no avail. Life merely goes on. Hajji repairs a window he broke while attempting to repaint his mother’s room. Cold floods the house. Bibi moves into the boys’ room, and the boys sleep in the living room. No longer able to sneak away from each other, they carry out long conversations before falling asleep. They discuss their family’s finances, their suspicion that their father is hiding bills from them. They plan to confront him but never go through with it. When they sleep, both of the boys snore, Marvin whistling and Mo sort of growling, and the girls, whose bedroom is closest to the living room, complain to each other all night. The timing of the boys’ snoring is uncanny. There is a certain rhythm to it. When Mo murmurs, Marvin bursts, and, when Marvin quiets, Mo roars. The girls refer to it as “the symphony.” Eventually, though, the girls fall asleep and you become the sole listener. Mo notices blood in his stool but doesn’t go to a doctor. Mary earns a 4.3 G.P.A. for the semester, and Hajji buys doughnuts for the whole family. They all sit in the living room, eating doughnuts and drinking tea, and Bibi jokes that now they won’t have to sell Mary for a pair of goats. The whole family laughs as though in a scene in a sitcom.

paragraph1: As Husna navigated the complex social hierarchy of her city, she found herself in a unique position, one that didn't quite fit into the traditional mold of her community. This air of mystery surrounding her was precisely what drew Harouni in, a man with a history of romantic entanglements with the maidservants who worked for his family. His fascination with Husna was evident, and she, in turn, seemed to revel in the attention, skillfully manipulating the dynamics of their interactions to her advantage. It was six weeks after her initial walk with K.K. that Begum Harouni announced her plans to embark on a pilgrimage, an event that would temporarily upend the household's routine. Husna seized this opportunity to engage Harouni in conversation, discussing the begum's impending departure with a mixture of curiosity and concern. As they spoke, Husna busied herself making Harouni's tea, her small hands moving deftly as she worked. She joked about her inability to type, a lighthearted remark that caught Harouni off guard and led to a moment of shared amusement between them. Despite the begum's absence, Husna expressed worry about not being able to visit the household, but K.K. was quick to reassure her, insisting that she was welcome to visit even more frequently. This exchange was telling, revealing the extent to which Husna had insinuated herself into the household's rhythms and relationships. Rafik and Shah Sahib, too, were drawn into her orbit, their interactions with her characterized by a sense of warmth and familiarity. As the days passed, it became increasingly clear that Husna's presence was having a profound impact on the household, one that would only continue to grow in her influence. And yet, despite her charm and charisma, Husna remained an enigma, a woman whose true nature and intentions were impossible to fully discern.
paragraph2: She did not behave or speak in the way of the women he normally met, for she had always inhabited an indefinite space, neither rich nor poor, neither servant nor begum, in a city where the very concept of a middle class still found expression in only a few households, among managers of banks and of big industrial concerns—sugar and textiles and steel. As a boy, Harouni had slept with maidservants, lost his virginity to one of them at fourteen. Husna evoked those ripe first encounters. Six weeks after Husna’s initial walk with K.K., Begum Harouni announced a pilgrimage to the Holy Places, in order to perform the umrah. Husna decided to bring the begum’s impending departure into the conversation with Harouni that afternoon, before any guests arrived and interrupted them. When Rafik brought afternoon tea into the living room, K.K. could hear the typewriter clacking in the background. It stopped, and then Husna knocked. She opened the door, showing her head without entering. “Come in, my dear.” Husna’s cultivation of Rafik had progressed to the point where he included an extra cup on the tea trolley. She drew herself forward and made K.K.’s tea exactly as he liked it. A boy passed a plate of biscuits, while Rafik stood back on his heels by the door. “When I’m here,” Husna said, “everything is so nice and everyone is pleasant. These biscuits, the tea. Shah Sahib tries so hard to teach me the typing, though I can’t seem to learn.” She held out her hands and spread her fingers in front of him, like a cat stretching. “My hands are so tiny, I can’t reach the keys. But then all of me is small.” She wore a tight kurta, showing the cleft of her breasts, which jutted out from her muscular youthful torso. Their eyes met; they both saw the joke, and he allowed himself a tight-lipped smile, his composed expression becoming avid and boyish. “That’s what I’ve been telling you about,” Husna purred, putting her hand on his arm. “Your crocodile smile, the one I like.” After pausing for a moment, she lowered her eyes and said in a meek voice, “But soon I won’t be able to come here. The begum is going on umrah, so I’ll have to be in charge of her house.” “Not umrah again!” K.K. said. “It’s becoming a vice with her. But, darling, don’t be ridiculous. If she’s away, you can come even more regularly.”

paragraph1: As the sweltering August sun beat down on London in 1956, Hanwell received news that would set him on a journey of discovery. His father, a man he had grown distant from, had started a small business in a quaint village in Kent. A mix of curiosity and perhaps a glimmer of unacknowledged hope stirred within Hanwell, prompting him to embark on a solo bike ride to visit his father. Undeterred by the heat and the responsibilities of his young family, he set off early, his makeshift water carrier - an old kerosene bottle - strapped to his bike. As he pedaled along the A20 and meandered through village byroads, the purer air and lush countryside were a welcome respite from the city's grime. Thick hedgerows, heavy with summer growth, snagged at his shirt, leaving it tattered at the elbow, but Hanwell pressed on, unaware that this journey marked the beginning of a new chapter in his life, one that would eventually lead him to another family, waiting for him in the unknown future. For now, though, he was content to ride, the wind in his hair, and the sun on his face.

paragraph1: As I wandered through Florence's iconic piazzas, I couldn't help but feel a sense of dissonance between the city's breathtaking beauty and the overwhelming crowds that clogged it's streets. It's a paradox that has come to define Florence in the age of mass tourism: how to revel in the Renaissance grandeur while also respecting the delicate, ancient history and architecture. The answer, I uncovered, lies not in avoiding the tourist traps altogether, but in approaching them with intention and respectful distance. Visit the Uffizi Gallery in the morning or late in the evening, when the hordes have dissipated and the artwork can be truly appreciated. Explore the Oltrarno neighborhood, where local artisans and family-run restaurants offer a glimpse into Florence's authentic meals. Support local businesses like the Cooperativa Agricola Toscanini, which promotes sustainable agriculture and provides a taste of the region's rich culinary heritage. Consider staying in a locally-owned B&B or Airbnb, which can offer a more immersive experience and directly supports the Florentine residents. And when you do venture into the crowded streets, take a moment to pause, look up, and truly absorb the beauty that surrounds you – it's a reminder that even in the most tourist-central spots, there is always more to uncover. By adopting a more mindful approach to travel, visitors can help ensure that Florence's grandeur endures for generations to come, and avoid being consumed by the tourist industry.

paragraph1: From that day on, everyone who happened by our room—neighbors wanting to borrow stuff, residential computer staff, student-council candidates, all kinds of people to whom my small enthusiasms should have been a source of little or no concern—went out of their way to disabuse me of my great admiration for Albert Einstein. Einstein had invented the atomic bomb, mistreated dogs, neglected his children. “There were many greater geniuses than Einstein,” a guy from down the hall, who had stopped by to borrow my copy of Dostoyevsky’s “The Double,” said. “Alfred Nobel hated mathematics and didn’t give the Nobel Prize to any mathematicians. There were many who were more deserving.” “Oh.” I handed him the book. “Well, see you around.” “Thanks,” he said, glaring at the poster. “This is the man who beats his wife, forces her to solve his mathematical problems, and then denies her credit. And you put his picture on your wall.” “Listen, leave me out of this,” I said. “It’s not really my poster. It’s a complicated situation.” He wasn’t listening. “Einstein is synonymous with genius in this country, while many greater geniuses aren’t famous at all. Why is this? I am asking you.” I sighed. “Maybe it’s because he’s really the best, and even jealous mudslingers can’t hide his star quality,” I said. “Nietzsche would say that such a great genius is entitled to beat his wife.” That shut him up. After he left, I thought about taking down the poster. I wanted to be a courageous person, uncowed by other people’s dumb opinions. But which was the dumb opinion, thinking Einstein was so great or thinking he was the worst? Hannah and I both caught a terrible cold. We took turns buying cold medicine and knocked it back from the little plastic cup as if we were doing shots. When it came time to choose classes, everyone said it was of utmost importance to apply to freshman seminars, because otherwise it could be years before you had a chance to work with senior faculty.
paragraph2: As I sit in my room, surrounded by the familiar comforts of my daily life, I've come to realize that it's not just a personal sanctuary, but also a hub for interactions with others who often challenge my perspectives. My admiration for Albert Einstein, for instance, has been a subject of scrutiny for many who visit me. It's as if they feel compelled to disillusion me with negative opinions and so-called "facts" about his life and character. I recall a particular encounter with a guy from down the hall who borrowed a book from me, only to criticize the poster of Einstein hanging on my wall. He accused Einstein of being a bad husband and a plagiarist, among other things. I listened patiently, though with a hint of sarcasm, as I defended my admiration for the brilliant physicist. "So, you're saying I should only admire people who are perfect?" I asked, trying to hide my frustration. After he left, I couldn't help but wonder if I should take down the poster, not because I believed the criticisms, but because I was tired of justifying my admiration to others. On a more mundane note, I've been dealing with a cold, and Hannah has been kind enough to keep me company. As we sat on the couch, sniffling and sipping tea, I realized that I need to focus on more pressing matters - like applying to freshman seminars. It's time to look beyond the confines of my room and engage with the world outside, where I can explore my interests and passions without the need for justification. Despite the criticisms, my poster of Einstein remains, a reminder of the importance of staying true to oneself, even in the face of adversity.

paragraph1: A few days later, Li Hanlin came back from his trip. He found Lin Hong sitting on the balcony, indifferent to his homecoming. He laid his bag on the sofa, went over to Lin Hong, and looked at her. She seemed to have been struck dumb. “What’s wrong?” he said. Lin Hong’s eyes were fixed on the floor. Li Hanlin waited by her side, and when she still said nothing he went over to the sofa, opened his bag, and dumped out the dirty clothes, then looked at her. He was displeased to find her still staring at the floor. “What’s the meaning of this?” he said. Lin Hong turned away from him and surveyed the view from the balcony. Li Hanlin went back to rummaging around in his bag. He took out his other belongings and laid them on the sofa. Then he began to lose his temper. He walked over to Lin Hong and started to shout. “What the hell is this about? I come home and you put on a sourpuss face. What have I done to offend you now? You—” Li Hanlin stopped abruptly. He could see that a key was clasped between Lin Hong’s finger and thumb. There was a buzzing noise in his head. He stood there a moment, then went to his study and opened a drawer. Some magazines were stacked inside. He groped around underneath the magazines, but failed to find the neatly folded envelope in the right-hand corner. He realized that he was breathing heavily. Li Hanlin stood by the window for a long time. Then he left the room and walked quietly over to Lin Hong. He bent down. “You’ve been to my office?” Lin Hong sat there motionless. Li Hanlin looked at her. “You’ve read Qingqing’s letters?” Lin Hong began to tremble. Li Hanlin hesitated, then put his hand on her shoulder. Lin Hong jerked violently, knocking his hand away. It returned to its original position and hung there for a moment before he put it in his trouser pocket.
paragraph2: Li Hanlin returned home from his trip, his footsteps echoing softly against the polished wooden floors as he made his way through the familiar corridors of his apartment. The late afternoon sun cast a golden hue across the room, where Lin Hong sat on the balcony, her figure silhouetted against the fading light. Her posture was rigid, her eyes fixed on the horizon, seemingly oblivious to his presence. Li Hanlin's heart sank at her indifference, a cold reception he hadn't anticipated. He cleared his throat, attempting to break the icy silence with a cheerful greeting, but Lin Hong remained mute, her gaze unwavering and distant. Frustration bubbled within him as he moved to the bedroom, wrestling with the zipper of his travel-worn suitcase. Each item he unpacked was a reminder of his absence and her unspoken resentment. The tension in the room was palpable, an invisible barrier growing between them. Unable to contain his irritation any longer, he stormed onto the balcony, demanding an explanation for her cold demeanor. His voice was sharp, slicing through the air as he asked what was wrong. It was then that he noticed the small, gleaming key nestled in her trembling hand. A bolt of fear shot through him, and he rushed to his study, his heart pounding in his chest. The envelope was missing, confirming his worst fears. The letters from Qingqing, secrets he had hoped to keep hidden, were now exposed. He returned to Lin Hong, his anger mingled with desperation, and confronted her about the discovery. Her trembling increased, and when he reached out to touch her shoulder, she flinched, her eyes brimming with unshed tears. The emotional turmoil was etched on her face, a mirror to the guilt and distress that gnawed at him. Li Hanlin's facade of anger crumbled, revealing the vulnerability beneath. In that silent exchange, amidst the charged atmosphere of unspoken words and raw emotions, both grappled with the unraveling of trust, unsure of what lay ahead for their fractured relationship.
